Councellers shall choose their aldermen and shreiffe out of them that carrie 6 men. The aldermen shall have a maior by turnes except some greate disabillitie happeneth and then the next in turne shall be maior. The Maior and aldermen shall choose their governour either out of them that bee admitted to bee of the order of governours by the patrition, or the patrition himselfe. The maior and aldermen alsoe of [each] severall corporation shall have power to choose out of their corporation one of the order of governours or the patrition himselfe to bee of the provinciall councell, which councell being all chosen out of the patritions and the order of governoures in everie province, and consisteing of 5, 7, 9, 11, 18, or 15, they shall have a monethly president by turnes, whoe haveing 2 voices, hee shall for his moneth call and breake of [off] all assemblies, and untill the councell of union bee compleate, wee give them the same power, which wee doe give to our sayde councell of union, makeing all theire decrees to stand as lawe, till they are disanulled by us, by the generall parliament in Virginea or by the sayd councell of union, when it shall bee compleate and in force, accordeing to our order now sett downe. This councell of union being the most soveraigne councell wee will tearme a Syneretisme or councell of union with the councell of England and this councell shall bee chosen onely out of the patriotes of everie province, by a component number of electours chosen out of the order of governoures which are not patritions, one out of everie particular corporation, which electors shall bee chosen by the maior and aldermen.

Genoa hath three presidents, so likewise had Marseilles which is commended by Cicero to be the best commonwealth that was in his time, in the world. We nominate them monthly, because offices of great power amongst equals must not continue long, and the shorter they are the less they may enterprise against the state. Arist. pol. li. 2 et 3. We give them their turns because mutual preferment equally bestowed by turns doth preserve and defend cities and commonwealths; Arist. pol. li. 2. Three presidents because of the odd number, three is best, two being as much in proportion to one as 8 is to 4, so as although to dispute and try and examine a cause, the even number is to be preferred before the odd, yet to conclude and

The presidents being thus ordered their 3 voices or two of them shall conclude all causes that shall be controverted by equal voices and not concluded in the body of the council, the eldest councillor of which presidents shall summon and break up all assemblies, the number of this council must be 7, 9, 11, 13 or 15 at the most but in the minority of the plantation 3 may serve without any presidents, the elder councillor of the 38 to summon and break off the assemblies. And our will and pleasure is that (besides the oath of our supremacy which all our subjects there shall be sworn to once every year at the least) there shall be a particular oath framed, for all these councils to take, viz: that all their decrees shall be made as well for the uniting of Virginia to the crown of England as for the combining of the members to the whole, and that they will to their uttermost power endeavor to prevent all usurpation of encroachment upon our sovereign authority whatsoever. Reserving therefore to ourself our most high absolute and perpetual power of commanding and controlling all, that thereby our commissions and writs of justice may spread themselves over every person, and in every place through our whole dominions there, we do grant that this sovereign council, shall have authority to unite in command, and to appoint the number of the forces, putting the power of commanding them into one of our marshals' hands as chief, to all by turns, or to each one severally as occasion shall require, giving them our said council likewise authority to proclaim war and make peace with

This fault therefore that is not unjustly laid upon aristocracies that they are too long a determining the business of the commonwealth, whereby the monarchal form is far preferred before it, will by this means be taken away, this number of 3 adding more authority to the decree than the voice of one doth, that was not for nothing that there were six several magistrates in Rome at one time consisting of Triumvirs. Read in the book termed the geometrical motion, to which I refer them that desire to be better instructed herein. This allowance and limitation of a dictator is only in cases of necessity because desiring the naturals of the country, to tax tributes as well for a treasury for England as for Virginia, to dispose of the treasury in Virginia as the council in England have of the treasury in England, To make contracts with the king or company in England and consenting with them accordingly to rate the prices of commodities, which shall be sent hither or thither, to appoint the places where the forces and colonies shall be planted, to condemn and pardon, to banish, to confiscate, to proscribe according to the laws ordained, To call magistrates and governors to account, and in case of necessity limiting his time short and the place certain to institute any one man that shall have sovereign power as the dictators in Rome, and all this their authority and all things they have done thereby shall be firm and of force till it be disannulled by us and our council in England. This council of union cannot be complete, till there be 3 provinces. In the meantime the provincial council shall serve the turn, we giving them the said authority to exercise and use within their own provinces. 2504: 422 desperate diseases must have desperate remedies, poysons expelling poysons when the body of the state and councell is rent and torne in pieces into factions which deadens and destroys the power of it, when the army abroad mutinies or is distressed by being invyroned, besieged or caught in some strait, then and not till then must it be cured with this only and extremest last help of naming a dictatour, whose word governing all, the magistracies being suppressed, the laws made silent, he must not be called to an account for any thing he shall do, by the councell there. Thus the sword being put into the hands of some one brave and austere commander, who resolves and executes at an instant we cannot expect that the resolutions that come from a councell can be so sudden, RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY showing that the heads of these colonies are sparks derived from our hereditary monarchy) do give and grant unto them and their heirs for ever, the hereditary command of the sovereign forces, limiting them to use them only in their own colonies and in the wastes adjoining to them, except they be authorized to use them farther by the sovereign council of union, and to the end they shall only employ this our sword and forces to the supporting of our sovereignty and the maintenance of our justice there, We will give them for the reward of their service these titles and honours following. The degree itself because we cannot give them better names, they shall be called Patriotes or patritions, when they are 300 strong and planted abroad then shall they be termed knights patriotes with the title of Sir. When they have attained to be 600 strong, at which number we (intending every planter and servant to be the father of a family) do stent the colonies that they shall not exceed above so many families (or that another colony hath issued out of them) our will and pleasure is that their sons and heirs shall be then knights patriotes and they themselves shall be Barons and termed lord patriotes, their wives and other children taking their honours and places accordingly. In time of peace they shall be and have the authority of our Lieutenants of shires in England, to appoint the commanders of our men at arms, see them trained, to look to their arms and watches. In time of war they shall be charged with what number of men the council of state shall think fit.

And whereas the patriots are the principal ringleaders and greatest adventurers, which carry and draw with them their friends, kindred, followers and adherence out of their natural country to a place so far remote, to be protected governed and cherished by them, We do therefore will and command all our said patriots, lovingly carefully and cheerfully to perform this their trust. And we do ordain that after admonition for being churlish and negligent in that kind, they shall be noted with a note of ignominy, if they shall not endeavor the helping and protecting any of their foresaid adherence, by all lawful means they may, and this we charge as well all our presidents councils and marshalls to look carefully unto, the rather to draw the Indians to the like dependency. And we do further ordain that from the time that the patriot shall be planted abroad, his estate of inheritance in England, together with his honors titles and inheritance in Virginia, shall be so united and made one to him and his heirs that he shall not sell the one without the other, and that sale to be made by the consent of our council of union in Virginia and our Virginia council in England, or the most part of their meeting at their general courts and not otherwise. And if it happen that the patriot do die leaving no heir male of his name then shall it go to the female and their heirs. And the eldest daughter of the
2506:
A424 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

patrition, and the heires that shall challenge by the female side and their children shall beare the patriotes sirname, if they will inherite the sayde honoures and landes, which if they shall refuze that then the nexte of the kinde either by the father and then of the mothers side, takeing the patriotes adopted sirname shall enjoye the sayde inheritance. And because wee knowe howe dangerous it will bee to the state to suffer thease greate honoures and inheritances, to bee conjoyned either by combinations, leagues, and marriages, whereby some one familie may growe monsterous in the state, therefore wee doe establish and ordayne that noe person inhabiting or inhabiteing within any of our provinces within the degrees aforesayde shall make any leagues, combynacions or contractes either by worde or writing, or confirmeing them by oaths, offensive or defensive, to the mainetenaunce of any faction whatsoever, uppon payne of forfeiteing their goodes and lives as fellons, and to prevente the combining and conjoyneing of thease honoures in one house by marriage wee doe further ordayne that such eldest daughter or heire female as shall marrie with any patriott, or the heire of a patriott, shall disinable herselfe from inheriteing her fathers or predecessours patriotshippe thereby, except shee marryeing of a husband soe enamored with her that he shall sell or give away his owne patriotshippe and soe shall take the sirname of his wifes auncester, he may by that meanes inable himselfe to inherite her honoures and estate and soe by marryeing the inheritrix of the patriot, hee will bee accompted a kinde husband, and that will be his portion. The principal intent of frameing this lawe being that noe one subject shall either by purchase or any other meanes unite the forces, theareby to inable himselfe to bee stronger then any of his order. But to the end that love may bee mayntayned, and that theise degrees may not estrange the upper orders from the lower, wee wish that the heires and eldest sonnes of the upper orders may marrie with the daughters of the lower orders, soe to rayse their wives fortunes. And that the daughteres of the upper orders being heires may marrye with the sonnes of the lower orders, makeing choice of the most vertuous, soe as vertue may advance both men and woemen to marriages, and that all degrees may bee thereby bound togeather in the bonde of love that none may be scorned but the scorner.
2507:
BEFORE DECEMBER 7, 1623

To this end alsoe, although wee would not have you imitate the Irish in their wilde and barbarous maners, yet wee will commend one custome of theirs unto you, which is that the poorer sorte sueing to gett the nurseing of the children of the lordes and gentrie, and breedeing upp in their minoritie as their owne, this breedeing, together with their custome, doth begett another nature in them to love their foster children and brethren, as if they were naturally bred of the same parentes, and they are accompted most vile and base that shall neglect any good oportunitie to shew their thankefulnesse and love thus begotten and bred betweene the riche and poore. And because wee will give all furtherance of the spreadeing of these newe collonies wee doe therefore ordayne and appoynte that all such servauntes that shall be carried at the charge of any adventurer or planter, both those servauntes that are soe carryed over and their servauntes, with their servauntes servauntes, shall bee tyed to plante in consorteshippe with their first masters, and shall rise and remove with them to plant a newe colonie when their foresayde masters shall bee enabled by our forme thereunto, which shall bee after hee hath gayned an estate in England and is able to drawe over or carrie with him 300 men, leaveing the collonie hee was first planted in 300 strong or upwardes. The next magistracie is the governour, him wee ordayne after the death of the first patriott to bee annuall by election, but during the life of the first patriott hee shall bee governour and afterwardes his heires shall bee honoured as head of that order but shall not governe unlesse hee bee thereunto chosen. The governours charge shall bee to see the lawes, decrees and orders aswell in the publique governement of the colonie as in the private families observed. hee shall controlle all men for breach of manners and discipline, first giveing them private admonition and afterwardes publique if they persevere in their misdemeanour. Hee together with the maior, the shreife, the churchwarden, and one commoner chosen by the rest of the commoners, the governour haveing the casting voice, they shall have power to indite for breach of lawes, and to suspend from degrees for breach of manners accordeing as in their discretion shall be thought meete.

The next order that wee ordayne is the maior and aldermen, togeather with the shreife, all which 3 orders in matters of triall of life and death, wee ordayne that they shall bee tryed either by the councell of state or the provinciall councell, the jurie that tryeth them being to bee of their owne ranke and order, and in case where there are not soe many to bee founde, they shall bee supplied out of the order and ranke next beneath them. And wee doe give as well to our provinciall councell as to this degree and order the jurisdiction over all persons and degrees under their order, they haveing some one learned in the law to direct them. And wee doe ordayne that both our sayde severall councells and the sayde maiour and aldermen, shall have full power and authoritie in theire jurisdictions to heare and determine as well all capitoll as criminall causes, which in the precinctes of their severall colonies or corporacions in manner and forme followeing (that is to saye) by twelve honest and indifferent persons, as neere as canne bee of the plaintifes and defendantes rankes and orders, then the sayde juries to bee chosen indifferently out of both their orders, which juries are to be returned by the marshalls, for the provinciall councell, and by the shreifes for trialls in corporations, thease jurours being sworne uppon the evangelist shall accordeing to their evidence to bee given unto them uppon oath, and accordeing to the trueth in their consciences either convicte or acquitte the persons accused and tryed by them, or shall trie causes for matter of right, betwene the plaintife and defendaunt, guided by their consciences and by evidence one oath delivered to them, wee giveing authoritie to the provinciall councell and to the maiour and aldermen, in either of their jurisdictions respectively to repreeve and put off execution of any one adjudged to dye, but wee will graunte noe power to pardon death, to any but to our greate Councell of State. Furthermore for the ordering of our under orders in thease our corporations wee doe ordayne that everie alderman shall have his severall warde devided to them accordeing as their number of citiezens encrease, and everie one must have a common councellor under him as a deputie whoe must appoynte under them everie tenne men a taskemaster chosen out of the commoners, or of the best labourers, thease must worke in the head of their file, and giveing them good example must direct and oversee them.
2509: BEFORE DECEMBER 7, 1623 427 And the taskemasters and common councellers must weekely relate to the governoures, whoe loytereth and whoe taketh paynes, and they must be rewarded or punished accordingly. These taskemasters and common councellers in their wardes, must alsoe take care of all sicke persons, and they must complaine of masters that abuse their servauntes, in suffering them to want either foode or apparrell. All these thinges must bee certified to the governour and hee must see it amended, for they and the whole colonie as a bodie politicke, must make good to the state there and heare all the covenauntes that the patriot, the governour, aldermen, one common counceller or one commoner or 3 of them of the sayde colonic of which the patriot or governour must bee one, shall undergoe to any adventurer that sendeth servauntes thither, or any trades men that shall trust them with wares, for such colonies as are raised there, they shall give warrant under the scale of the colonye, before 5 of their councell there. And the councell there sendeing their letters of credence to the counccll heare, they shall hinde the colonie whome the letters coneerne to performe all covenauntes that they shall undergoe. These covenauntes must bee acknowledged and sealed heare before the Treasurer and his deputie and foure councellers, and then they must stand as a statute to binde and make lyable all the goodes and persons of any personall adventurers in the sayde colonies, the arest of them or their goodes to bee made either heare or theare. The like shall bee done for all colonies that shall bee raised heare, certificate being made by the councell heare, of their warrauntes acknowledged in courte, and this shall binde all their goodes and persons theare to bee aunsweareable to any seasure that shall be made for not performeing the covenauntes signed and sealed as aforesayde. This assureance as well of their owne goodes they adventure as all the goodes of that colonie wherein they adventure, will give such satisfaction to adventurers, that shall either have sonnes, brothers, or kindred that they meane to doe good too, that they shall neede onely to lend them their adventurers for, 5, 6, or 7 yeares, as the colonie and they canne agree, and then they may have their moneys repayed. Moreover because where the busienesse of the commonwealth is left to manye, there everie one putting it off nothing is donne, therefore our Councell in England nominateing 9 persons (whome they shall thinke meete) to us, wee will make choice of 3 of those 9 to bee principal magis-
2510:
428 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

trates planting them in each province one, which shall have power to see each magistrate, councellor, patriot, and governour to execute their office, to see the lawes and orders observed, and to execute the decrees of our councells as our shreifes doe in England. And these being capable of the generall command of the forces throughout their severall provinces when the Councell of State shall put the sword in their hands, they must only have power to censure, indict, and suspend, but he must have no jurisdiction. These 3 magistrates having so good allowances as the plantation will afford them, they shall settle their estates in England and have no estates in Virginia, every one having certain men allowed them for their guard by the colony, and holding their places for a time limited by us and our Councell in England and removing them from province to province as we shall think meet. These we appoint to be our marshall governour, and are to take their directions, both of taking up and laying down the sword according to their commissions by the councell of state in Virginia granted and giving an account of their actions to the said councell, at their coming out of the field.

Furthermore, we considering that this great power given amongst our magistrates, councells, and governours may (as we have formerly shewed in the lawe provided against the abuses of the said soveraigne power) prove to be the undoing of our obedient subjects that are to live under it and be commanded by it, and so may turn to the ruin of the commonwealth. Therefore it concerning the whole body politick as well as every particular member, that it may be the better looked unto, and the more severely punished, we do ordain a Syndex or magistracie, framed out of the 5 orders or degrees, 3 a piece out of every order, that shall so often as the generall parliament meets have power to enquire, examine, try, and adjudge (as need shall require) all the great councellors either of the state or of the provinces, the patriots, the governours, or any other that shall have the administration of justice within any of our said provinces or colonies. And whichsoever of them shall be found guilty of oppression or the encroaching farther upon our soveraigne power than to him or them or [is] limited by these our orders, or warranted by our councell of state, they shall have power to punish them according to the lawes, either with loss of life, goods, or banishment. The goods of which offenders, we will bestow on the publique, who having
2511:
BEFORE DECEMBER 7, 1628

A429 caught the wolves and stripped them shall have the fell for their paynes. Noe sentence must passe in this magistracie under 10 voices, none of death under 13. This magistracie must continue dureing the time of the Parlament. Everie counceller or magistrate that shall bee questioned by this magistracie, must stand 8 dayes subject to this inquisition and triall, in which time it shall bee lawfull for any man to accuse him, and afterwardes being acquitted he shall have a certificate under the handes of these magistrates, certifying his integritie in his place, which may remaine by him as a marke of honour to him and his posteritie. To choose this magistracie, there must bee a provinciall parlament called, one out of each order of the 5 orders in everie corporation, which being mette and the orders sorted and severed by themselves, they must write everie one his name to whome they give their voices, and then the partie out of everie order which hath the most voices must stand as choosen for this magistracie. These magistrates shall bee called the Protectoures of the commonwealth dureing the time of their magistracie. To the purpose therefore that wee may forthwith have these our orders lawes and forme of governement, put in execution, wee doe first charge and ordayne that all our councellers in Virginea shall perswade and prepare first and especially the ould planters and all other adventurers that are planted there and have servauntes, to devide themselves into consorteshipps of 30 or 50 to bee principall men in these our particular collonies, and that they planteing themselves as neere one to the other as may bee, will prepare houses for certayne other planters or servauntes that shall be sent to them, of whome they shall take charge, they being payed as well for those their houses as for their undertakeing the charge of servauntes, by them that shall enter or adventure into consorteshippe with them. And that such our councellers, as have estates in England or Ireland and such other of the planters as canne procure 300 men to joyne with them, to bee suretyes one for each other that within 7 yeares they shall purchase estates in England, to such a value as shall bee thought meete. These shall be allowed to bee patriotes. And wee doe farther will and charge our councell in England that they give furtherance to all such as shall bee soe consorted, to supplie them with planters that haveing estate heare may bee either patriotes or of the order.
2512:
430 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

of governoures. And to cause adventurers that will onely send servauntes thither to joyne with those ould planters, giveing them reward for their paynes, and for such hundredes as are now planted onely with tenauntes or servauntes, to cause the ould planters that are freehoulders to joyne and plante with them, and likewise to send to them patriotes and governoures that have estates in England, to plante amongst them, that the ould planters may both helpe to instruct them and keepe them to their laboures. And the colonie may bee aunsweareable, both to the state for their allegeance and to the adventurers for their adventures and that they will not graunt any farther patentes heareafter to any other but such as shall bee enabled by this our forme to take them. And in regard that our planters in Virginea may bee the better furthered by the companye in England wee doe ordayne that everie collonie after it is 300 strong shall appoynte 3 deputies of their principall adventurers whome they best trust, resideing in or about London or Plimouth, whereof one of them being nominated to bee the principall shall bee authorrized to bee present at all consultations with the councell of Virginea and New England, to consulte uppon the election of officers belongeing to the courtes there, and about contractes with the King or companie about auditeing the accomptes. The whole order and classis of thease men, being tearmed the preconsulters, shall have a negative voice to staye and hinder all thinges that shall bee prejudiciall to the planters in Virginea giveing in their names, their consentes or their denialls for the matter questioned in writeing, the other two deputies shall bee as agentes and factors to buy and sell the goodes transported and returned to and from Virginea. And wee doe further charge our councell in Virginea, that in the interim whilst thease thinges are doeing, they will send out certayne flatt bottomed vessells to discover to the southward where the best places (most especially for health) are to plant one [on], and that they will likewise prepare long and large vessels flatt bottomed, like those they tearme flutes in the Low Countries, that in transporteing our men they may laye drye in them till their houses are made or built. For the seating and ordering thease severall plantacions because they require a good judgement uppon the veiue of the place (there haveing
2513: BEFORE DECEMBER 7, 1623 431 beene either none or verie slight discoveries in that kinde), wee must leave it to the wisedome and judgement of you our councell in Virginea, but wee knowing the manye inconveniences that doe heape themselves together both uppon the plantacion and the governement in our planteing in grosse, which noething but a potent domesticke enimye should enforce us to, And considering that the naturalls of the cuntrie are soe weake, that the strength and largenesse of the cuntrie is soe greate, soe as by the fortifieing of the mouthes of the rivers and keepeing the center and middle province of the plantacion strong, And knowing that the devideing of our forces in soe strong a cuntrie will bee a principall meanes not onely to increase the strength of them by our retireing fightes from one collonie to the other, tireing, debillitateing and anoying an assaileing enimie and draweing them to all places of disadvantage, but alsoe to bee a special helpe to the attayneing of all other our desired endes, Wee doe ordayne therefore 3 provinces, a southerne, a middle, and a northerne province, planteing our collonies in them, according as wee shall finde the rivers to lye, planteing not above 2 collonies vpon one river, One at the falls to make bridges to coste the cuntrye, and another not farre of from the mouthes of the sayde rivers, and they being noe farther of [of] in distance vie from the other but that they may second one the other in 3 or 4 dayes by land, which manner of planteing and seateing them, will not onely bee and [an] impulsive cause enforceing by necessitie the continuance of the governement by us now ordayned, but alsoe and [an] especiall meanes of gayneing healthie places to plant one [on], a meanes to enlarge our dominions, a meanes to encrease our navie, a meanes to discover the comodities of the cuntrie, a meanes to make tame and civill the Indyans, a meanes to make our commaunders the better agree, a meanes to keepe our collonies from generall mutinies and oppresseing each other, a meanes to keepe them from makeing leagues and aydeing each other agaynst the soveraigne councell, a meanes to ballance one province and collonie by the other, a meanes to make them joyne against anyone that shall rebell against the generall governement, and finally a meanes to make the patriotes greute within their owne collonies and wastes adjoyneing to them, thus planteing them and equalling them in number, seateing, ordering, and fortifieing them, our religion, discipline, governement, ecclesiasticall and civil, the ordering of our families, and the tying of the naturall Virgineans all to coheare according to our forme, everie thing will bee soe united and made one in LOST 25. 29
2514:
432 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

dependencie, as the essence and being of it shall naturally depend on our soveraignetye. Now because we will shewe you that the duties of commaundeing and obeyeing are mutuall, having hitherto endeavoured to winne you to a loveing obedience of these our lawes and orders set downe in this forme, as we intend wholly for your good and advantage, we by waye of retributeing our love for your obedience doe promise that hereafter if you shall either finde out there growing, or plante there any commoditie that shall be of necessarie use in any of our dominions, that then payeing us our customes and impostes, and being able fullye to supplie us with the sayde commodities, you shall have only the bringeing them in. And because we knowe that this spreadeing and growing quallitie doth necessarily require a publique growing stocke, in performance of this our promise, we doe give unto such as shall desire to plant estates in England, the sole importation of tobaccoe, that you may plant estates as well in England as in Virginia, we doe enjoyne you that if by restrayneing it that it come not too fast into England, and by keepeing it in banke heare, it shall prove worth 4 or 5 pounds, yee shall be payde halfe of it in Virginia in commodities and servauntes at easie and reasonable rates, and the other halfe shall remaine in banke in England, in good handes (you receaveing 6 in the hundredth) to imploye as you shall thinke meete, The surplusage proffite above 4 or 5 being imployed as a treasurie for the publique. We will order that there shall be servauntes and cattle equally sent to the colonies, the benifitte of whome they shall have the 4th parte of it for takeing the charge of them. And because we doe knowe that a sett and frugall habite is the best meanes to advance a growing commonwealth to the one that yee may banish superfluitie and that every degree may be knowne by their habites, we doe charge and commaund you to set downe amongst yourselves certayne frugall and inchangeable fashions, for each degree to weare, giveing to the ould planters some neate of honour to distinguish them from others. And that this may be the better donne, we doe ordayne, that there shall be a megasine for the publique, the stocke whereof shall be raised
2515: BEFORE DECEMBER 7, 1623 433 out of the ould debtes and the fines of such as have abused the governement, which stocke shall still bee upheald and increased as the plantacion increaseth aswell by the benifitte of retourne of commodities, as by one 4. parte of the publique servauntes labours, by and [an] increase of the 4th parte of the cattell, and by a rent to bee reserved out of the landes where the publique servauntes shall bee planted, when they are once made free tenauntes. We haveing thus not provided you a meanes to plant estates in England but put you into the waye how it shall bee donne, our busienesse will bee soe to order the seating, fortieficing and the manner of the spreadeing of your collonies, that it maye bee for your healthes, and strengthening of you, soe onely, as you may not strengthen yourselves against our publique state. And because soveraigne seates are onely to bee used where the person of the soveraigne hath his continuall abydeing, therefore wee doe ordayne that no colonie shall bee planted on the mouth of any navigable river, where the channels maye be commaunded or shall take any soveraigne seate naturally strong to commaund both sea and land, but shall leave the mouthes of all the riveres to bee fortiefied in that manner the state shall thinke fitt, onely with small fortes bastions or bullworkes that maye contayne 20 or 30 men a peece, to handle their ordinaunce to beate and commaund the channells. But because prepotencie is the principall thing that you must all take heede of, dwarfes and gyantes never agreeing well togeather in one familie, ranke or order, wee will leave this to your cares whome it doth most especially concerne to looke unto it, willeing and commaundeing you that noe peece of grounde within the degrees before limited, shall bee taken and fortiefied, by any our subjectes the planters theare, but first a commission shall bee directed to certayne surveyoures some of which shall bee well experienced in fortifiecation, a record being kept of the names of the commissioners, togeather with the condition of the place, the quallitie, quantitie and manner of the fortifiecation by them allowed to bee made, that not onely thease commissioners if they shall connive and suffer such fortes and places of advauntage to bee taken and fortiefied may receave condigne punishment therefore, but alsoe it may make all such planters as shall fortiefie contrarie to the alloweance of the state to bee unexcuseable, which offence according to our lawes of England, wee doe ordayne that it shall bee fellonie.
2516:
434 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

Now for the manner of the fortification that they may bee all equall, wee will and commaund that there shall bee one sett forme for all, and that citties bee fortified with bricke and stone walls only, not of any greate thickenesse, but battalemented on the toppe, flanked without and terrased within more for comelynesse than strength, planting them either upon easie and accessible assentes, or else on levell groundes, by small rivers as farre from marshes and ill aires as may bee, not suffering any to fortifie within gunneshott of the banke of any greate navigable river, neither one collonie to plant on both sides thereof that they may not annoye either those that plant above them, or such their neighbour colonies as shall abutte against them, but wee would have them plant on such small riveres as are fordeable, and where bridges may bee made to passe them, there they shall plant on both sides, if the riveres bee not the boundes betwixt two colonies, in which cases none of the sayde colonies shall plant within gunne shotte of them, the fishing being common to both. On these riveres if wee shall plant our townes in the middest, our wastes and commons next and our countrie villages last, making them soe strong as they maye bee sufficient defences against the Indyans, and the placeing those villages in an orderlye distance one from the other, everye planter that is but of 2 or 3 yeares standing will knowe his station, the manner of the fortification and building as well as the Romans knew their campe. But for the manner of spreading and dividing our colonies, wee will take example by King Alfridde whoe first divided England into several shires or sections and appoynted over every sheire an earle to commaunde his forces there, which shires hee alsoe divided into lesser partes whereof some bee called Lothia [lethes?] of the Saxon worde, which signifieth to assemble, others he termed hundreds, because those that commaund over them, had jurisdiction over a hundred pledges, others he termed tythings, soe named because there was in each of them ten persons, wherein each one was suretye and pledge for the others good bearing, and whatsoever hee was that was not of credite to bee received into one of these tythings hee was either subject to the marshall law, or else committed to prison and there made worke like an idle droane. If this course bee now taken in Virginia and that the Indyane within the wastes adjoyning to the colonies, were by your gentle usage drawne into these polliticke orders, whereby each colony should have...
2517:
EARLY DECEMBER, 1623

their propper Indyans beelongeing to them, whoe seeth not what greate benifitte would arise to the plantacion theareby.

CDXVIII. Captaine John Bargrave, Copy of A Letter To The Lord Treasurer Middlesex

Harty December, 1623

Manchester Papers No. 402. Additional MSS. 12496, fo. 454 (Caesar Papers) Document in Public Record Office, London; also in British Museum List of Records No. 604

Right hoᵇˡᵉ after 10 yeares service in the warres in the summer time, and at my study in the wynter, whereby in some measure I informed my Judgment in publiqu[e] buisinesse, and 7 yeares since now latelie spent in observing the abuses of the Virginia Company, and studdying the meanes to rectifie them, being forced and necessitated to be an earnest follower, and studdyer of the same by losse of my Estate, I may now Claime to my-selfe the right of being Maister in that art, Challenging all others that shall oppose what I write, and makeing it good that it is impossible for any one (that shall newly enter into the buisinesse) to be able to setle this Plantation. I will take this proposition for the ground of my maister-peece, and proue by right reason (wᵗʰ Plato saith is the ground of pollicie) That honors, liberties, and freedomes, togeather wᵗʰ returne of profit, ordered to the Working of our pollitique End, would plant Virginia, and worke those effects wee all aimed at.

From this ground I raise these 6 heads:

1. First I vndertake to show the meanes to draw a sufficient Nomber of men that haue good Estates here, to plant in Virginia, wᵗʰ their persons & goods, and to Cause the planters in Virginia to plant Estates in England.

This copy is in Sir Nathaniel Rich’s hand. It reads in some minor points as though he had misread the original. It has been compared with Additional MSS. 12496, fo. 454, and differs in some important particulars. The document in the British Museum is addressed to the Lords the Council instead of to the Lord Treasurer. Differences are indicated in the footnotes following. Still a third text, addressed to the Lord Treasurer, is No. 6157 of the manuscripts of Lord Sackville preserved at Knole Park, Kent, and printed, under the heading, ‘Captain John Bargrave’s Proposals’, in the American Historical Review, XXVII, pp. 411-514. It seems to be a later version than the one here printed (running to ‘seventhly’ in the early paragraphs instead of ‘sixthly’), yet is endorsed by the Lord Treasurer’s secretary as received December 7.

These entire paragraphs preceding are omitted in Additional MSS. 12496.
2518:
436 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

2. Secondly so to seaver and divide the faculties of soueraintie, and the Command of the forces amongst those men so estated that they shall never meete vnited in power, but to advance our politique end of holding the Plantation of Virginia to England.

3. Thirdly by making vse of the naturall strength, and largeness of the place, so to marshall those men, as they shall not onely make the Plantation to spread, and growe, to find out the best Commodities, and inlarge the King's Dominions, but they shall secure it both from forraine Enemies, and enable it to give lawes to the Domesticke Indians.

4. Fourthly, the employing of those men there to make the best & suddenest returnes hither.

5. Fifthly the managing and ordering those returnes so, as they shall not only supply and maintain the Plantation with apparrell and necessaries but it shall make a publique stocke and Treasurie, that should increase as the Plantation increaseth.

6. Sixthly and Lastly the doing of all these things by way of right and Interest to the maintenance of Justice, and peace, and to the Honor of God, our King, and State.

All these qualities being treated of in five severall Treatises are lastly Composed into one forme which may aptly be termed militarie Intendencie by Tribe, it being a way not only to plant Garrisons without pay, but each Garrison bringing with it a Certaine Revenue to the Crowne, it shall tie Virginia as fast to England as if it were one Terra firma with it.

The hint of it I had from Charles the 5, and if he himselfe or King Philip his sonne, had used the like policie in the West Indyes, low Countries, Millane, Naples, and the rest of his provinces to Maintain his Soveraigntye there, he had not spent so many [2] Millions to keepe Garrisons as he hath done, neither would his provinces be so readie to fall from him as now they wilbe if his plate fleet should faile him.

When I shall see the Companie incouraged, and the Comission goe forward, so as the delinquents being knowne to their King from honest men, a stocke may be gayned out of th’ abuses of the Government, and that this forme be setled, I doubt not but to procure 8 or 10 Gentlemen that
2519:
EARLY DECEMBER, 1623

A437 shall haue 7 or 8000 li p An̄i revenew to goe as Comissioners into Virginia, to setle it, and to be the heads of the first Colloneyes; and all they shall demand of his Maᵗᵉ is, that he will grant them the wardshipp of their heyres if they shall dye in their service now at their first going. And if his Maᵗᵉ will but grant me releife out of the Imployment of the said stocke, I will vndertake on payne of my life, that what is wanting to performe the buisines, the Planter shall supplie, and when this is done I may glory in the worke and brage that I haue helped the state to meanes, shewed them the way and helped them with Instrumente to Conquer and keepe in subiection to England a State that may grow to be as great an Empire as the King of Spaynes, the distance of place no way hindering it, to the honoᵘʳ and inriching of our King and State & to the releife of Thousands of poore people. I euer said and so exprest my selfe in my Articles two yeares since at the Councell boord, that if the buisnes with the Company were not tenderlie handled, that till this publique stocke was gayned, and this forme were framed, and setled by the Company, we should beginne at the wrong end, and it would hinder the worke; this takeing away of the Patent being a device of the delinquents (like some other they haue formerlie vsed) hath so madded the Company, that whereas there is 80 Articles put in against the former Gouᵉʳnors, 15 of them being against the Accompte, and but 3 examined they let all goe now at sixe and seauen, and will medle no further; and that there Cannot be a more pleasing thing to the delinquents any one may see it by some of their earnest following it. For my part I neuer durst seeke to take away the populer Government here, partlie because the deliverie vp of Patents doth weaken the Confidence that Patentees should haue in them, and the Patent now granted being to the Company, Consisting of the Adventurer, and Planter, and the Gouᵉʳnment being now in the Company here, if the Company will by Consenting to this Forme, transferre the Gouᵉʳnment to the Planter (to whom of right it belonges) there is no necessitie that the Patent must be delivered, partlie because there must by necessitie be such Correspondencie betweene the Planter in

2520:
438 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

Virginia, and the Adventurer here, that the Planter must make noe lawes to bind the Estates of the Adventurer, but he must Consent to it either by himselfe, or some other; for otherwise no man will adventure. Partly because the Consent of all the Parties interested to the forme will make it the more firme, and perpetuall, partlie because all Changes of Gouernment should be insensible, gentle, & [3] easie. Partlie because this Consent by voices doth make many adventure that otherwise would not, Partly because I made a doubt whether the King would take the name of the Plantation as a worke of his owne till he saw it was able to subsist and defend it selfe against forreyne and domesticke power. Partly because vnder the name of the publique (wᵗʰ is the King in right of his Soueraintie) all the benifit of the publique lands & seruants will returne vnto him though he be no more seene in the busines then formᵉrly he hath beene. Lastlie the plantation being divided into petty Collonyes of 300 in each one, if those Collonies shall nominate 8 Adventurers here, two of them to be their Agents to doe their busines, as the Comittees doe now, and the third to preconsult and make Contracts for the Planter wᵗʰ the King or Company, the whole Classis of those preconsulters haueing a Negatiue voice; theis will preuent all wrong done to the Plantation, and there will nothing remayne but the very name of the Company.

The Company feares that this takeing away the Patent before the abuses were examined was hatched at Alderman Johnsons house at Bowe, at the Kings being there, that the King is now prest to it by Sr Thomas Smithes Freinds of the Bed Chamber, and all is done to Conceale the falshood of his Accompts, and the grossenes of their Gouernment from his Mat knowl- edge. They feare likewise that Sr Tho: Smith, Sr Samuell Argoll, and Alderman Johnson standing Cleare in the Kings Eyes, and the Gouernment being framed, That they may doe wᵗʰ the Planter and Adventurer what they list, all their privildges and right being taken from them they wilbe made their Gouernors who haue beene the principall abusers of them, and this that side bragge of. Some of the Com's also answearing Peti- tioners that it is to no purpose for them to medle any further, being the King hath declared himselfe to take away the Government from the

[MARGINAL NOTE: 1Jn Additional MSS, 12496, instead of the lengthy statement from this point, Captain Bargrave prays that the Company be commanded to make good their complaints before the Commissioners and that a committee be appointed to examine and amend the form of government.]
2521:
EARLY DECEMBER, 1623

Company, and to put it into the hands of twelve Councellors, that may right their causes. The way to right all will be the setting forward of the Commission, the forcing the Company to make good their Complaints, the nominating a Committee from the board, or otherwise to examine, and approve of the form of Government that shall be tendered to the Company, and when they shall see that Justice is done, this stock is like to be gained, and that this form of Government which the King and State doth press on them is no such Bugbear as they need to be afraid of, but framed according to right, tending to the good of all parties interested, for the Companies ease, and to take away the blame from them, If any thing miscarry for want of Government, the order of the form placing the same men in the Government which they themselves would choose if the Government should remain in their hands and they being by the said form to have their adventures secured to them by the whole Colonies, wherein they shall adventure, and that this is all the hurt that is intended to them; I make no doubt but the States and the Companies End meeting in one and the same thing, they will embrace it, and the business will go well forward. I know (my good Lord) that in Cases of necessity all states & statesmen, instead of following straight ways to Compass their end are forced to follow more oblique and Crooked, the greatness of the future good recompenseth the present ill. So Lycurgus although his policy was Aristocraticall, so just, as for it he was (of the Oracle) termed beloved of the Gods, yet notwithstanding he being necessitated to set up his Government by Conspiracy, and force he was likewise Compelled to Choose all his first Council out of the Conspirators; by this rule of necessity Romulus (as Livie saith imitating other founders of Common Wealths) to draw people to his new built City, erected an Asylum, or Sanctuary for Outlaws, men indebted, and discontented persons. Junius Brutus likewise in the desperate Case of the City of Rome, after the battle of Cannae was forced for want of men to set at liberty all the prisoners indebted, and to discharge their debts on Condition, that they would serve the State; although in these Examples we in our necessity may entreat Connivance, and help for some industrious Gentlemen indebted; and decaying in their Estate, by whose industry the States turn may be served, and their falling houses relieved. This policy no question is
2522:
440 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

tolerable and fitt, but that theis delinquents seeing their leaudnes like to be discovered, should meet the storme in the ferce, and to avoid the obloquie of their offences should be suffred to Compound vnder hand, and vnder a Colo of their loue to the Plantation, and a desire to see the mannageing of it, by Concealing their Wronge done, should thrust all the disgrace from themselues vpon others, it being a most sure rule that nothing makes a State more florish then a due administration of rewards and punishments, this must needs be by the rule of state intollerable, and the more intollerable because the State at this tyme both here and in Virginia, longs for examples in this kind, The limitation of the soueraigne faculties amongst the Councell, and Magistrates in Virginia, wholy Consisting in the severe punishment of all incroachment vpon soueraigne power, further then the forme giveth leaue, they therefore that shall robb the Comonwealth of this example shall robb it of its very life! Whereas therefore the foresaid Delinquents takeing advantage on his Mat’ Declaration against such as did not make good the Complainte, that they shall suffer the same punishment (that the Delinquents should) if their Complainte prove not true, did thereupon by the Kings direction Cause the Complaints in the name of the Company to Cease, because such punishment Could not be inflicted vpon the Companie as might vpon private persons, whereby they did for a long time hinder the proceeding of the buisines before the Com’s, till such time as the boord did order it, that against such Delinquents as were Instruments of the Company they might Complaine (it being but a device like this of takeing away the Patent) to hinder the proceedings of the Complainants. If therefore his Ma'tie will suffer a bill to be drawne in my name (I makeing choice of the Companies Articles, and proofes that shall be laid in the said bill) and will Continue my protection, and give vnto me the 4th part of what shall be recovered, to recompense my losse; I will vndertake, skinne for skinne, that nothing shall be laid against them but shall be proued. And if the other partie will doe the like against Sr. Edwyn Sandys, or any others of the Companie, the buisines will be by this meanes fully Censured, so praying for your Lo’® increase of honor I rest Your Lor®® to Command JOHN BARGRAVE

CDXXI. Privy Council. A LETTER TO THE GOVERNOR AND COUNCIL IN VIRGINIA

December 19, 1623

(1) Manuscript Records Virginia Company, II, pt. i, p. 70a. (2) C. O. 5, Vol. 1354, p. 210. (3) Privy Council Register, James I, Vol. VI, p. 199. Document in (1) Library of Congress, Washington, D. C.; (2) and (3) Public Record Office, London. List of Records No. 606

After our hartie Comendaéons, Wheras Captaine John Marttin Esquire, being a Planter in Virginia, hath bene Detayned a good space here, by reason of Div™ Controverses, wch haue Risen concerning the Plantac̄on of Virginia, wherin (as wee Conceaue) hee hath behaued himself honestly & Discreetly, ffor as much therfore, as hee is now retourneing backe againe wth some of his Servants, and many others, that would plant & ioyne, wth him, and begine againe to settle himself and them, vppon his Ruinated Plantac̄on, wee haue thought good for his better incouragement, to accompany him wth these our letters vnto you the Gouernor and Counsell their. And althought wee Doubt not, but that you will vse him and his asociatte, as becometh you, and may stand wth yᵉ Advancement of the Plantac̄on yett wee Will expect, that for this our recomendac̄on, Some what more then ordinarie respect, should bee had of him, and Doe require you to take Care (soe much as in you lyeth) that hee and Such as shalbe vnder his Comaund, may bee free from all Danger of oppression, and peaceably inioye all such Lande and goodes as belongeth vnto them, behaving themselues as faithfull
2526:

Subjects ought to Doe Wherefore nothing Doubting, wee bide you hartily farewell from Whithall the xixth of December 1623

Your Loving friends

To our loving friends Sr. Francis Wyatt kt. gouernor and to the rest of the Counsell of Virginia

Governor of Virginia,

A LETTER TO CAPTAIN WILLIAM TUCKER

December 26, 1623

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, II, pt. ii, p. 53a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 607

Capt. Wm. Tucker

Forasmuch as wee are certainly informed that Carter & other of the sailors belonging unto the ship called the True Love have contrary to the proclamation made by the Governor & Counsell, sold the Commodities above the rates of the said proclamation, this particular above other matters being especially committed to our care by the Governor in his absence, Wee earnestly desire you to make enquiry throughout the plantations under your Command, what Commodities or debts, belonging to the said Carter or any of the sailors of the said ship remain in the hands of any manner of person or persons there residing, & to make stay thereof, until such time as you have further order from the Counsell, As also to enquire at what rates such (as have paid for the Commodities) received them taking notice by writing of their names & of the names of such as they bought their said Commodities of. Sending us the writing by the first opportunity. These things wee commit unto your care, hoping that (as a good member of this plantation) you will be ready to perform. And for the performance of the same wee give & grant unto the said Capt. Wm. Tucker full

445, power & authoritie Comaunding all persons residing in the said plantacions to bee ready & willing to giue such information vnto him concerning the Premisses as shalbe required. Your Loueing friends George Yeardley, George Sandis, AR: Dawson, Francis West, Roger Smith. James Citty December the 26th 1623.

CDXXIV. Councill in Virginia. A Commission TO CAPTAIN WILLIAM TUCKER December 31, 1623 Manuscript Records Virginia Company, II, pt. ii, p. 68a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 609(b)

By the Counsell of State in Virginia

Forasmuch as some persons have attempted to depart out of this Country not having their passes, & others having their passes, without discharging their debts & duties in this Country. These are to give full & absolute authority, unto Capt. Wm. Tucker, to go aboard, & view all the ships before they depart hence, & to see every persons pass. And if any person in any of the said ships have not a pass, to cause them to be brought ashore, not suffering them to depart this land. And if he know, that are any way engaged in this country by debts or otherwise, either of his own knowledge or by true report of others, notwithstanding they have their passes, to stay or cause them to be stayed till they shall relieve themselves of such objections as shall be laid against them. Charging & commanding all persons to be aiding & assisting unto the said Capt. Wm. Tucker, or his deputy in the execution of this warrant as they will answer the Contrarie at their uttermost perils.

Given at James Citty December the 31st: 1623 George Sandis, Cur: Davison John Pott

CDXXVI. Governor in Virginia. A Commission to Captain RALPH HAMOR

January 19, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 41a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. List of Records No. 617

To all to whom these presents shall come to be seene, read, or vnderstood &c. greeting. Whereas for diuᵉ considerations especially moveing the Governor and Counsell of State, it was thought fitt, for this present yeare to restraine all perticuler trade for Corne, within the Bay, and to apropriate that trade, only for the publique benefitt of the Colony. Now Know yee that LSᵗ Francis Wyatt Kt Governor and Capᵗ generall of Virginia, out of the certaine knowledge & good opinion wᵗ [we haue] of Capt. Raph Hamor.
2530:
448 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

I, Francis Wyatt Esquire Counsellor of State, for the managing of an employment of such consequence, and which may much conduce to the benefit of the Plantation do by these Presents constitute and appoint the said Capt. Raph Hamor to be Captain and principal Commander of the good Ship the William & John now riding at Anchor in Patomeck River. Giving and granting unto the said Raph Hamor, full power and absolute Command, in all cases, for the managing of the said trading voyage, over all and every person of what nature or quality soever to be employed in the said voyage. And also full power and authority, to trade, in any River, or Rivers within the Bay, either upon pledge, if the Savages shall require it, or otherwise: forbidding notwithstanding the said Raph, to compel by any ways or means any Indians whatsoever to trade more than they shall be willing to trade for; or to offer any violence to any except in his own defence, in case of suspicion of treachery, or open wrong intended to him or any of his Company. For the better managing of which present employment and voyage, I do strictly Command and charge, all and every person in the said voyage to yield all ready obedience, unto the said Raph Hamor, and in all things to follow and execute the Commands of him, as they will answer the contrary at their uttermost peril. Given aboard the William and John in Patomeck River this xix of January. 1623

Francis Wyatt.

A Commission to Capt. Raph Hamor given aboard the William & John for trading &c.

2532:
450 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

CDXXIX. Council in Virginia. A Letter To THE VIRGINIA COMPANY OF LONDON JANUARY 30, 1623/4

(1) Manuscript: Records Virginia Company, II, pt. ii, pp. 7a-8. (2) State Papers, Domestic, James I, Vol. 156, No. 1 Document in (1) Library of Congress, Washington, D. C.; (2) Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 620

Right Honobl &c.

Wee receaved your Letters by the Bonny Besse and the George, wherynto (though divers shipps haue since retorned) wee haue been enforced through the absence of the Gouernor To defer our replie, as also owt of our desire to enforme you of other accidents and proceedings.

Wee haue to our vttermost abilities revenged ourselves vppon the Salvages havinge vppon this river, Cut downe theire Corne in all places wch was planted in great abundance vppon hope of a fraudulent peace, wth intent to provide them selves, for a future warr, and to sustaine theire Confederates, burninge downe the howses they had reedified, and wth the slaughter of many enforeed them to abandone theire plantations, and had soe served the rest, yf in yt tyme of our gretest scarcitie, & noe reliefe to be founde amongste the Enemyes) want of meanes to feede the souldiers had not Constrayned us to desiste.

Notwthstandinge yt Gouernor as soone as our Corne was ripe, sett forwarde to the River of Potomak to settle the trade wth our freends, and to revenge the trecherie of yt Pascoticons and theire assocyates, beinge the greatest people in those ptes of Virginia, Who had cutt of Capt Spillman and mr Pountis his Pynnace, In wch expeditione he putt many to the swoorde, burnt theire [houses, wth a marvelous quantetie of Corne carryed by them into the woodes, as it was nott possible to bringe it to the Sowrce boates.

The maine reasone yt invited the Gouernor into that river, was an agreement made the last yeere by mr Threasurer wth the Patomacks, our ancyent allies, of whome greate numbers were murthered by those nations, not only to asiste us in that revenge, but to accompeny us and bee our guides.
2533:
JANUARY 30, 1623/4

in a warr against the Pomunkeys, wch would haue been very Advantagious vnto us, The vnseasonablenes of the weather havinge longer deteyned him then the necessitie of the Countrey, could consent to, enforced him to leaue off his Chief intention for Ponunka. It is noe smale difficultie and griefe vnto us to maintaine a warr by vnwillinge people, who levinge to feede and cloath their owne families by their owne labours, Crye out of the loss of Tyme against their Comanders, in a warr where nothinge is to be gained, and the Chief tyme of doeinge the enemie most spoyle falling out to their greatest hindrance, of this the Gouernor can speake by experyence, who although at their ernest suite, hee staide till their Cropps were in, In his beinge abroade A fortnight before he sawe the enemie, was petitioned by them all subscribed with their handes, that they might haue leaue to retourne, lest it should proue their vtter vndoinge.

Whereas we are advised by you to obserue rules of Justice wth these barberous and perfidious enemys, wee hold nothinge iniuste, that may tend to their ruine, (except breach of faith) Stratagems were ever allowed against all enemies, but wth these neither fayre Warr nor good quarter is ever to be held, nor is there other hope of their subversion, who ever may informe you to the Contrarie.

Howsoeuer our intended house of entertaynment was not builte, for wth workmen were entertayned, many subscribers beinge slayne in the Massacre, yett there hath beene great addition of buildinge in divers places, wherein hath and may bee entertayned, great number of new Comers, and that wth more convenience in our oppinions, then in publique Guest houses, where many beinge sick togeather, are likely to bringe a generall infection, and finde noe willinge attendance. And heere wee cannott but againe putt you in minde, how the ships are pestered Contrary to your agreement Victualed wth mustie bred the reliques of former Voyages, and stinckinge beere, heretofore soe ernestly Complayned of, in great pte the cause of that mortalitie, wch is imputed alone to the Countrey, the old planter Consideringe the accidentes, livinge as longe heere as in most ptes of Englande. And it would bee wished, that new Comers who are not Consigned to such as are heere well settled, may bringe such provision over wth them, as mault Cyder butter Cheese etc. as may give them Content.
2534:
Page 452

RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

not make too sudden a change in their dyett, though the first charge be more, yet the profit in the end will be the greater. The rest we must commend to the good pleasure of God, who in his time, may through our penitence turne his Judgments into mercy. The scarsitie this forerunning yeere hath been great, and who could expect less, after such a massacre, yet none to our knowledge hath perished through want, many seasoned men going through their labours, beside harde marches, with endured the same common scarsitie. And to advance the future plentie, beside our Proclamations for the setting of abundance of Corne, we have restrained trade to publique uses, that no private man may depend thereon, which formerly many have done. But nothing will more conduce to the plentie of the Colonie, than the offer of giving of 8 li per bushell, which will greatly diminish the planting of Tobacco, and further all other undertakings, a thing generally desired by the Colony.

We have at all times bent our endeavors to the furthering of those staple Commodities, which you have given us in charge, as for the Iron worke, which had long before now arrived at the perfection [if] the workmen had not been cut off, you know it is not in our power with those that remain to reestablish them. For Vines and silke, we conceive no Country more proper, and will endeavor to see them fully prosecuted. Concerning the state of those and the rest, the Treasurer will further inform you, and we beseech you to consider how great an interruption, they must of necessity receive by the employments, we the Troubles of these times have imposed upon us.

We in the name of the whole Colonie do render most humble thanks to his sacred Majesty for his royal care and favor, not only for his gracious intention of restraining the sole importation of Tobacco to these two Colonies, which we know not by what misinformation may have miscarried, it the only present means to enable us to proceed to more real Commodities, and work of greater Consequence tending to the strength and beauty of the Colonie, for what can be expected from poverty, but also for being the author of this supply of meale out of his tender sense of our former scarcity. And we hope notwithstanding the malice of our virulent traducers,
2535:
JANUARY 30, 1623/4

To approue o'selves in our accions not vnworthie the Continuance of his favor. And to the lords of his ma“ Counsell, we beseech you in our names to render our dew retourne of thanks, for their Honorable care, noe less can we retourne to you for your noble performment, and although we had noe cause to doupte the want therof (else had we beene blame worthie not to haue written as ernestly for it as we did for the former supplie) yett it is nevertheless welcome, rather in regarde of Varietie then necessitie. And we must freely profess that the taxe which was laide vppon you, was malitious and vniuste, Consideringe our Valuations of Tobacco (not to say the rates which unconscionable marchants and maryners doe impose vppon our necessities, which heere we esteme at noe more then xviij pence, as by the publique rates of Comodities may appeere, enforced thervnto by the dayly enhaunsinge of their prices, especyally of rotten Wynes which destroy our bodies and empty our purses, wherof Mr. Robert Bennett (we hope without the privitie of his Brother) hath been most Culpable, who in his liefe tyme boasted that the only sale of fower butts of wyne would be Sufficyent to clere the whole Vioage. And for the furtheringe of Mr. Blanys recouery of debts, at the begininge of harvest we made an edict, that noe debt should be paide nor tobacco disbursed till he were satisfied, and we haue from tyme to tyme, not only putt him in minde therof, but given him all possible assistance, neyther doupt we but that by these ships hee will make you a profitable retourne, his accounpts we cannott as yett peruse, in regard of his absence in gatheringe his debts but shall with the first Convenience, we haue donne heerin what we could, for we hope you thinke us too woorthie to spend, yf we had leysure, our tymes in the Troblesome gatheringe of those debts, who are our burdened with greater ymploymente, And for Mr. Powntis accompt for his maides, we are such strangers to his proceeding therin, that we can give you noe account therof, notwithstandinge before his goinge abroade he was remembred of it, and perused these your letters, therfore he cannot be vnmindfull to give you Satisfactione. For the Glass worke, ship wrights, and Compositione with the ffrench men, we refer you to Mr. Threas letters, which though they haue had noe better success, yett was not his care and excedinge charge wantinge, even to the...
2536: 454 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY neglect & great hinderance of his owne particular, For the Blowmery we refer it to our next letters, As for the Petitions, with our best convenience, we will give them dispatch some of them having been deferred for want of Solicyters, but of these you shall have a further account by Mr. Harte. Concerning the disparagements of the plantation, which we understand to proceed only from the corrupt heart of one who but for the respect of the place which he had formerly undeservedly borne, might justly have received exemplary Punishment for his Venery and drunkenness, we need say no more, than that the informer, who it should seem came purposely for a spy, never saw most of those places where he complaineth of finding such wants & devastations, what he gains himself in this, we may give him in the rest, but we will refer his Unmasking of Virginia, to a particular unmasking of him by the general assembly, in as much as Concerns the Country, and by ourselves in the slanders that concern our government. We have done all that lay in our power to procure you a reimbursement for the charges of the fort Undertaken by Capt Each, with other expenses concerning the Abigail, but find a general unwillingness (not to say an opposition) in all almost but ourselves, whereof as yet we cannot but shall after the general assembly which is already summoned, give you an account, however the account of yours mentioned in your letter to be sent, is not come as yet to our hands. Concerning the fort the men were levied throughout the Country, but supplies sundry ways expected having failed, made us unable to feed more mouths than would only suffice to keep the place, together with sickness that fell upon many, who although they stood extraordinarily well to health at the time of the date of our letters (that we be not wrongfully taxed for writing placentia) yet suddenly after fell down in great numbers in many places, and that it be not often repeated, we freely confess that if our men had stood indifferently to health, we were liable to these aspersions, in the failing of many of our undertakings, which our malicious adversaries impute to our neglect, we have with much earnestness importuned Capt Smith's patience to stay upon the place, who hath done as much as could be expected from him, and doubt not but in the general assembly we shall have as willing assistance from those, that have hitherto hung back in perfecting the same with due expedition.
2537:
EARLY IN FEBRUARY, 1623/4

Thus referringe other things to our next letters, which shalbe written after the generall assembly, beseeching God to free both you and us from the malice of our adversaries and to give his blessinge to our endevors and sufferings we humbly take our leaves and remane, Devoted to your service

Fra: Wyatt
Doctor Jo: Potr
FRA: WEST
Carr
Roger Smith
George YARDLEY

CDXXX. William Ganey. Petition to Sir Francis WYATT

Early in February, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 60a

Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. List of Records No. 625

To the right worll Sir Francis Wyatt knight etc.

The Humble Petition of Wm Ganey

[21] Most humblie sheweth, that whereas for the space of these two yeres I have been Employed by Capt. Thomas Nuce late deceased, as well for Newfoundland as for other trading voyages, himselfe allowing your pe-
2538:
456 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

Petitioner six pounds sterling by the month, as by Couenant vnder his hand appeareth. Now so it is that Capt Nuce being for a long tyme verie sicke desired your petitioner to be Contented, and not to call him to any accompt, vntill hee recouerid, And whether hee liued or dyed your petitioner should be fully satisfyed to his Content, but now hee being deceased your petitioner is vnsatisfied. In Consideration whereof & for that there is due to your petitioner from Capt Nuce, as appeareth in & by the bookes of accompts kept betwixt them it doth plainly appeare, The some of 201 pounds of tobacco, & 289 pounds sterling & x/* for wages due to himselfe & the shipps Company, which your petitioner hath paid, to the great hindrance of him & his, Hee most humblie beseecheth your good worships: for to take such order in this so Just a Cause, that your petitioner may be sattisfied what is due vnto him, for that hee is engaged to diuers & like to loose his Credit vnlesse by your worships fauor hee may be releiued, vpon his hopes doth solely depend & hee shall euer pray for temporall felicities in this worlde, & euer lasting ioy in the worlde to Come. Mr. Thresuror gaue him Content by the seruice of six of the tenants.

To the right Wor'll Sir Francis Wyatt knight Gouernor and Captaine generall of Virginia.

The Humble Petition of John Barnett

[22] In all humblenes of Duty sheweth your petitioner, that whereas John Clarke of London Mariner, & late deceased in this Country, was hired by Mr. Daniell Gookin & John Edwing owners of the good shipp Called the Guidence of Bristol as pylott to bring the said shipp into Virginia, which hee well performed as Mr. Kensain Master of the said shipp being then present Can testifie, the said Mr. Gookin & Mr. Edwing agreeing with the said John Clarke to giue fower pounds as by a Coppy of the agrement appeareth, so it is.
2539:
FEBRUARY, 1623/4 457 that there is due to the said Joⁿ Clarke from them for 12 months wages, which cometh to 48 li sterling. And for that the said Joⁿ Clarke hath left a poore widdow behind him in great distresse & misery hauing a great charge of poore children, & nothing to releive them, but this wages due to her late husband, in consideration whereof & for that the said Joⁿ Clarke hath formerly had much losse & hindrance by this country, being carried away in a Spanish Caruell. May it please your good Worships to direct your warrant to Lieutenant Sheapard, who is Mr. Gookins Agent here, to giue satisfaction for the said 48 li pounds & the poore widdow & her children shall euer pray etc. See the Acts of Court the 4°. Febr. 1623. The like granted to the other widdowes of the Marriners of the said shipp here deceased. See 13° Febr. 1623.

CDXXXII. Robert Poole's Petition To Sir Francis Wyatt

February, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 60a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 622

To the right Worⁿ Sir Francis Wyatt knight

The Humble Petition of Robert Poole

[23] In all humbleness of Duty sheweth your poore petitioner, that whereas there is due to him for his publique service for this country the sum of 563 li weight of Tobacco, & 12 barrels of Corne as by one account thereof hereunto annexed doth truly appear, & which should have been paid unto him the last year, now so it is may it please your good Worships, that your poore petitioner is indebted & engaged to divers men for needful & necessary commodities hee bought & received of them, & which are yet unsatisfied, in regard whereof your petitioner is threatened by his creditors to be arrested & troubled which will be to his great discredit & undoing, hee having no other means to give them satisfaction, but with this which is due to him.
2540:
458 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

In tender Consideration whereof hee most humbly beseecheth your good Worships, & the rest of the Counsell of estate, for to Commiserate his present distressed estate, & to take such order for his releefe, that hee may receive the wages due unto him, whereby to give his Creditors honest satisfaction, & hee shall not only be ready to performe his best service ebaies at all tymes for the good of this Country, but shall ever be bound to pray etc.

Given him By the Generall Assembly 500 waight of Tobacco: besides his helpe received by Trading Voyages.
