CDXXXIII. John Harvey. Petition to Sir Francis Wyatt and the Council

March, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 62 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 631

To the right worll Sir Francis Wyatt knight etc. and to the Counsell of Estate

The Complaint and petition of John Harvey Esquier

Whereas at this present whilst your petitioner according to the Commandement of their Lordships is here busied in his Majesty's service, John White one of the master's mates of his ship the Southampton, being abetted by Robert Guyar master of the said ship, hath most perniciously framed a mutiny or division among the ship's Company, & hath been so Impudent, yea insolent, as to deliver into the hands of your said petitioner, (on whose bread he liveth at all) of their names, whose minds he hath seditiously alienated from their duty, for the utter overthrowing of the voyage which your said petitioner, being sole honor & adventurer of the same ship now intendeth, & for the performance whereof hath been a great Charge of four thousand sterling at the least. All which notwithstanding, & that the right Honorable the Lords of his Majesty's Counsell for new England have been pleased by their Commission and Instructions to give in Charge the admiralty of those seas, & also that the said ship is to return hither with her lading of fish to the great relief & safeguard of this plantation, the said White, abetted by Guyar as aforesaid, still persisteth in his mutinous practice, not only to the intolerable Damage of your said petitioner but also to the manifest hurt & disfurnishing of this Country, & to the hindrance of his majesty's service there in New England.

Humbly desireth that in respect of the great damages he hath already sustained & greater he is like to sustain by their means, you would be pleased to deposit the goods, & attach the persons of these two ringleaders of Mutiny, & to employ them in some service of the Colony, till such time as order may come from their Lordships of the privy Counsell of England for their farther Censures.

And your petitioner as well here as in England by his affectionate service shall be always ready to express his thankfulness.
2542:
460 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

CDXXXIV. ROBERT GUYAR AND JOHN WHITE. ANSWER TO THE COMPLAINT AND PETITION OF CAPTAIN JOHN HARVEY MARCH, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 62 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 633

To the Honorable Sr. Francis Wyatt knight etc. and the right Worshipfull the Counsell of state

The answer of Robert Guyar and John White to the Complaint and Petition of Capt. John Harvey Esquier

Whereas it is obiected that Robert Guyar abetted John White to make a muteny or deuision among the shipps Company, it is denied by them both, that any other order was giuen by the one, or receiued by the other then to know of the shipps Company, whoe were willing, & whoe not, to alter the former designes that they were shipped vpon, without any mocion of perswading or diswading them any thing, Intending rather for the good of Captaine Harvey then otherwise, and John White denieth that hee used any perswasions, but only demaunded their opinions.

For Muteny (if any be) Robert Guyar holdeth it to be Comitted against himselfe by Capt. Harvey & his Confederates (hee affirming that whoe so would not runne his Course hee would Cutt his throat, in regard hee knew none of the shipp to haue Comand aboue him, Esteeming himselfe master & Comaunder, As well by a deed vnder the hand of Capt. Harvey (which hee is ready to produce) together with Capt. Larucys affirmation both ashoare & aboard, that hee Came no otherwise then a passenger aboard the shipp, As by a Comission hee had from the Company of Virginia in England, which Capt. Harvey gott from him by intreaty) at the westerne Islandes vnder pretence to shew it the Gouernor there to Certifie whether wee were bound with Comission hee saieth hee hath torne, if in Contempt hee referreth to the Censure of this board.

As for the roll of names alleged to be so Impudenly & insolently deliuered to Capt. Harvey, they doubt but it wilbe a manifestation, that they ment no prejudice, but rather benifitt vnto him, that thereby hee might Consider,
2543:
MARCH, 1623/4

if it were his best Course to vndertake yᵗ Designe, wᵗʰ vnwilling men. Had they knowne before the’ Coming out of this voyage of the Comissions & Instructions fro’ the lords of his Maᵗʸ Counsell for New England vnto Capt Haruey, Doubtlesse they would haue either willingly haue submitted themselues thervnto, or haue Craued liberty not to proceed in the voyage. And now Considering yᵗ not only Robert Guyar & John White, but also the rest of the shipps Company at the first vndertooke, & were hired to Come first hither, hence to Canada, fro’ thence either to Portucall, Biscay or France & so home againe, they humble desier to proceed in ther first intentions, otherwise that by the authority of this board, Captaine Haruey may be Caused to putt in suffyent suerties to discharge what Robert Guyar is engaged for him, & to discharge & pay what is otherwise Due vnto him & the Shipps Company, And that Robert Guyar & John White may be remitted fro’ further Employment wᵗʰ the shipp, not presuming wᵗʰ Capᵗ Haruey to prescribe to yoᵘ Honor & woʳps what punishment should be Inflicted vpon him, for what (vnder Correction) wee Deeme little lesse then Double Dealing & slander, Subscribed

RoBERT GuYaR JoHN WHITE

CDXXXV. Joon Harvey. Seconp CoMPLAINT AND PETITION Marca, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 62a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 632

To the right Worᵖˡ Sʳ Francis Wyatt knight etc. and to the Counsell of Estate, the second Complaint and peticion of John Haruey esqʳ.

[33.] Sheweth not wᵗstanding yoᵘ pétioners Commission for the Admi- rallty of New England was yesterday twice publiquly read at this Counsell board in the heareing of Robert Guyar & John White the p'tended mʳ & masters mate of the southampton, & therby yoᵘ petitioner was Certainly knowne by all that were then present to be appointed & authorised fro’ ther Loʳps of that Counsell in England, to goe Admirall in & aboard the
2544:
462 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

said shipp for New England, & notwithstanding yoⁿ yesterdays order, that the said Guyar & White should haue no Conference with any of the shipps Company, & also notwithstanding yoⁿ said petitioner the sooner to expedite his voyage, for performance of his said admiralty, appointed yesternight that his long boate with seauen of his men should goe up to Flowerdie hundred to fetch Downe him for making his hart & furnace, The said Guyar about midnight in high scorne & Contempt of their Loⁿps Commission under his Maⁿ seale for that Counsell, & of yoⁿ authority also, as if hee had some greater power in himselfe, & vtterly to hinder the preparation of yoⁿ petitioners voyage for his Maⁿⁿ service in those parts, & his returne hither for the releife of the Colony in these tymes & straightnes & Danger, & to stirr up the Coles of Mutiny once againe, sent Comand aboard the same shipp to those of his factions, that no boate should moue from the shipps side, tell other order Came from him the said Guyar, and (abususing with all the best name in the Cuntry, from the gouernⁿ and so yoⁿ petitioners authority of Admirall is trampled vnderfoot. And therfore yoⁿ petitioner humblie desireth that seeing they are fallen into a relapse farr more hanious & willfull then their former error & that there is so Cleere Muidence against them, & that White said last night, there should be a tricke for the Captaine viz Yoⁿ petitioner, you would be pleased for vindicating the honor & authority of his Maⁿ seale, & also for his Maⁿⁿ Counsell of New England, & of yoⁿ selues the Gouernor & Counsell of estate here, & to Cleare away to the releife of this angustiated Colony & for the saffety of yoⁿ petitioner now threatned & hindred in his Maⁿ service here to Cutt off all Delayes of examing further witnesses, which may be occasion of new mutenie and Danger in the same shipp & forthwith to send up to two malefactors to some remote part up the riuer, there to be in safe Custody from breeding further troubles, either by word or writing among the said shipps Compⁿ, & also to attach all their goods in the Country for satisfying yoⁿ petitioners damages, till such time as order may come from their Loⁿps in England, how these two shalbe disposed of.

CDNAXVI. Robert Guyar AND John White. ANSWER TO THE SECOND COMPLAINT AND Petition OF Captain John HARVEY

March, 1623/4 Manuscript Records Virginia Company, II, pt. ii, p. 62a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 634

To the hono:ble Sr Francis Wyatt knight etc. and the right wor:ll the rest of the Counsell of State

The answer of Robert Guyar and John White to ye second Complaint and peticion of Capt John Haruey esq:

Touching Capt John Haruey Commission for the Admiralty of New England, & all the authority that by vertue therof can lawfully bee Challenged, ouer vs, wee willingly submitt o'selues thervnto no way Conceauing it to be here in force.

Hee Inferreth yo:r order prohibiting o:r privat Conference w:th any of ye shipps Company, as though hee would, but indeed nether doth, nor Can iustly accuse vs of the breach therof.

His pretence of sending men to Monardieu hundred to fetch him, is by vs Coniectured to be meerly an excuse to send them out of the way, that they should not bee present to testifie the truths in o:r behalfs, ye rather for that (as it is not vnknowen vnto them, Robert Guyar had formerly sent men to Warrisquincke for that purpose, the Jealousy of such an excuse was ye cause (it is Confessed) that Robert Guyar sent word by mr Dennis his boat & men aboard the Southampton, entreating them to speake to one of the quarter m:rs to will the rest of the Company not to absent themselues, because the Gouernor would send for them the next Day, thinking himselfe to haue no small Cause so to doe, in regard Capt Haruey so earnestly pressed for speedy Sentence to be pronounced, alleadging a Crime to depriue him of life, Wherfore wee hope this board will not Censure it to be done, either as hee alledgeth, in Contempt of ther Lo:ps Commission, or of yo:r Authoritie, or to the intent to hinder his voyage or to stirr vp muteny.
2546:
464 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

Esteeming ourselves formerly to have Committed an error, (we Conceive not how we should have been fallen into a relapse, we thinke we Mr. Fenton's evidence so cleare (for the trucke) for it may well be supposed that hee remembreth not what was spoken by himselfe, or others at that tyme, in regard that men are & will be disposed to words (that hee viterly denieth to have spoken) Not a man among so many hearing John White use the words, that Mr. Fenton sweareth hee did speake, And that Capt. John Harvey still insisteth upon prescription of punishment, it being in our opinions above a petitioner privilege, & that besides those things that are [devuliped?] & [blank], Robert Guyar by his former familiarity with him, having warrant from his own mouth Just Cause of Jealousy, that hee hath further Authority, that is yet manifest here, We humble desire by the authority of this board, to have it under his hand in writing if hee have any further power to Command the Governor, then is yet revealed or not Subscribed.

Robert Guyar
John White
Commissioners in Virginia.

CDNNXVIII. Henry Horner. Petition to Sr Francis Wyatt AND THE COUNCIL

MARCH 9, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 61 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 647

To the right Wor[shipful] Sr Francis Wyatt Knight etc. and Counsell of Estate here Assembled

The Humble Petition of Henery Horner

In all humbleness of duty sheweth to yo[u]r good wo[rship]. that in July last past yo[u]r humble petitioner, upon some former & familiar acquaintance w[ith] Mr. Jo[hn] Procter of Virginia, upon some Conference had w[ith] him understanding by him, that hee was intended to come out into this Country & upon the good report hee gave of the Country I ever conceiving a good opinion of him was induced thereby to come ov[er] in[to] this Country w[ith] him, desiring to have his best advice & sound directions, what Com[modities] were most beneficiall for me to transport for this Country, whereupon the said Mr. Procter gave yo[u]r petitioner an Invoice of all such needfull necessaries & provisions as were most fittest & Commodious for me to bring ov[er] w[ith] me. And w[ith] all told me that all those goods of mine should be shipped in his ship, otherwise they would not be received into the good ship called the George, only willing me to provide him money w[hich] accordingly I did referring myselfe solely to his

1 For the Laws and Orders of this date, Doc. No. CDXXXVII A, see p. 580, post.
2549:
MARCH 9, 1623

467

upright and honest dealing with me, as well as the shipping of goods, as also to provide me a man servant, whereunto hee answered me saying that hee had daily Choice of men offered him, willing me not to trouble myself therewith, the Charge of my provisions, the fraight thereof, & the passage of myself & my man amounting to the some of 48 li 17 s 9 d wet money the said Mr. Procter received of your petitioner to a penny as plainly shall appeare to your worship as Concerning the man hee provided for me named Richard Croue hee had bound him with himselfe, enioyning men to say anything unto the said Croue, before hee Came aboard the shipp, & then hee would resigne him out unto me. I paid for the horse hire of the said Richard Croue from London to Portsmouth, & since his landing here I have found him meat & drinke, apparrell & lodging & both at sea & since his landing here hee hath been cut reputed & approved my servant, but most wrongfully hee detaineth him from me only hee will assign out unto me one Thomas Flower another man for three yeares, who now he also denyeth to performe, bidding me Complaine to your worship. In Consideration whereof & for that your petitioner is a poore young gentleman & hath been meerly deluded & wronged by the said Mr. Procter to his great discouragement, losse & hindrance, May it please your good worship to grant your warrant to Cause the said Procter to Come before you, that by Course of equity & true Justice you require him to resigne & deliver unto him me as well all my goods as my said servant to the end that I may bee both master & disposer of what is my owne, for that I fully purpose never to have any further dealing with him or any the like, & your petitioner shall ever have Just Cause to pray etc.

See the Court holden the 9th of March 1623.

The Humble Petition of Richard Quaile to the honoᵘʳ the Gouernor with the right Worᵖ and Worᵖ the Assistant in Counsell

Honorable, right Worᵖ etc.

[24] May it please you to vnderstand, yt yor & distressed suppliant haueing fro’ yor iust Censure undergone punishment for myne offence, haue Psumed vppon yoᵘ wounted goodnes to Psent this my humble petition. most humbly Craueing at yoᵘ hande, to bee pleased to Cast an ye of pity ypon my pouerty, & to vouchsafe to lend mee on hand to raise me vp againe, as you haue had an hand to humble me, I beseech you let my poore Case plead my Cause, who haue made of this place a meere plantacon of sorrowes & Cropp of troubles, haueing been plentifull in nothing but want & wanting nothing but plenty, It is not vnknowne, how I haue buried my good fortunes in my servants Deaths, in long sicknesse of my selfe & the death of my wife, so that the pillars of my raisings are fallen, & I Cannot expect to stand long after, besides all wch coucn wᵗʰ Compleateth the number of my Calamities, I haue so little to trust to my future releife, that I am more indebted to others, then I Can wᵗʰout my great hurt, and damage discharge, I beseech you therfore, honorable and right worᵖ to pity my estate, & not to suffer me to sincke in the degree of extremytie, but of yor owne Clemmency & my vnfained sorrowe vouchsafe to pitty me, & be pleased to ease me of that heauy burthen of my fine Imposed on me, wᵗʰ I am not able to vndergoe, Let pity pleade my pardon & my misary second it, and in tyme to come (god assisting) my fidelity to my King, my Cuntry & you, shall giue you Cause not to repent of yoᵘ vnderserued fauoᵘʳs.

Yoᵘ Humble distressed suppliant

RICHARD QUAILE

CDAL. George Harrison, Petition to Sir Francis Wyatt and Council

March 11, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 61

Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C.

List of Records No. 6492

To the right Worll Sr. Francis Wyatt knight and the rest of yor Worll Counsell of Estate

The Humble petition of George Harrison

[25] Most humble sheweth vnto yor worps: yor petitioner, that whereas yor said petitioner had certaine goods & fower men shipped into the good shipp Called the Marmaduke into the hande of Mr. Dennis being by John Harrison of London to be deliuered vnto yor petitioner his brother, all fraight for goods & passages & paid vnto the said Mr. Dennis. Now so it is that ye sd Dennis Coming by the West Indies, ther to deliuer some Certaine goods & passengers, did giue & grant vnto one of yor sd petitioners fower seruants at the request one Lieutenant Ben to helpe the sd Lieutenant to shore wth ther goods, & by that meanes did there leaue yor petitioner said seruant, & this the other three will testifie vpon ther Oathes & the said Mr. Dennis will not allow or give any satisfaction or Content to yor sd petitioner for his servant so lost by his owne negligence to the great hindrance & losse of yor sd petitioner.

May it therfore please yor Worps. to send for the said Mr. Dennis before you, wherby such order may be taken, that yor said petitioner may haue & receaue such good content & satisfaction of the said Mr. Dennis for his lost man, as yor Worps shall thinke in that Case to be meete and Convenient, And yor petitioner shall eu' pray for long life & happines.

CDXLI. Governor in Virginia. A Commission to Rawleigh CROSHAW

March 16, 1623

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 41a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 652

By the Gouernor & Capt. generall of Virginia

To all to whome these presents shall Come greeting in our Lord euerlasting

Knowe yee yt I Sr Francis Wyett Knight Gouernor & Capt. generall of Virginia. Endeuoring the sufficiency of Corne to releiue ye necessitie of this our Country, doe by these presents giue leaue, power & authoritie vnto Capt. Rawleigh Croshawe to Embarque himselfe & his Comp. in the ye good shipp called the Elizabeth, & to sett sayle with ye first oppertunity of wynde into ye Bay into any rivers, Creeks or harbors to vs appertaining there to trade with ye salvages for Corne or any other Comodities they Can afford him provided yt it shall not be lawfull for the said Capt. Rawleigh Croshawe nor any of his Company by force to compel ye said salvages to trade nor to kill or to offer them violence or injurie (except in their owne defence vpon great suspicion of treachery intended against them to the danger of their lives). And for ye better managing of this Imployment, & redressing of all disorder & mutinies incident to such affaires, I doe by these presents nominate & appoint him the said Capt. Rawleigh Croshawe absolute sole Commander during this voyage giueing him full power & authoritie to punish all sorts of offenders according to ye lawes & Customes of the seas, And such further power to punish at his discretion life only excepted, as is incident to any Capt. Commander or officer of his qualitie. Giuen at James Citty vnder my hand & ye seale of this Colony March the xvjth 1623.

Francis Wyett.

CDALII. John Harvey. Third Petition to Sir Francis Wyatt AND THE COUNCIL

March 23, 24, 25, 1623/4

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 63 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 653

To the right Worll Sr: Francis Wyatt knight etc. and to ye Counsell of Estate the third petition of John Harvey Esq.

[84] Whereas after yoʳ peticioner had this morning aboard his shipp the Southampton published his Comission for the admyrallty of New England, that part of the shipps Company that adheareth to Guyver & White, did mutiny more then before, and being Comaunded to ther worke, refused, takeing away the boate in despite of the boateswame, Cuming tumultuously ashoure, and vureuently disobeying the Gouernor himselfe, when hee willed them to returne aboard, yoʳ peticioner hath Just Cause to doubt least they should make a bulwarke of his shipp against yoʳ authority, & against the safety of his person & estate.

Humbly prayeth that for preuention of all further danger threatned by these Mutyners against yoʳ petitioner, ther persons may be removed of the shipp ere such tyme, as the whole body of the Counsell doe meete for the farther debate of so waighty a Cause, the wch meeting hee desireth may bee wt all speed possible, for ye wch fauor hee shall rest much bound vnto you.

CDXLIII. ROBERT GUYAR AND JOHN WHITE. A Petition To SIR Francis Wyatt AND THE COUNCIL March 23, 24, 25, 1623/4 Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 63 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 654

To the right hono’ble Sir Francis Wyatt Knight &c. the right Wor’ll the Counsell of state

The Humble Petition of Robert Guyar and John White

[35] Whereas Capt: John Harvey Esq. hath and doth prosecute law against yo'r petitioners pretending them to be mutiners, whereupon it pleaseth this board to prohibit them from going aboard to their no small prejudice, loss of time, & if some speedy order be not taken for redress utter subversion of all their designes

May it please therefore this hono’ble Court to proceed to Censure, either to Condemn or Clear yo'r petitioners of these accusations, that are laid to their Charge, and to take such order that they may proceed in their first intended voyage, otherwise to be discharged from further employment in the ship. And that Capt Harvey may put in sufficient sureties to discharge what Robert Guyar is engaged for him, & that he may pay what is otherwise due to him & the shipps Company, beseeching you to take into your Consideration how precious time is, & how prejudicial the loss thereof

Robert Guyar
JOHN WHITE

CDALIV.

Jane Dickenson. Petition To THE GOVERNOR AND COUNCIL

MARCH 30, 1624

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 61a

Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 635

To the honobᵉ right Worᵖ etc., the Gouernor and Counsell of Estate in Virginia

The humble Petition of Jane Dickenson Widdowe

[28] Most humbly sheweth that whereas her late husband Ralph Diekenson Came ouer into this Country fower Yeares since, obliged to Nicholas Tide deceased for yᵉ tearme of seauen yeares, hee only to haue for himselfe & yoᵘ petitioner yᵉ one halfe of his labors, her said husband being slaine in the bloudy Massacre, & her selfe Caried away wᵗʰ the Cruell saluages, amongst them Induring much misery for teen monthes At the Expiration it pleased God so to dispose the hartes of the Indians, yᵗ for a small ransome yoᵘ petitioner wᵗʰ diuers others should be released, In Consideration that Doctor Potts laid out two pound of beades for her releasement, hee alleageth yoᵘ petioner is linked to his seruitude wᵗʰ a twofold Chaine the one for her late husband’s obligation & thother for her ransome, of both wᵗʰ shee hopeth that in Conscience shee ought to be discharged, of yᵉ first by her widdowhood, of the second by the law of nations, Considering shee hath already serued teen months, too much for two pound of beades. The premises notwithstanding Dr. Pott refuseth to sett yoᵘ peticioner at liberty, threatning to make her serue the vttermost day, vnlesse shee procure him 150℔ waight of Tobacco, shee therfore most humbly desiereth, that yoᵘ wilbe pleased to take wᵗʰ Course shalbe thought iust for her releasement fro’ his seruitude, Considering that it much differeth not from her slauery wᵗʰ the Indians, & yoᵘ peticioner shalbe bound to pray etc.

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 61 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. List of Records No. 659

To the right Worll. Sir Francis Wyatt knight etc. The Humble Petition of John Hall

[26] Most humbly sheweth that John Johnson agreed with your petitioner to goe in his place & stead in the last March with your worship for which hee was to pay your petitioner the somme of tenn pounde sterling which hee refuseth to pay & wrongfully detaineth from him forty shillinges sterling, which your petitioner paid for apparel for his servant made, for all which debt your petitioner can gett no honest satisfaction. In tender consideration whereof, & for that your poore petitioner hath received great losse and hindrance by goeing the reb, & now standeth in great want of provision & thinges necessary to relieve himselfe & his charge, your petitioner most humbly beseecheth your worship to grant your warrant to cause the said John Johnson to give your petitioner due satisfaction.

CDXLVI. Council in Virginia. A Letter to THE Earl of SOUTHAMPTON AND THE COUNCIL AND COMPANY OF VIRGINIA

April 17, 1624

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. i, p. 8a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. List of Records No. 660

Right Honorable &c.

Since our last Letters, we have mett in our generall Assemblie, wherein we have considered of those thinges, which may most conduce to the good of the Plantation, and have sent the particulars of our proceedings by Mr. John Pountis, elected by the Generall Assembly to Solicit our Common Interest.
2557:
APRIL 17, 1624

Cause with the King's most excellent Maiestie and the Lords of his most Honorable Privie Counsell, wherein we doubt not but you will express your noble and accustomed Zeale to this worthie Action, in your countenance, advise and furtherance of our affaires. The many misinformations and wrong Conceptions of those, whose Knowledge must depend upon vncertaine relations, hath induced us and the Countrey in generall to present Virginia with her severall statutes and Conditions, the grounde of her evils and wayes of her restauration, which we hope shall vindicate her Excellency, your Zeale, and our endeavors from malice and faction. We have little more to informe you of at this tyme, than what these relations and our last Letters comprehend, only the Colony is at this tyme in very good health, God be praysed, and furnished with store of provisions. And a greate impiety it was in those, whose slanders have kept back such supplies of People as intended to come over. Our Continuall troubles have Exhausted that Powder and shott wherewith we were provided the last yeere by your Care, we desire a large and sudden Supplie. We humbly take our leaves and rest devoted to your service.

Francis Wyatt
George Yardley
April the 17, 1624
George Sandis
John Pott
Roger Smith
Ralph Hammer

To the right Honorable Henry Marlo of Southampton with the Lords and others of the Counsell of and Company of Virginia.

CDXLVI, John Harvey. A Letter to Sir Nathaniel Rice April 24, 1624

Manchester Papers, No. 400 Document in Public Record Office, London. Autograph document List of Records No. 663

Honorable Knight

I and my friends appointed, have done our utmost endeavors for searching out the truth in answer to those commands which the Lords of his Maᵗ Privy Council were pleased to send unto us; and do find the persons here to be more in number, and provision of victuals to be more plentiful than we expected, after the Massacre and so great a mortality both of men and Cattle, but there is great want of Ammunition, and diverse solitary plantations too slenderly peopled, to avoid the vigilance of so subtle and nimble an enemy, whereby, and by the stupid security of our nation it is to be feared, that in Summer time when the corn and weeds are grown high, here will be much mischief done, as the Attempts of the Indians in these two months of March and April, a beadroll whereof sent to their Lords Mr. Pory will show you, do shrewdly prognosticate. Otherwise were the Indians driven off from infesting our people and Cattle, as with no great forces in two or 3 years, they might be, then the Plantation with good government would undoubtedly flourish. In February at our coming in, they were here met in a general assembly, the first fruits whereof, were most bitter invectives in the highest pitch of spleen and detraction, against the twelve years government of Sr. Thomas Smith, and in answer to Als Alderman Johnson and Captain Butler, with a letter, petition, and other things all presented partly to his Maᵗ and partly to the Lords, the copies whereof we have attained unto, for your and their better information, and do hope they will come to your hands before the delivery of the Originals, by Mr. Pountess, the messenger of the general assembly; ever since the arrival of the Bonny Besse which was in September last [2] these storms have been a-breeding, and at our arrival at James City, we found men's minds fully possessed. Longer I need not trouble your patience through the hand of so understanding and well-furnished a messenger.

CDXLVII. James I. A Letter To THE SPEAKER OF THE House OF Commons

APRIL 28, 1624

State Papers, Domestic, James I, Vol. 163, No. 71 Document in the Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 665

Trusty &c. Whereas wee have taken notice That some of the Virginia Compagnie have presented a Petition to our House of Commons, and doubting it might occasion the repetition, and renewing of those Discords, and Contentions, which have been amongst them, and which by our great care, and the Directions of our Counsell are in a good way to bee composed, We doe signify to our House of Commons, That wee hold it very unfitt for the Parliam't to trouble themselves with those Matters, which can produce nothing, but a further increase of Schisme, and Faction, and disturbe the happy and peaceable proceeding of the Parliam't which wee hope your cares (as hitherto they have done) shall concurr with ours to bring to a good issue, As for these businesses of Virginia, and the Barmudoes, ourself have taken them to heart, and will make it our own worke to settle the quiet, and welfare of those Plantations, and will bee ready
2562: 478 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY to doe anything that may bee for the reall benefitt, and advancement of them. This we thought good to intimate to our house of Commons, not out of favour, respect or mediation of any party, but of our own Princely love, and regard to our House of Commons, And we earnestly desire to remove all occasion, that might either disturb the Peace of it, or hinder you from your more urgent, and weighty Occasions, and assure ourself our house of Commons will take in good part, and correspond with us herein, as they have done in all things else during this Session. Given &c. at Windsor, April 28, 1624. CDNLIA. Nicholas Ferrar. A Draft (and Copy) for a Petition FROM THE COMMONS May, 1624 Ferrar Papers Document in Magdalene College, Cambridge. Rough draft in Nicholas Ferrar's autograph and a copy in Edward Collingwood’s writing List of Records No. 669 Spanish Tobacco. Your Majesties most Humble Commons, taking into careful consideration, the great want of money in this your Realm at this day; whereby Rents are unpaid, Contracts broken, Bonds forfeited, Markets and Fairs much deserted, or unfrequented, the better sort impoverished, and the meaner (for want of means in the better) not set on work; extending, not only to a general Distemper amongst your Subjects at home, but to the hinderance also of Trade, and Traffique abroad; (money being as well the Mother as Daughter thereof) And doubting, lest the same want, may in fine also redound to the prejudice of your Majesty in Subsidies and other Duties, granted or to be granted for the service of your Majesty: and necessary defence of your Kingdoms: they have thought fit, to present one petition to your Majesty's princely regard one principal cause of this want, amongst divers others, which the straightness of time, doth exclude from exact and full consideration.
2563:
MAY 1624

It is generally knowen, that the West Indies, are at this day almoast the onely Fountayne, and Spayne as it were the Cesterne, from whence Silver is deriued into all parts of Christendom. The cause of the greate Importation of siluer from thence into this Realme, hath beene for that Spayne having soe greate need of many English Commodities and being not able to Counterballance them with their owne, they haue beene forced to make the acompt euen with Mony. But since this Weede of Tobacho hath growen into request, they haue payde, (as their Prouerb is) for all our Commodities with Their Smoake: And the vayne of there siluer to us ward, hath beene in a manner dried upp, to the Loss of a Million and a halfe in mony in these fifteene yeares last past. For uppon very full and exact examination, it hath very playnely and undeniably appeared, that what by vndersale of our Natiue Commodities to make ready mony for their Tobacho, what by the mony itselfe payde unto them for that weede, there hath beene lost to this Kingdom of one hundred Thousand pound euery yeare, which else would haue returned in mony from thence. And a miserable kynde of Trade hath been driuen with that Nation, our Natiue Commodities being undersolde, and the forreigne ouerbought, and the Treasure of mony transformed into a Smoaking weed. Your humble Commons therfore, moast instantly craue of your Maᵗⁱᵉ, that the Importation of Tobacho, may bee prohibited from all other parts ether then your Maᵗⁱᵉ Sowne Dominions, according to the Practize in like Cases in all other Nations, in fauour of the natiue Commodities, and of their Naturall People.

[Indorsed:] Petitions to Parliamᵗ rel to Virginia.

The Humble Petition of Richard Barnes gent:

[29] Sheweth that whereas your petitioner is iustly Conuicted of rash & most vnbecoming words against your worthy person, before the Counsiel of State in this Country, & is thereupon worthily Censured to vndergoe Certaine punishments, his most humble petition is that howsoeuer hee Confesseth himselfe vtterly unworthie of the least fauor from you, yett if you would be pleased of your accustomed goodnes to mittigate the said Censure, as to your wisedome shall seeme fitt & your petitioner shall not only pray, as by duty he shall be bound, for your reall prosperity but shall euer desire that, & thinke himselfe most happy, if there be euer an occasion offered, whereby hee may show himselfe truly thankefull for so extraordinarie & vndeserued fauor, & if it be possible make reparation for so foule an Injury to so noble a gentleman as yourselfe.

COLL. COUNCIL IN VIRGINIA. A LETTER TO THE EARL OF SOUTHAMPTON AND THE COUNCIL AND COMPANY OF VIRGINIA

May 12, 1624

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. i, p. 9

Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 675

Right Honorable &c.

Whereas the generall Assembly, at the Commissioners request, haue Answered [in] writing vnto fower propositions, wherein the Lords of his
2565:
MAY 12, 1624

481

May it please your most Honorable privie Counsell expected Satisfactione from them, Receavinge a voluntarie promise to participate with us, after they had more fully informed themselves, Theire Conceptions of the same, wch beinge since demanded, was denied in this respect (videlicet) that theire Lo: might haue the firste Survey of whatt they intended to present. We havinge the same care, were prevented by Mr. Porye who contrary to his professed integritie, Hath suborned the Clarke of our Counsell with reward and promises to betray our Secrecye, and to geve him Copies of all our proceedings (for wch he hath receaved dew Punishment of his periurye by the losse of his eares). Wherein we Cannott but Suspect some Sinister intentione of forstallinge our Counsells, the doupt wherof he thought A Sufficyent exeuse to disingage him of his solem promise. We thought it our dewties, with the firste, to acquainte you heerwith, that you may both vnderstande his duble dealinge (and prevent his practises) hopinge theire Lps, who ymployde him will give smale Creditt to any his pticuler informations, which agree nott with the generall, The Acte arguinge faction and noe way becominge the service. We humblie take our leaves & rest devoted to your Service.

Maye the 12th 1624

Francis WYAtt  
GEORGE YARDLEY  
GEORGE SANDIS  
John POTT  
ROGER SMITHE  
Ralph Hamer

CDLI. Ralph Hamour. A Petition to Sir Francis Wyatt AND THE COUNCIL May 30, 1624 Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 61 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C. List of Records No. 678

To the honoᵇˡᵉ Sir Francis Wyatt knight &c. and the rest of Counsell of Estate in Virginia. The humble Petition of Ralph Hamour

(80) Whereas yoᵘʳ petitioner as well for monies adventured in yᵉ generall stocke of yᵉ compᵃⁿʸ, as for transporting divers servant of his owne Charge, is to take up a great quantity of land in Virginia, as also had a particular patent fro’ yᵉ Compᵃⁿʸ in England for a great plantation, as by the printed booke may appeare, wᶜʰ patent was burnt in the Masacre, And for as much as yoᵘʳ peticioner hath been a planter in Virginia, these fifteen yeares, & now & purpose to settle a plantation already begun upon an Island, Called Hoge Island, In wᶜʰ Island Mr. Robert Euers is by patent, granted about sixe yeares since by Sr. Yardly knight then Gouernor of Virginia, to take 490 acres wᶜʰ till this time hee hath wholy neglected, & by vertue of the said patent layeth Claime to yᵉ whole Island, Concerning by estimation no lesse then 2000 Acres, my humble request is yt yᵉ said Mr. Euers may be sumoned to appeare before this Court, to make proofe of his title of land in this Island, & also be ordred to Cause his 490 Acres to be surveyed, & made a Choice of in some one part of yᵉ Island not already Cleared & seated upon, that so no doubt or scruple of a good or sure title in the said Island, may be any hindrance for the plantation thereof, being every way Commodious for the generall Colony in Virginia, & that it would further please this Court, Mr. Euers haveing first made Choice of his land, to Confirme the rest of the said Island to yoᵘʳ petitioner, in part of his shares of land due to him, excepting also that parcell of land Cleared by Southampton hundred Company, & yor petitioner wilbe bound to plant & seate upon the said Island wᶦᵗʰin these two yeares, so many persons, as ther shall appeare, upon the surveie of the said Island to bee single shares of land, I hope the reasonablenes of my request shall obtaine all lawfull favor.
2567:
JUNE 14, 1624

& furtherance the rather in respect the Company in England by their patent granted me under their great seale, gaue me liberty to make Choice of any land, not actually inhabited nor laid out for particular deuidents. And I shall euer, as I haue hitherto faithfully, Endeauor the good & prosperity of this plantation. James Citty May the 30th 1624. State Papers, Domestic, James I, Vol. 167, No. 60 Document in Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 683

14 June 1624

It is not vnknowen that at the death of your cousin who was employed in the Virginia business there were remaining in his hands diuers Letters and papers of importance concerning those affaires which may be verie vsefull and therefore fit to be Preserved in safetie. And because his Majesty is informed that those papers are either in your custodie or where you may haue the
2568:

command of them, His pleasure and commandement is that such of those papers as remayne with you, you keep safely, and carefully against such time as use may bee made of them. And if you knowe where anie of them are in the custodie of others, you are to call for them and cause them to bee putt in like safetie, that none of them bee Wantinge when there shalbe occasion to use them. This is the charge &c. Sr Thomas Merrie

CDLVI. LETTER AND PETITION CONCERNING VIRGINIA INTENDED FOR DELIVERY TO THE KING

June 22, 1624

Manchester Papers, No. 403 Document in Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 685

I conceaue it standeth with the duety I owe his Ma'tie to giue him information that I heare the State of the Virg. Plantacion is so desperate that both my self and others with whome I have conferred doe apprehend that the Companie intend to neglect the sending of any supplyes thither & then by Clamour to lay the blame of the destruction of that Plantacion vpon the proceedings which by his Ma'ties direction haue been taken against them, though in trueth they tended onely to the redress of their abuses & this is apparent both by their complaint in Parliament (where they sought to haue raised their owne reputation vpon the ruine of others) and by their carriage since.

[This letter ends abruptly here: on the next page is the following draft]

you haue opposed the course for reforming the abuses of the plantacion you haue complained of with your Commissioners and of those that haue informed both me and them whereby time those abuses might haue been redrest. We cannot now in respect of other important business settle and the season of the yeare so farre spent enter into such a thorough examination of particulars concerning the same as we intended: But seeing notwithstanding all your clamour we are fully assured that by your misgovernment the estate of that plantacion is brought into the wretched estate wherein now it standeth; we require you that for the present you see on And that nothing but your owne wayes are growne plausible; We haue for the present thought it fitt to lett you know that if the worke doe perish vnder your hands We will expect a strict Account of it from you (as and therefore require you as you so to proceed in the quiet & orderly managing of those affaires and making seasonable supplyes for the relief of the Colonye before winter approach that we may not haue hereafter more cause added to the former to lett you feele the effects of your iust displeasure, but rather

[This letter ends abruptly here and then follows the petition]
2570:
486 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

May it please your most excellent Maᵗᵉ

Whereas heretofore your Maᵗᵉ out of your princelie care and regard of the good and welfare of the Plantation of Virginia have as well in your owne royall person, as by the endeavours of the right honᵇˡᵉ the LLᵈˢ and others of your Maᵗᵉ's privie Counsell, and by speciall Commission therevnto appointed laboured to be thoroughly informed of the true estate of those affaires: By which inquirie the miserable condition thereof (as we conceaue) evidently appeare to be such that vnlesse some present course were taken therein the whole worke must sodainlie fall into vtter Ruine: which could not but be foreseene by those that principally manage the affaires of that Companie who being in all likelihood possest with an Opinion of an Impossibilitie of bringing that worke out of the extremities whereinto it is fallen doe (as by sondrie of their courses (we conceaue) neglecting the care of the plantation) intend nothing but how to derive the blame of miscarriage of that businesse from themselues by laying Imputation vpon others who have only desired a Reformation of the abuses which threaten the destruction of that good worke: And for that by process of tyme wherein these things hang in suspence and undecided the plantation doth dailie suffer We who at first petitioned your Maᵗᵉ for some course to redress Those fatall disorders have thought it our bounden duties most humblie againe to petition your gracious goodnes that the estate wherein that plantation by the is found to be by the Certificate of the Commission and which we thinke is now much worse, may be published, and that some such direction may be therevppon given for the good of the said plantation as to your great wisedome shall seeme most fit and convenient: most vnfainedlie professing to your sacred Maᵗᵉ that herein we desire nothing but the preservation of your Maᵗᵉ's honor, the supportation of the worke itself, and the freeing of our owne soules from being any waies necessarie to the great mischiefes and Inconveniences vnder which the said plantation hath long laboured and which seeme to vs to deale with them and threaten the very life and subsistence thereof almost brought to a period as are vines by your Maᵗᵉ's speciall care they be speedelie prevented and redressed:

[Indorsed:] Coppy of a petition intended to be delivered to his Maᵗᵉ concerning Virginia &c. and a letter from the Council to the Company. 22 June 1624.

CDLVII. Assembly in Virginia. Law against Unlawful, Improper Contracts of Marriage

June 24, 1624

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 498 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. List of Records No. 686

Whereas to the great contempt of the Mat of God and ill example to others, certaine Women within this Colony haue of late contrary to the Lawes ecclesiasticall of the Realme of England contracted themselues to two severall men at one time, whereby much trouble doth growe betweene parties: and the Governor and Counsell of State, thereby much disquieted: To prevent the like offence in others hereafter, It is by the Governor and Counsell ordered in Court, that every Minister giue notice in his Church to his parishoners, that what man or woman soever shall hereafter vse any word or speech tending to contract of Marriage vnto two severall persons at one time (though not Reall and legall, yet so as may intangle and breed scruple in their Consciences) shall for such their offence vndergo either corporall punishment (as whippinge etc.) or other punishment by fyne, or otherwise, according to the qualitie of the person so offending. Given at James Cittie this 24th of June 1624.

They humblie praye that before any such Protection bee graunted, Itt maye please yoᵘ Loᵈ that there maye be a course taken for payment of the said monney, as is due by the said bond, for that the Company & Aduenturers haue nowe speciall occasion, for the Imployment thereof, to the Collonyes releife, wᶦʰ is att present in great neade of the same to furnishe and sett forth shipps for Virginia And they shall ever praye &c.

State Papers, Domestic, James I, Vol. 169, No. 7 Document in Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 693 His Maᵗ is pleased to direct his royall Commission to diners gentᵉ to treate & conclude a Contract for all yᵉ Tobacco of the English Collonyes for his Mᵃ vse In wᶦʰ treaty information is given by many men, that there are at this time divers shipps preparing and fraighting in yᵉ low Contryes, for the plantaéons of Virgᵃ & Caribbe Islands, wᶦʰ intention to trade there and to returne wᶦʰ Tobacco into those forreine parts, contrary to severall...

orders and proclamations, as also to the vtter ruine of the contract now in treaty and likely to take effect. For the preuention of wch mischeife to the sayd plantacions and his Maᵗʲes service. It is humbly desired that strict charge and command be given either from his Maᵗʲe or this Hoᵗʳᵇˡᵉ Board, to the Gouernᵒʳ of Virgᶦⁿᶦᵃ especially, not to suffer any such trade by foreinᵉʳs vppon the sayd plantacion, there being no neede of their provisions, and being shipps enereh good store of our owne already gon & now going to supply their wants if any bee. Nathaniell Butler Esquier George Wilmore Esquier Willm Hackwell Esquier John Mildmay Esquier Phillipp Jermayne Esquier Edward Johnson Esquier Thomas Gibbes Esquier Samuell Wrote Esquier John Porey Esquier Michaell Hawes Esquier Edwarde Palavicine Esquier Roberte Bateman merchant Martyn Bond merchant Thomas Styles merchant Nichas Leate merchant Roberte Bell merchant Abraham Cartwright merchant Richard Edwards merchant John Dyke merchant Anthony Abdy merchant Willm Palmer merchant Edward Ditchfeild George Mole merchant and Richard Murer greeting Whereas heretofore at the humble suite [and requeste] of divers our loving subjects intending to deduce a Colony and to make habitation and plantation of sundry our people in that parte of America comonly called Virginia and other partes and territories in America Wee greatly commending and graciously accepting their desires to the furtherance of soe noble a Worke which might by the providence of Almightye God thereafter tende to the glory of his Maiestye in propagating religion to such people as then lived in darkenes and miserable ignorance of the true knowledge and Worshippe of God and might in tyme bring the Infidells and Savages in those partes to human Civilitye and to a setled and quiett governement did by our tres Patentes in the fourth yere of our raigne of Englande graunte to divers knightes gentlemen and others for the more speedy accomplishment of the said plantation That they should devide themselves into twoe Colonies the one consistinge of divers knightes gentlemen merchants and others of our Cittye of London called the firste Colony and the other of sundrie knightes gentlemen and others of the Cittyes of Bristoll and Exeter the towne of Plymouth and other places called the seconde Colony And Wee did by the same tres Patentes graunte that the said Colonies might make their plantations and habitations in
2576:
492 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

certain places in the same tres Patentes expressed. And [wee] did thereby alsoe graunte that the said Collonies should have divers landes groundes havens portes comodities and hereditamentes and divers priuileges and libties for theire quiett setling and good goverment in the saide plantaçons. In and by which tres Patentes Wee did declare our pleasure that Wee our heires and successors Would from tyme to tyme ordeyne and give such further instrucçons lawes constituçons and ordinances for the better rule and goverment of such as so should make plantaçon there as to vs our heires and successors should from tyme to tyme be thought convenyent. And whereas Wee according to the effecte and true meaneing of the saide tres Patentes did by seuerall Tres vnder our privy Seale prescribe and give orders ordinances and constituçons for directing and ordering the affayres of the same first Colony. And whereas afterwardes vpon the peticon of divers of our loving Subiects aswell adventurers as planters of the saide first Colony Wee did by our tres Patentes in the seaventeenth yere of our raigne mençon to incorporate divers noble men knights gentlemen and others therein pticulerly named and all others that shoulde be admitted to joyne with them by the name of Tresorer and Company of Adventurers and planters of the Cittye of London for the firste Colony in Virginia graunting vnto them divers landes territories and Countries in the saide tres Patentes mençoned With pmision that they shoulde distribute convey and assigne vnder theire Comon Seale such pticuler porçons of landes to the said Adventurers and planters as vpon a Comission of Survey to that purpose shoulde be named appointed and allowed. And Wee did thereby alsoe graunte that there shoulde be a Councell here residente for the managing of the affaires of the saide Colonye with power to place and displace officers and make lawes and ordinances for the govermente of the saide Colonye and plantaçon and the affaires of the Company and Wee graunted vnto the saide Thesorer and Company and theire successors divers powers liberties and autorities and afterwardes by our tres Patentes in the nynth yere of our raigne of Englande Wee for the Consideraçons therein expressed did further mençon to give to the saide Tresorer and Company and theire successors divers other Islandes within the Ocean Seas within the lymitte in the saide tres Patentes expressed With other powers and authorities As by the said Tres Patentes may appere. And whereas Wee out of our zeale and affecçon to the furthering of the saide Plantaçons.

2577:
JULY 15, 1624

having still a Watchfull and careful eye to the same and finding the courses taken for the setling thereof had not taken that good effect which Wee intended and soe much desired did by our Comission lately graunted to certaine persons of quality and truste cause the state of the saide Countrie of Virginia to be examyned howe yt stood aswell in pointe of livelyhood as governmente and howe and in What manner the greate Somes of money collected and intended for the good thereof had beene expended and disbursed to the end yf good Cause were Wee might by our royall hande supplye what shoulde be founde defective And whereas our Comissioners after much care labour and paynes expended in execuéon of our saide Comissions did certifye vs that our subjects and people sent to inhabite there and to plante themselues in that Countrye Were most of them by God's visitaton sicknes of bodye famyne and by massacres of them by the native Savages of the lande dead and deceased and those that Were living of them lived in miserable and lamentable necessitye and Wante but the countrie (for any thing appered to the saide Comissioners to the contrary) they conceived to be fruitfull and healthfull after our people had beene some tyme there and that yf industrie Were vsed yt Woulde produce many staple and good comodities though as yet the sixteene yeres govermente nowe past had yeilded fewe or none and that this neglecte they conceived must fall on the governors and Company here Whoe had power to directe the plantaéons there And that the saide plantaCons were of greate ymportance and Woulde as they hoped remayne a lasting monumente of our most gracious and happy govermente to all posterity yf the same were prosecuted to these endes for which they were first vndertaken And to that purpose that yf our first graunte herein menéoned and our most prudente and princely instrueéons given in the beginyng of the plantaéon for the directon of the affaires thereof by thirteene Councellors in Virginia and as manye here all nomynated by vs had beene pursued much better effectes had beene produced then had beene by the alteraéon thereof into soe populer a course and amongst soe manye handes as then yt was which caused much contenéon and confusion Whereupon Wee entering into mature and delibate consideraéon of the premisses did by the aduise of the Lordes of our Privie Councell resolue by altering the Charters and tres Patentes of the saide Company as to the pointes of govermente Wherein the same might be founde defective to settle such a course as mighte best secure the safety of our people there and cause the saide plantaton to florishe and yet with
2578: 404 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY preservation of the interest of every planter or Adventurer so far forth as their present interest shall not prejudice the public plantations but because the said Treasurer and Company did not submit their Charters to be reformed our proceedings therein were stayed for a time until upon a Quo Warranto brought and a legal and judicial proceeding therein by due course of law the said charters are avoided. Now forasmuch as We are still resolved and determined to proceed in the course Which We ever intended for the good of the said plantation which our desire is to effect and establish by a new Charter to be made in such manner as shall be found most convenient for the general good of the said plantation and Colony and because the points of the said Charter newly to be granted may be many and as well in respect of the number as of the nature and consequence of them will require advised consideration and deliberation before it be passed and much time care and pains must be taken therein and yet the least delay may prove perilous to the said plantations and Colony Which may suffer much inconvenience for Want of good government and direction if in the mean time it be not well ordered know ye that We for the better progression to the effecting of this our royal pleasure and reposing assured trust and confidence in the understanding care fidelity and circumspection of you the said Lord Edmondes, Sir John Suckling, Sir George Calvert, Sir Edward Conway, Sir Richard Weston, and Sir Julius Caesar to be one) full power and authority to take into your Considerations the state of the said Colony and plantation and to treat, consult, and consider of all matters whatsoever concerning the said Colony and plantation as well for the safety of the people there, strength of the place, and government to be exercised there, as for the managing of the business and affairs thereof here in England and upon deliberate consideration thereupon had to direct and settle all business and affairs concerning the same in such manner and by such orders, rules, and directions and such good ways and means as you or any such six or more of you as aforesaid shall for the present in your Wisdoms and discretions find most necessary, fit, and convenient. And to the end you may the better be enabled to perform the same, We do hereby give unto you or any such six or more of you as aforesaid full power and authority to put in execution and to perform and execute according to your sound discretions all, every, or any of the powers, authorities, privileges, matters, and things whatsoever concerning the said Colony and plantation and the Inhabitants, planters, and adventurers of, in, or unto the same which by the aforesaid Letters Patents or any of them We meant to be granted to the said Treasurer and Company or any of them or to the Treasurer and Council for the said first Colony or any of them or which they or any of them might have done, executed, or performed by virtue of any our said Charters, Letters Patents, grants, or instructions whatsoever before the judgment given upon the said Quo Warranto and to take into your hands or into the hands of such as you or any such six or more of you shall appoint all such goods, Chattels, merchandizes, and money as are in the hands of any person or persons for or concerning the public uses of the said Colony and plantation or either of them or of the said pretended Governor and Company. And further to give order and direction for sending of supplies to the said Colony as well by and out of the proceeds of the said goods, merchandizes, and money as by such other way or means as you or any such six or more of you as aforesaid shall think fit and convenient. And further that you or any such six or more of you as aforesaid shall have full power and authority by virtue of these Presents to give direction for assembling and calling together from time to time as occasion shall require the adventurers or Planters to confer with them of and concerning such matters and things as may any wise tend to the advancement, furtherance, or 135307 —35- 33
2580:
496 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

settling of the saide plantation and to appoynte Comittees for the due preparation of such affayres of the saide Plantation as to you or any such sixe or more of you shall seeme meete and convenient. And further Wee doe by theise presents give like power and authoritye vnto you or any such sixe or more of you to consulte, consider of, propose and sett downe all such matters and thinges as you in your Judgementes and discrecions shall thinke moste necessarie and convenyente for the settling and establishing of the governmente of the saide Colony or plantation and concerning the Planters and Adventurers and Inhabitantes thereof and of the trade and traders to and from thence and of all other thinges whatsoever requisite for the vphoulding, mayntenance, increase and continuance of the same Colony or plantation, trade or traffique which may be necessarye to be inserted in the newe Charter by vs intended to be made for the good of the saide plantation and Colony. And Wee doe hereby signifye and declare that in case you in your proceedinges vpon this Comission shall vpon any question or doubte which shall arise fynde yt requisite to certifie any of your proceedinges and praye ayde from vs or our privye Councell, that then vpon Certificate of such your proceedinges and doubte vnto the Councell boarde from whence Wee may receive information thereof Wee or our privye Councell will give such directions and assistance for further proceedinges in everie such case as shalbe most necessary and convenient. And our further Will and pleasure ys that yf any person or persons shall at any tyme or tymes hereafter be willing to ioyne together in the raysing of any Magazin or ioynte stocke to be sente vnto the saide Colony, that in such case everie such Adventurer soe by your consente and privity adventuring as aforesaide shall have a free voice in the ordering, managing and disposing of such Magazin or jointe stocke or any thing concerning the same. And for your better helpe and assistance in the exacte execution of this our pleasure Wee doe by theise presents gyve vnto you or any such sixe or more of you power and authority to take into your handes and Custody the seales of the Tresorer, Company and Councell of Virginia and to take into your handes and to keepe and peruse all and singuler such Charters, Letters Patentes, grauntes and instructions as have by vs been heretofore made, graunted or given or mentioned to be made, graunted or given to the saide Tresorer and Company or any others concerning the saide Colony and Plantation and all. books, orders, tres aduises and other Writinges and thinges in any Wise concerning the said Colony and Plantation in whose handes soever the same be requiring all persons to deliver the same vnto you whereby you may be the better informed and enabled to proceed in this Worke of soe deepe and great import and consequence Willing and requiring you to be diligent and attendante in the execution of the same And lastly our Will and pleasure is that this our Commission shall continue in force vntill such tyme as Wee by Writing vnder our Signett or privy Seale shall signify our pleasure to the contrary and that you our saide Commissioners shall and may from tyme to tyme proceed in the execution of the same and of all thinges therein conteyned according to the true meanyng thereof although the same be not continued by adjournment In Witnes whereof &c. The Commissioners then appointed their Clerke to attend the Commission; & agreed that Henry Fotherbye who is now secretary to the Barmuda Company should be the Clerke to this Commission. Next they named Thomas Newton to be their Bedle who was their officer before in that place. The place of meeting to be at Sr. Thomas Smiths house. The Days of meeting to be on euery Thursday in the afternoon, at two of the Clocke. That all the Commissioners who are not of the quorum shall be a standing Committee, to prepare businesses for the Commissioners against that day, they or any 6 of them to meet as often as they thinke fit at the place aforesaid. Order is now given that all the Charters, Books and other writings mentioned in the Commission be forthwith brought to this place, and left there in the Custodie of the Clerke for the Commissioners & Committee to use at their pleasure. The Seales of the Company to be likewise delivered in, forthwith to the hands of the Clerke. The Lord President was pleased to undertake that so many of the Charters &c. as are delivered into the Councell Chamber shall be sent to the Commissioners by such Messenger as they shall send for them. It is ordered further. That the Committees against the next Daye of meeting for the Commissions, take into their Consideration the present state of that plantation; and make report thereof on Thursday next. And that the committee shall to that purpose have power to send for all such persons as can give information therein. That the Committee doe also take into their considerations these generall & essentiall things, for the future,
2583:
JULY 16, 1624

1. What supple course is fittest to settle the government there.
2. What supplie is necessary, for the subsistance of the persons nowe inhabiting in that Colony or which shalbe sent theather.
3. What is fitt to be done for the Defence of the Inhabitants against the Savages & others, that they may the better intend their plantation with security.
4. What Commodities can be raised there for the present & what for the future.

My Lord President Delivered nowe into the hands of the Clerke to the Commission 7 pieces: for instruction to the Committees: and for remembrances conducing to these things which are Directed by the Commission.

That there be some publication made in forme heretofore used at the exchange giving notice of his Majesty's Commission, and of his gracious intention thereby; and to notify to all such as have any purpose to goe or send to Virginia that they repaire to the Commissioners & thence receive their Directions as they did before from the company upon all occasions.

It is next ordered that the Committees shall take into their consideration how the plantation nowe stand and how it did stand at the bringing of the quo warrant & what transactions and grants have been made since that time And by whom.

The Commissioners did conceive that there is an absolute grant necessity for the present maintaining of the Plantation by their Tobacco, as the only present means for their Subsistance but as that whereon they will not rest, And that for that purpose there is also a necessity of Present restraining the bringing in of all other Tobacco, of foreign Dominions lest there be so great a glut thereof that it will be afterwards too late to recover that loss: whereby the plantation will be put backe for 2 or 3 years if it be not prevented.

And they have desired my Lord President, to present forthwith their humble desires to his Majesty herein, And it is further ordered that no ship shall goe from hence to Virginia (whereof 2 or 3 are already in Preparation) until a resolution be taken for settling the government there, lest the Report of the Dissolution of the former government might breed a confusion there, before the settling of a new one.
2584:

newe And because these businesses are weightie and require speed the Committees are ordered to meete againe to morrow in the afternoone and soe from Day to day betwene this and Thursday nexte to prepare those things referred vnto them as before, for the resoluéon of the Commissions; And to make such further propositions for the good of the plantation as they can thinke of in the meane time.

James by the grace of God &c. To our trustie and welbeloued Counsellor Sr. Richard Weston knight Chancellor and Vndertrer of our Exchequer; and to the Treasurer Chancellor and Vndertrer of our Exchequer for the time being greeting Whereas John Porye gentleman hath bin imployed by the Lordes of our privy Counsayle into Virginia about our special affaires in which he hath expended the some of one hundred poundes Forasmuche as wee are informed by the Lordes of our said Councell that he hath taken paynes and vsed diligence in our said service and thereupon the said Lordes have thought fitt (if wee shall soe please) that there bee an allowance of one hundred and fiftie poundes made to the said Porye: We will and Commaunde you of our treasure in the receipt of our Exchequer forthwith to paie or cause to bee paied to the said John Porye or his assignes the said some of one hundred and fiftie poundes of lawfull money of England as of our Princely reward for the said service & without account imprest or other Charge to bee sett vpon him or his assignes for the same or for anie part thereof: And these our tres &c Given &c

By order of the LLs of your Ma* Counsell

WINDEBANK

James I. Commission to Sir Francis Wyatt as GOVERNOR AND TO THE COUNCIL IN Virginia! August 26, 1624 Patent Roll, 22 James I, pt. 17, doc. No. 2 Document in Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 720 James by the grace of God King of England Scotland France and Ireland Defender of the faith &c To our Trustie and welbeloved Sir Francis Wyatt knight Francis West Esquier Sir George Yardley knight George Sandys Esquier Roger Smyth Esquier Raph Hamor Esquier John Martin Esquier John Harvey Esquier Samuell Mathewes Esquier Abraham Percey Esquier Isaack Maddison Esquier and William Clayborne Esquier greeting Whereas heretofore at the humble suite of divers our loving subjects intending to deduce a Colonie and to make habitation and plantation of sundry our people in that part of America commonly called Virginia and other parts and territories in America Wee greatly commending and graciously accepting their desires to the furtherance of so noble a work did by our Tres patents in the fourth year of our reign of England grant to divers knights gentlemen and others for the more speedy accomplishment of the said plantation that they should divide themselves into two colonies the one consisting of divers knights gentlemen Merchants and others of our City of London called the first Colonie And the other of sundry knights gentlemen and others of the City of Bristol and Exeter the town of Plymouth and other places called the second Colonie. And wee did by the same Tres patents grant that the said Colonies might make their plantations and habitations in certain places in the same tres patents expressed, And that the said Colonies should have divers lands grounds havens ports ' See Chancery Warrants, Series II, 1978. The Privy Seal, delivered 26 August, 1624, is the warrant for the Great Seal to these letters patent.
2586: 502 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY commodities and hereditaments and divers privileges and liberties for the quiet settling and good government in the said plantations. In and by which tres patents wee did alsoe declare our pleasure that wee our heires and successors should from tyme to tyme ordavne and give such further * * * instructions lawes constitutions and ordinances for the better rule and government of such as soe should make plantation there as to vs our heires and successors should from tyme to tyme be thought convenient, And whereas wee according to the effect and true meaning of the said tres patents did by several res under our privie seale prescribe and ordinances and constitutions: for the directing and ordering of the affaires of the said first Colonie And whereas afterward vppon the petition [etc. etc. as in the recitals to No. CDLXI (List of Records No. 701), almost word for word, but omitting some phrases, the correct date (7 Jas. I) being given for the Charter of Incorporation.] * * * * * * give orders yet the least delay might prove dangerous to the said Colonies and Plantations yf during the tyme of this deliberation they shoulde want direction and government for the better progression, therefore to the effecting of this our royall pleasure wee by our commission under our great seale of England bearing date the fifteenth day of July in the yeare of our raigne of England France and Ireland the two and twentieth and of Scotland the seven and fiftieth did give power and authoritie vnto our right trustie and right welbeloved Cousin and Counsellor Henry Viscount Mandevill lord President of our Councell and divers others of our privie Counsell and others to treate consult and consider of all matters whatsoever concerning the said Colonie and plantation as well for the safetie of our people there strength of the place and government to be exercised there as for mannaging of the business and affaires thereof here in England and to execute and perform divers other things conducing therevnto in such sorte as by our said Commission may at large appeare In the execution of which our Commission our said Commissioners have already made some good beginning and have given vs this humble advise That by a like Commission from vs wee should appoint and authorise such other discreet persons residing in the parts of Virginia as wee shoulde thinke fitt to be our Resident Councell for the ordering mannaging and governing of the affaires of that Colonie and plantation and of the persons there already inhabiting or which hereafter shalbe or inhabite there.

503 until some other constant and setled course be resolved upon and established by us, Know ye therefore that we reposing assured trust and confidence in the understanding care fidelity experience and circumspection of you the said Sir Francis Wyatt Francis West Sir George Yardeley George Sandys Roger Smyth Raph Hamor John Martin John Harvey Samuell Matthewes Abraham Percey Isaacke Madison and Willm Clayborne have nominated and assigned and do hereby nominate and assign you the said Sir Francis Wyatt to be the present Governour and you and the said Francis West Sir George Yardeley and the rest before mentioned to be our present Councell of and for the said Colony and plantation in Virginia giving and granting unto you and the greater number of you by these presents respectively full power and authority to perform and execute the places powers and authorities incident to a governour and Councell in Virginia respectively and to direct and govern correct and punish our subjects now inhabiting or being or which hereafter shall inhabit or be in Virginia or in any the Isles ports havens Creeks or territories thereof either in time of peace or Warre and to order and direct the affairs touching or concerning that Colony or plantation in those foreign parts only and do execute and perform all and every other matters and things concerning that Plantation as fully and amply as any Governor and Councell resident there at any time within the space of five years now last past had or might perform or execute. Nevertheless our Will and pleasure is that Ye proceed therein according to such instructions as ye or such of you as have been heretofore of our Councell there have received or according to such instructions as you shall hereafter receive from us or our Commissioners here to that purpose or intent. And our further pleasure is that we do hereby give power and authority and do will and command that you the said Sir Francis Wyatt Francis West Sir George Yardley George Sandys Roger Smyth Raphe Hamor or any two of you who have already been of our Councell in those parts for the Plantation there shall minister unto the said John Martin John Harvey Samuell Mathewes Abraham Percy Isaacke Maddison and William Clayborne and every of them the like oath upon the holy Evangelist as ye or any of you have already taken as Counsellor of or for the said Colony or plantation Willing and requiring you to be diligent and attendant in the execution of this our service and commandment and also willing

At the same tyme there was a new offer made by dyuers honest Men for the good of the Plantation and presented to Mr. Solicitor the 28th of October 1624:

The new offer is

That they will make good to the Kinge yearely for the 2: first yeares a Reuenew of fifteene thowsand pound for his Maiestyes owne vse and the Plantations and the third yeare twentye thowsand pounds and then to bee on either parte at libertye.

That all the Tobaccos of the Plantations shall be sould absolutly to the most aduantage to the vse and benifite of the Planter and Owner and a good accoumpt giuen quarterly of itt.

That the Rewardes of those Men that take these paines and spend theyr tyme to doe this good Worke and to preserue the Plantations from Ruine shall be: 2500 li: whereas the other Contractors will haue at least twenty thowsand pound a yeare it may bee: 30, or: 40: thowsand

That if any doe like this other Contract of Mr. Dichfeilds and had rather have it upon the Conditions of that Contract they shall haue itt.
