CDLXVIII. Council in Virginia. Letter To THE Earl of SOUTHAMPTON AND THE COUNCIL AND COMPANY OF VIRGINIA

DECEMBER 2, 1624

(1) Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, p. 11a. (2) C. O, 1, Vol. III, No. 30 Document in (1) Library of Congress, Washington, D. C.; (2) Public Record Office, London, Document signed List of Records No. 748 1624, Dec. 2.

Right Honorable: We have Received Letters from the Lords of his majesty's most Honorable privy Council of especial recommendation in the behalf of Capt John Martine, dated the xixth of December, 1623. Accompanied with yours of the first of February, to the same effect, which, by divers reports and rumors since his arrival by him raised he hath little deserved at your hands, Notwithstanding in obedience to their and your Lordships' Letters, We have and are ready to give our best assistance to the accommodation of his business, Whereof, when it shall be finished (wherein we will use our best expedition) We will give you A particular Account.

As for Order Concerning the Widow Smaley, we had received none, till the Receipt of your last Letters, she herself as yet is not arrived in Virginia, but remains in New England, nor hath appointed any to Solicit her cause, But at her arrival she shall find all lawful favor.

It hath pleased God this year to give us a great Victory over Otiotan & the Pomunkeys, with their Confederates, by a handful, being in all not above 60 fighting men (whereof 24 were employed only in the Cutting down of Corn) Conducted by the Governor, in which was showed what the Indians could do, having maintained fight two days together, and much thereof in open field, The young men being beaten up by the elder, Many slain, and as much Corn cut down, as by the Estimation of men of good Judgment, Was Sufficient to have Sustained four Thousand men for a Twelve month, who were so discouraged, that they gave over fighting and dismayedly, stood most ruefully looking on while their Corn was Cut down, And had we been well furnished with powder,
2592:
508 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

The Gouernor had proceeded further to Matepany River, whereby he had hazarded the Starvinge of all those nations. In this expedition sixteen of the English were hurt, the first and second day whereby nine of the best shott were made unserviceable for that time, yet never a man slayne, nor none that miscarried of those hurts (since when they have not greatly troubled us, nor interrupted our Labors). The Indians were never known to show so great resolution, either encouraged by the paucity of ours, or their own great numbers, there being of the Pomunckeys eight hundred bowmen, besides divers nations that came to assist them, fighting not only for safeguard of their houses and such a huge quantity of Corn, but for their reputation with the rest of the Salvages: which we now hope they have lost, it depending much upon the success of this Action. The Pomunckeys having made great braggs, of what they would do, Among the Northern nations: of whom the king of Potuxsone sent an Indian unto us expressly to be an eye witness of the event. If our store of powder had been answerable to our intentions and readiness, we had gone upon our neighboring Indians, although we understand, that they have quitted their former Plantations by the harsh visits, which they received from us the former Summer, and as we conceive did much rely upon relief from the Pomunckeys, who therefore planted the greater quantity. Our powder is now so far exhausted, that we shall not be able to maintain our Plantations, should they make any attempt upon us, if shortly a supply come not in, it being now the second of December and no ship heard of, a thing unaccustomed, and for many reasons doth put us to many perplexities. We therefore earnestly desire that if powder be not already sent according to our former Letters, that order be taken for the sending thereof with the greatest Celerity, that possible may be. This Summer, God be thanked, the Colony hath very well stood to health: which assureth us that the mortality of former years, is to be imputed to other accidents, and not to the Climate. And among so many of his benefits God hath sent us a plentiful harvest of Corn and the industrious are well stored with other provisions, such that excepting the number of men the Colony hath worn out the Scars of the massacre, and if in any thing it come short in many things it exceeds the former Condition.
2593:
JANUARY 10, 1624/5

Thus humbly desiring your former favor and fervency in the Support of this Action and the settling of our estate much shaken by rumor, which hath bred a general irresolution among us, we humbly take our leaves and remain

Your devoted Servants  
Fra: Wyatt  
FFRA: WEST  
GORGE YARDLEY  
GEORGE SANDYS  
JO POTT  
ROGER SMITH

CDLXX. Sir George Yeardley. Answer of Defendant to the Demand of Captain John Martin

February 4, 1624/5

C. O. 1, Vol. III, No. 36, Document in Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 753

The Answer of Sir George Yeardley Knight Defendant to the Demands of Capt. John Martin Esquire Complainant whereby he requireth recompence of wrong done him.

To the first, the said defendant saith that he never knew that Mr. Whittakers had at any time any Corne of the said Complainant; but saith that Mr. Whittakers intestate he the said Defendant being then Deputy Governor of Virginia required one Thomas Hobson, who belonged to Mr. Whittakers and was as his Sonne and Child kept by him in his life time, to take an Inventorie of all such goods and provisions as were then to be found in the said Mr. Whittakers house and them to take into his safe custodie that if afterward there did appear any to whom the goods might more rightly

[A pencilled note in the margin reads: “Wanting, N.B. See [S.P.] Dom. Car. I Vol. I No. 122 1.”]

[Written by a very careless scribe.]
2595: FEBRUARY 4, 1624/5 511 belong he should be accomptable for them. and the said Defendant saith there was as farr as he remembreth found in the said house of Corne tenn barrells of Eares which he verily beleeveth was the said Mr. Whittakers owne Corne which Corne was afterwarde disposed of and spent by the said Tho: Hobson in the feeding of himself, Jarrett Holloek, John Flood and one Ruben all of them servants to the said Mr. Whittakers. And saith further that after the arivall of Sr. Samuell Argall who succeeded the said Defendant in the Goverment of Virginia there came into this Colony a sister of Mr. Whittakers who made enquiry after the goods of her deceased brother but found that he left little of value behind him. at that time also was the said Complaynant here in this Contrie who no doubt if he had then complayned to Sr. Samuell Argall and could haue made proof that the said Corne had any waise belonged unto him he might then haue recouered the same. for the Corne was at that time very little thereof spent. if he did not then complaine or had not justice don him therein the said Defendant saith itt was no fault of his. To the second the said Defendant saith that he doth remember one Pope whoe served in his Shipp as Cooke enterteyned for that purpose by James Brett Mr. of his said Shipp and went also for England as he remembreth therein but whether the said Pope were servant to the Complaynant or was runn away from him the said defendant knoweth not. and doth further protest and wilbe redy to be Sworne that the said Complaynant never at any time to his rememberance spake to the said Defendant of or concerning the said Pope nor that ever he so much as heard say that the said Pope was runn away from the said Complaynant. To the Third the Defendant saith that with his knowledg or by any Warrant or allowance of his there were never any kine or Calves taken from the said Complaynant to the use of Mr. Bargraue as he suggesteth and therefore the said Defendant deemeth the said Complaynant to be much mistaken in demanding allowance for any such kine or Calves from him the said Defendant. To the fourth the said Defendant saith that he was never acquainted that the Complaynant had hired any of Capt. Stallinges men neither did he ever heare say that the said Complaynant had hired any one or more of them.
2596: 512 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY but saith that at his arrivall to be Governor of Virginia he found ridinge at Anchor in this River A shipp wch the said Defendant was given to vnderstand belonged to Sr. Ferdinando Gorges Knight the said Stallinge being Capt thereof wch said Shipp soone after the arrivall of the said Defendant was by the negligence of the said Stallinge and Company belongeinge to her suffered to breake from her Anchor and in the night to run a ground at a place called Bowiers bay the said Stallinge the next day came to the said Defendant and did intreat for help to gett of the said Shipp whereupon the said Defendant saith he lent the said Stallinge the long Boat of the Diana with twelve of her best men to help of the said Shipp. but before they could gett her afloat they were forced to vnlade much of her provisions and goods and by the direccion of the said Stallinge to carry them on Shoar vppon the South side of the River and afterward with great labor brought the said Shipp into Southampton River where the said Stallinge very negligently left her with only a boy to poump out the watter. the said Shipp being extreamly leaky by reason of the great hurt shee tooke in running one ground at Bowiers Bay and he the said Stallinge tooke all the rest of the Marine and Company to row him and some others vp the river where in his way putting ashore at a place called Dancinge Point, he happned to be slayne after whose death his Company went vpp with their boatt vnto the said Complaynants Plantacion the said Defendant being then above at Charles hundred bussied about the publique affaires of the Collony. the said Complaynant wrot vpp to him and certified him of the death of the said Stillinge and howe that his men and boatt weare at the said Complaynants Plantacion whereupon the said Defendant vnderstanding the misaccident of the said Stallinges Death and howe also that the said Shipp was left by him in doubt of perishing and that divers of the goods and provisions belonging to her were left one shore by the said Stallinge in hazard of the Indians whereby Sr. Ferdinando Gorges owner of the said Shipp might be much prejudiced he the said Defendant forthwith in consideration thereof gave Warrant vnto Capt Georg Bargrave and one John Damerin to take the said Stallinges men and boatt and to go downe to Rieoughtun and taking Capt Tucker, then Comander there to assist them to make a true Inventorie of all the goods and provisions belongeinge to the said shipp and also with the said Boat and Company to seek and bring together all things whatsoever that belonged
2597:
FEBRUARY 4, 1624/5

to the said Shipp and were by the said Stallinge left ouer Shore vppon the South side of the River at Newporte Newes or any other place and them to see laid vpp in some House or Store where they might be preserved for the vse of the said Sr. Ferdinando Gorge of wch his proceeding the said Defendant saith he gaue notice by letters vnto the said Sr. Ferdinando intreatinge him to appoint and send over some one whoe might receiue them to his vse wh afterward the said Sr. Ferdinando did and gaue great thankes to the said Defendant for his care and paines taken therein and for that also the said Defendant had employed his owne people and boate in helping to bring the goods together wch not long after were delivered vnto one Ellis Cornish substituted by the said Sr. Ferdinando as doth appeare by a receipt vnder the hand of the said Ellis wch the said Defendant hath to showe. And the said Defendant saith that the goods of the said shipp being once thus laid vpp as aforesaid he gaue license vnto the said Shippe Companye to dispose of themselues for their owne best profit where and in what place they thought good some of whom soone after shipped themselues for England others for Canada. One only whose name was Stoake entertained himself for the publique service of the Collony. Moreover the said Defendant saith that he was not at all acquainted that the said Complainant had hired any one or more of them to serve him either as his servant or Tenant and saith that the said Complainant did never give him any notice of any such agreement nor did then or after require of him that they might fulfill any Covenant or agreement made. So that he verily believeth that there was not any Covenant made at all between the said Complainant and the said Shipps Company. And further saith that if any such thinge were done by the said Complainant as to hire into his service the said Shippe Company for the planting of Tobacco at such a time when their Capt was newly slaine and the Shipp and goods like to be vtterly lost, that there was little respect had by the said Complainant to the damage that might therevppon ensue vnto the said Sr. Ferdinando Gorge in the losse of his Shipp and goods wch Shipp notwithstanding that all the care was taken that the said Defendant could devise for the speedy sendinge to her succor was sunke in the River ere the boat could get downe. And the said Defendant further saith that if any bargaine or agreement had been made between the said Complainant and the said Shippe Company that had beene lawfull he doubteth not but the said...
2598:
514 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

Complaynant would haue requyred iustice at that time that it might haue beene performed the which thinge he never did either by word or writing. To the fifth the said Defend[ant] saith that soone after his arivall to be Governor having occasion for the publique service to employ Ensigne Savage as an Interpreter he sent for him to the Complaynant at whose Plantation he then lived and saith that after the said Ensignes returne, the like occasion required the sendinge of him againe but saith that I was not acquainted by the said Complaynant that the said Ensigne was his hired servant neither did the said Complaynant require the said Ensigne to be sent home againe, nor did the said Defend[ant] knowe that the said Complaynant had any occasion to employ the said Ensigne to go abroad in his Shallopp, and saith further that he did not vnderstand that the said Ensigne was servant to the said Complaynant or any man else but as a publique Interpreter. Yet saith that if the said Complaynant had desired to haue made vse of the said Ensigne and had acquainted him the said Defend[ant] therewith he beleeueth he should have beene redy to haue showed him curtisie therein for at that time and afterward the said Defendant did vnto the said Complaynant many speciall fauors with, as he thinketh the said Complaynant wilbe redye to acknowledg one among the rest being the lending of him Corne when both he and his people relied very great necessitie. And saith [3] further that he knoweth not nor doth beleeue that the said Complaynant had at that time whilest the said Ensigne was employed by the said Defendt for the publique service of the Collony any intent to send forth his Shallopp one tradinge for that his Cropp must haue spoiled on the ground in the absence of his people. To the sixth the Defendant saith that the said Complaynant was sent for to James Cittie by the Generall Assemblie who writt him a very courteous letter to that effect the Copie whereof the said defendant hath to show their desire to commune with him as by the iornall of the generall Assemblie will appeare was for that he sent from his plantation two Burgesses to sitt in the Assembly and to haue their voices there in the makeinge of lawes and orders for the good and peaceable governing of the Collony unto which lawes they the said Burgesses would not assure the said Assembly that the said Defendant or any of the people that lived under his Command would be obedient unto, but that he the said Complaynant would notwithstanding.
2599:
FEBRUARY 4, 1624/5

any lawes that should be made there, govern and Command by the authoritie of his private Pattent and strictly stand vppon the privileges thereof, vnder the protection of wth said Pattent it was well known to the Assemblie that there lived at his plantacion diuers bankrouts and indebted persons with others of evill fame which said persons the said Complaynant had and hath diuers times protected against the authoritie of the publique officers of this Collony and would not suffer them to be arrested for their debte but hath Comanded the sayd publique officers to depart his teritorie, threatninge them otherwise to lay them Neck and heeles. whereof the said publique officers haue complayned to the said Defendent as he will be Sworn and could haue otherwise more strongly prooved if the said officers were now alive. by wth the said Complaynant opposicion and resistance, the Cape Marchant of the ould Magazine hath beene forced to stay for the depte of the said Magazine, as himself beinge now here is able to wittnes. Another reason of the Generall Assemblies sendinge for the said Complaynants to Commune wth him might be and was concerninge an outrage done by some of the said Complaynants people to Certaine Indians in the Bay wth whom wee were in league and peace, in takeing away by violence from them a certain quantitie of Corne at which act it seemed to the assemblie the said Complaynant conived, and Complaint being thereof made to the said Defendent by Opachankan, whoe also was Complayned vnto by the Kinge on the Eastren shore to whom those people and the foresaid corn belonged, that satisfaction might be made the said Assemblie thinking the same but reason resolued to moue the said Complaynant therein. To the seventh the Defendent saith that vppon the Day of the massacre the said Defendent going vpp in his shipp toward Flowerdieu hundred and the tide takeinge him short about Capt Sand's his plantation he manned his Shipps boatt and went on shore to search if any of the people might haue lyen wounded whome he might haue saved and recovered. but searching the ground and findinge none it groweing toward night he retired to his Shipp purposeing to send downe his boat the next day to haue saued the Corne which lay in Capt Sand's his house with any other goods wth might haue been found of worth to haue beene brought thence the necessitie and danger of the Defendent's own plantation nott permitting at that time his longer stay.
2600:
516 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

there, but the next day he had certaine newes that the houses and all things else therein were burnt. He also saith that he doth not know of any thing that brought thence save some poulterie from the roust at one Taylor's house a dweller there, together with a Sow which he the said Defendant gave unto the Master of his said Shipp upon his request thereof as also one Chest wherein as near as he can remember was about sixty weight of very ill conditioned Tobacco which he the said Defendant bestowed upon the Marriners purposing to pay for the said Sow and Tobacco which he the said Defendant might as he thought well doe in regard the said Capt Sand's dyed indebted to him the sum of Eighteen pounds starlinge as will appeare by a bill of the sayed Capt Sand's hand which the said Defendant hath to show. He saith also that the Marriners did throw some smale trompery into the boat things of little or no value the Indians having carried away all other things as it should seeme by their strowing of old Chests and barrells about the field but whether there were at the said Capt Sand’s Plantation any goods at all belonging to the said Complaynant the said Defendant saith he knew not nor did he see or perceive that anything was brought thence by any of his people save one young Calf which dyed in the Shipp and was throwne overbord before he got up to Flowerdieu Hundred. And farther saith that if the said Complaynant can prove that any thing was by him the said Defendant or by any other with his allowance brought thence he will be ready to make sufficient satisfaction for the same to the right owners thereof. Moreover the said Defendant saith that he hath heard that none of the goods of the said Complaynant were at the Plantation of the said Capt Sand's but were left by him the said Complaynant at his departure for England in his own dwelling houses which were about a mile distant from the said Plantation. And where the said Defendant saith that neither he nor any of his people ever came at that time or since the Massacre and therefore the said Complaynant shall doe him wrong if he accuse him of bringing any thing thence where neither he nor any of his came. To the eighth the Defendant saith that until this time he never heard of any such thing but saith that he hath lately spoken with Ensigne Chaplaine and then certified him of this demand of the Complaynant who told him the whole tale his oath. 

1 Sic. 2 Torn away.
2601:
FEBRUARY 4, 1624/5

517

him and the said Complaynant that two kine should be delivered to the said Ensigne for satisfaction of the said Complaynant's bond. and said that he never demanded any kine of Capt Saund's nor did Capt Sande's at any time make proffer to deliver him any whereby it is not likely that the said Defend' did command Capt Saund's the contrary. To the Nynth and last the Defendt saith that vntill this time he never heard of any such thinge but saith that Lieutenant Peppett beinge now in this Cittie it may please the Governor and Counsell to examine him thereof. Extr. op JOHN: SOUTHORNE

CDLXANI. Councii in Virginia.

A Letter to the VIRGINIA COMPANY of LONDON

February 4, 1624/5

(1) C. O. 1, Vol. III, No. 36. (2) Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. i, p. 12 Document in (1) Public Record Office, London; (2) Library of Congress, Washington, D.C, List of Records No. 755

Right Honorable:

Accordinge to your Lordships: Comaundes, we haue now sent you the particulars of our proceedings and orders, since vppon the Complaynt of Capt John Martine against Sr. George Yeardley, and alsoe for the Cattle in question between him and Capt Bargroue, so far as concernes the Possession, not the right and propertie, which as it appeares, is a Controversie yett dependinge in England, in the High Courte of Chauncerye.

We have been readye to yeelde him all lawfull favor for the settlinge of him at his Plantatione, which his owne disabilities hath hindered. We cannot but praise your Charitie in forgivinge and forgettinge those many and fowle iniuryes, whereof he hath boasted, yett holde it our duties to informe you how much you are mistaken in him and what he hath retributed for so greate a favor, beinge besides his many slaunders, whereof we send you some particulars vnder oath, A sower of disentione and diso-
2602:
518 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

obedienc amongste us, which as yett we have not questioned, owt of respect to the Lres from the Lo:ds of his Ma:ties most Honorable privy Counsell, as also from your selves, and resolve nott to doe vnles greate necessitie Compell us. The rather because, beinge a man of soe light repute and Creditt in the Colony where he hath been soe longe discovered and knowne, we hope yt ye venome that pceeds from him, will pduce noe dangerous Effect. We cannott but be Seneyble how much the obedienc to us vppon wch the well managinge of yo:r affayers depends, hath beene shaken and weakened, ffirste by the Rumors spread and raysed at the Cominge in of the Comissioners, now renewed and revived by Capt. Martin and must forsee how much the Plantation and our good opinions wth you are likly to suffer by false suggestiones wch only receaue their strength by our beinge soe farr from answere. Thus recomendinge both to yo:r noble Patronage Wee humbly take our leaves & remaine Att your Comandes

James Cyttie the 4th of Februarie 1624

Francis Wyatt
Frans West
George Yeardley
George Sandys
John Pott
Roger Smyth
Ralph Hamor
2603:
APRIL (?), 1625

519 CDLXXII. Virginia Company. Discourse of THE OLD Company April (?), 1625

C. O. 1, Vol. III, No. 40 Document in Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 758

May it please your Loᵈˢ

When last wee attended this Honourable Board, yoᵘ Loᵈˢ required two preeferent things at our hands, to be presented this day in writing to yoᵘ Loᵈˢ. Was!

The first, our opinion touching the best forme of Gouernement, to be here established for yᵉ affaires of Virginia.

The second, an offer to be made for such a Contract touching Tobacco wᵗʰ his Maᵗʸ as might both vphold his former Revenue, and not be grievous to the Plantations.

Concerning the former of wᵗ propositions, wee humbly craue leave thus much to deliver wᵗʰout offence, that it came alltogether vnexpected to vs: who brought wᵗʰ vs a strong & confirmed resoluēon, not to entermedle any more in the busines of Virginia, so foyled & wronged by the partie opposite, & now reduced to extreame termes allmost past recovery and wherein all our former labours, cares, & expences, had receaved by the practise & procurement of these men, the vndeserved reward of rebuke & disgrace.

Notwstandinge in due obedience vnto yoᵘ Loᵈˢ Commānd, whom wee haue allwayes found iust & honoᵘʳᵇˡᵉ, (and if happily some good may redound thereby to that now distressed and languishing Plantation, wᶜʰ hath bin heretofore so deare vnto vs, and wᶜʰ gaue so great hope of honour to this Kingdome, & might haue bin in these tymes of warlike preparations, of so great vse & service to his Maᵗʸ, if it had bin so cherished & strengthened by these men, as when they gayned the governemᵗ, they pretended & promised, wee wished and desired): Wee here present in all humblenes our deliberate opinion touching yᵉ forme of Governemᵗ now fittest to be established, for yᵉ restoring & reviving of that Plantation, if it be possible yet to be recovered. Wherein wee thinke it requisite, that yoᵘ Loᵈˢ in

1 In pencil.
2604:
520 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

the first place be truly informed, of the state of that Colony, what before it was, and what now it is, according unto the best advertisements from thence received. The Plantation now in Virginia, began about the yeare 1606 & continued about Twelue yeares under the Government of the selfe same handes, whereinto it was first intrusted by the late Kings Maᵗʸ, the most Royall founder of this Noble worke. The perticular carriages of this first Government, are too long, & would bee too displeasing to your Loᵈˢʰᵖˢ cares. But in Generall such it was, as the new Earle of Midd. then Lo: high Treasurer (being an ancient Adventurer & Councellor for Virginia) informed your Loᵈˢʰᵖˢ, sitting in Counsell the 5ᵗʰ of March 1622 when he told Alderman Johnson, That in former yeares, when he the said Alderman was Deputie, and the busines was in other handes, it was carried leaudly, so that if they should be called to an accompt for it, their Estates would not answere it. What his Loᵈˢʰᵖ delivered as his owne Censure, was truly the opinion of the whole Company of Adventurers here in England. And with them doth the Colonie concurre, having the last yeare by their Viceadmirall sent a writing signed by the hands of the Generall Assembly, & directed to his Maᵗʸ, wherein having declared, the manner of those Twelue yeares Government, they conclude with these words, full of passionate griefe: Iud rather then to be reduced to live under the like Government, wee desire his Maᵗʸ that Comissioners may be sent over with authoritie to hang vs. Of this qualitie was the first Government. And answerable to the Forme, were the Effects, as the Generall Assemblie having by oath examined the perticulers, sett downe in their Declaration directed to his late Maᵗʸ, 1. For People then alive about the number of 400, 2. Very many of them in want of Corne, utterly destitute of Cattle, Swine, Poultry, and other provisions to nourish them. 3. As for Fortification against a forraigne enimy, there was none at all, only foure peeces mounted, but altogether unserviceable.
2605:
APRIL 4, 1625

1. There was onely eight Plantations, all wch were but poorely housed, and as ill fortified against the Savages.  
2. Onely one old Friggott belonging to the Summer Islands, one Shallop, one Shipboate, and two small boats belonging to private men.  
3. Three Ministers in orders, & Two without.  
4. No Comoditie on foote save Tobacco.  
5. The Indians in doubtfull Termes.  

This as they report was the true estate of the Plantations at the Twelve years end. To wch being added the other condition of the Colonie, wch in other writings they expresse:  

1. That they either lived or rather suffered under Martiall Lawe:  
2. Under a most extorting Governour there, whom by 24 bundles of depositions they have accused of strange depredations:  
3. Under most oppressive orders hence, to the breach of all faith & honesty:  
4. Without comfort of Wives or servants:  
5. Without assurance of their Estates:  
6. There being no Dividents of land laid out:  
7. Without assurance of their Liberties, being violently detained as servants beyond their Covenanted times:  

Wee may truly affirme, that the intentions of the people then in Virginia, were no wayes to settle there as a Colonie, but to gett a little wealth by Tobacco, then in price, and so to returne for England. As for the Adventurers here, the greatest part were long before beaten out as from an hopeless Action. In wch regard there was fifteen thousand pounds detained of mens subscriptions, wch by no means they could bee procured to pay in; sundry of them alleaging in their answers in Chauncery upon their oathes, the misimployment of the monyes, & ill keeping of the Accounts. Those few that followed the busines, upon some hope to reforme it, were (by the Governours here, for their owne particular ends as is conceived, for to their private benefitt it was only sutable.) directed to bestow their monyes in Adventuring by way of Magazine, upon two Commodities only, Tobacco & Sassafras, matters of present proffitt, but no wayes fit foundations of a future State. Soe that of a merchantlike Trade there was some probability, at least for a while: but of a Plantation...
2606:
522 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

there was none at all, neither in the courses, nor in the intentions, either of the Adventurers here, or of the Colonie there. In this Estate & condition was the Action left by the First, to the Second Government which began in the yeare 1619 by the choice of Sr. Edwin Sandis for Treasurer. To whom the yeare following succeeded the Earle of Southampton. Vnder whose Government by Gods blessing, the Plantation, so prospered, as by the end of the yeare 1621 the number of people was increased there, to be about Two thousand. 

2. The number of Neat Cattle, besides Goates & Swyne, Eight hundred. 

3. The number of Housing was proportionably increased, and the manner of building much bettered. 

4. The number of Boates was Ten times multiplied: And which was much more, there were Fower Shippes belonging to the Colonie. 

5. There were sent more than eight able Ministers. 

6. With great care & cost there were procured men skillful in Sawing-Milles from Hambrough. 

7. Vignerons from Languedoc: In divers places of the Colonie, Vineyards begunne, some of them containing Ten thousand plants: 

8. Store of Silkeworme-seed sent: 

9. And the Iron-workes brought after Five thousand pounde expenses to that assured perfection, as within Three months they promised to send home great Quantities, 

10. Many new Plantations were made: 

11. All men had sufficiency of Corne: 

12. And many Great plenty of Cattle, Swyne & Poultry, & other good provisions. 

13. The mortality which had reigned the two first yeares, (at that time was general over all America) was at last ceased. 

14. So that by this sudden & unexpected advancement of the Plantation in these things, together with the redress of all former Grievances: Supplies of young women for wives, & of youths for servants being sent them: 

15. The bloody Lawes being silenced, & their Government ordered like to that of this Kingdome:
2607:
APRIL, 1625

16. Provisions being made for the maintenance of Officers, that they should not need to prey upon the people: And the like done for the Ministers:

17. The liberty of a Generall Assembly being granted them, whereby they find out, & execute those things, as might best tend to their good:

18. The estates of Land by just Dividents being surely conveyed:

19. A Free Trade from hence for all sorts of people being permitted, whereby they were even to superfluity furnished with all necessaries:

The Colony grew into an opinion, that they were the happiest people in the world: Which meeting here at home with the experience of most Noble demeanor on the Companies part, against which Envy itself could not find any shadow of Calumny or offence: the reputation of this Action grew to such a height, as not only the old Adventurers renewed their zeal of their first Loves, but great numbers of new came daily in with assurance to expend large sums in the business. And for the Plant's to go in person, not only here at home Thousands of choice people offered themselves: but out of Ireland went divers Ships, & more were following:

Three hundred Families French & Dutch in the year 1621 made request to the State, that they might plant in Virginia: whither not long before, Condemned persons had refused to go with pardon of their Lives.

The great amendment in this and in all other parts of this Action, made the Earle of Middlesex say at your hono[r] Board, That in these latter times the Plantation by the good carriage had thriven and prospered beyond belief, and almost miraculously.

This we cannot but esteem an hon[orable] testimony proceeding from our most heavy Enemy, who had himself laid in the way so many great Rubbs & Difficulties, as he might well say, It was by miracle we over passed them.

The first year, directly against his Ma[jes]ties Letters Patents, and consequently against Law, by the judgment of the then Attorney General, exceedingly over burdening our Commodity:

The second year, to the Kings great damage, & abuse of the whole kingdom, procuring an utter banishment of our Tobacco:
2608:
524 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

And the third yeare, enforcing vs to bring all in, only to the enrichment of his private friends. But besides these, wee were continually strugling with a most malicious faction within our owne Body here, besides that vniuersall sickenes abroad in the Colony mentioned before: Yet through all these Difficulties did wee wrestle by Gods blessing, with the expence of lesse then fower & twenty thousand poundes of the Publique stock. For howsoeuer yoᵘ Lorᵈs haue beene enformed, the very truth which wee shall alwayes make good, is, that there was not receaved from the Lotteries in the tyme of this latter Governemᵗ, any more then Twenty one thousand Seaven hundred Sixty six poundes, Nyne shillings Two pence. By the expence of which some, together with about Three thousand pounds receaved from the Collections, wee brought the Colony to those Termes wee haue related. And if in yoᵘ Declaration sent to his Maᵗᶦᵉ the last yeare, the Colony haue made a right & perfect Calculation, wee affirme vnto yoᵘ Lorᵈs that in yoᵘ first Three yeares of this latter Governement, the Company sent as many Shipps in Nomber, but of greater burthen; As many people in nomber, but much better provided, as were sent in the first Twelue yeares. Yet had the latter Governemᵗ vnder Twenty fower Thousand poundes, and Sr Thomas Smith receaved above Three score and fifteene thousand poundes of publique Stock. Soe that wee may truly affirme, through Gods blessing, with a Third part of the mony, and in a fourth part of yoᵘ tyme, wee brought the Plantation to [these] foure tymes the number of Men that Sr Thomas Smith left it in, and in all other parts incomparably better.

The Plantation being growne to this height by the end of yoᵘ yeare 1621 it pleased God in his seerett judgement to giue leaue to yoᵘ enemies thereof, by many powerfull & most wicked meanes, to bring it downe agayne to yoᵘ ground. The first Blowe was a most bloudy Massacre, when by the Treacherous cruelty of the Savages, about 400 of our People were slayne; vpon the 22ᵈ of March 1621. The terror whereof with the losse of much Cattle and other Substance, and on sodayne alteration of the state of all thinges, so dismaide the whole Colony, as they almost gaue themselues for gone. But then appeared both the love of the Company to the Plantation, & their great abilitie to goe through therewith: when in supply of this Losse, and for yoᵘ encouragement of the Colony, they did send that yeare to Virginia 16 Ships.
2609: APRIL 15, 1622. 525 & 800 people, and that altogether at the charges of private Adventurers. For the publick Stock being utterly exhaust the yeare before, was not able to contribute 500 li. toward all this charge. But this cruell Tragedy of the Massacre, was seconded by Two other sharpe Calamities in the very neck one of another: First Scarcity in the Colony by being putt off from their Grounds prepared, together with the losse of their season & much seed; besides that, through the troublesomnes of those tymes, they could not freely inploy themselves in planting thereof, no not in those their scant grounds, many Plantations being drawne into few places for their better defence. The pestering of themselves, did likewise breed Contagious sicknesse; which being increased by the Infection brought in by some shipps, there dyed that yeare of Mortality neere upon 600 more: and the Colony passed much hardnesse in their victuall, by reason of the miscarriage of one of their Shippes, which the Company sett forth with above 500 li. worth of Meale and other provisions: But the Shipp being blowne up with Powder at the Summer Islandes, the Provisions were lost, & never came to Virginia. Notwithstanding these things were most grievous to the Company here; yet were they no wayes of Discouragement, but rather seemed to add heat to their former zeale: so as by the beginning of the yeare 1623 there appeared in readines & preparation to goe to Virginia, double that number of people, & Adventurers, that any former yeare had carried. When on sodayne the Plantation itselfe was by Captaine Butler in a certayne writing Intituled, The vnmasking of Virginia, so fowly discredited, and the present miseries thereof so farr amplified above Truth, and the future hopes thereof so belowe all good meaning derided & vilified by divers ill willers of the Action, especially some discontented members of the Company, as the greatest part of the intended Supplies for New Plantations, gave over, as some of themselves will testify to your Lordship. Yet notwithstanding, the vnited Body of the Company, did even that yeare 1623 send out Eleven shipps, stored with supplies of victuall & provisions: although by many cruell Encounters of the Opposites, they were sore hindred and deiected, directly with Intention to make them abandon the busines. But the welfare of the Plantation, and the maintenance of their...
2610:
526 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

owne honour & credit, did prevaile so with the Company, that though with the certainty of their owne extreame losse, they passed in the aboundance of Supply, not only the necessities of the Colony, but even the vnreasonable demande of their Opposites: havinge in fower dayes space that was given them after the notice of the Colonies want, procured the vnderwriting of Fower thousand pounds Adventure: which the Honorable Board of the privy Counsell was pleased with much Noble favour highly to approve. As for the people that went that yeare in those Eleaven ships, the nomber was not above 260: and those procured not without difficulty, so much had the disgrace of the Plantation spread amongst the Common sort of people: Neither could it be prevented by the Companie, although they vsed all possible dilligence: soliciting the Comissioners then appointed by his Majestie by a publick Examination of Captayne Butlers reporte, to cleare the truth. But they would by no meanes bee drawne therevnto. As for the Companie it selfe, their proceedings & demeanour were soe opprobriously calumniated: as deprived them both of abillitie & credit to doe any good herein: but with much sorrowe to behold how sensibly and dangerously the good opinion of this Action decayed; so that divers Preachers of note in the Cittie that had begunne in this latter Governement to pray continually for Virginia, left quite the remembrance of it: finding the Action to growe either odious or contemptible in mens minds: which yet but a little before was of that esteeme, as divers on their death beds gaue great Legacies to the furtherance thereof: and even from the East Indies by way of Contribution, hath bin sent by the Factors and poore Marriners above 1000 pounds Sterling so farr was the reputation of this Action spread, by the prosperinge thereof vnder the latter Governement, & by their zealous & sollicitous endeavours. We although by the continuall encrease of further suffringes, their Pattent being called in question, receaved a sore check: yet notwithstanding their owne Innocencie giving them courage & hope that they should overcome all with honour & thankes of the State: there were Five shipps provided for this last yeare 1624 whereof one of them since the Companies dissolueon, hath given over her voyage: the other foure haue proceeded, although with much difficulty, in regard that a great part of the Passengers that afore intended to goe, fell off. Whereby two of the Shipps which had their Comissions from the late Companie in May.
2611:
APRIL (?), 1625

527 last, could not gett away till the end of this last yeare, the other one in February, the other in March last. Thus haue wee given your Lo’ a true Information, both of the growth and languishinge of the Virginia Plantation, in these Five latter yeares [7] Government: wherein no encombrances, no calamities whatsoever could keepe it soe downe, but that it did yearely advance it selfe with a most remarkeable growth, whilst the carefull Nurse and tender Mother the Company was permitted to governe it. Though contagion & sword destroyed many people: yet whilst the number of new did doubly supply those that fayled, it cannot be said, but the Action was in a thriving, in a prosperous course; though not in a cleare or easy. Then began it to stand, when the Companie was troubled; to stagger, when they were disgracd and discountenanced; to sincke, when they were terrifyed with affrightment of Dissolution; since which tyme there hath bin nothing at all done towards the recovery or helping it forward, but much towards the hindringe & bringing it lower. The poore supply of People & shippes that are gone, are but the remaynder of the late Companies cares & loves. The setters out of the best of them doe affirme, that if they had not beene so farr engaged before the vnexpected dissolution of the late Companie, they would haue drawne back their Adventures & People. When they shall arive in Virginia, they will not bring either comfort or supply to the Colonie: but only add to their Calamitie, to their greife. The first Shipp went in August, victualled only for Three moneths: the next in October: neither of them were arived the 25th of February last. Whereby they must needs come into Virginia in most miserable distresse. The other two went out soe meanly provided, that how euer short their voyage shalbe, they cannot but prove an insupportable charge to the Colony, much disfurnished by the victualling of divers shipps lately returned thence, and so ill provided by a deceiptfull cropp, which seemed large, but proved scant, as wee dare not but acquaynt your Lo’. what experience.
2612:
b28 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

perswades vs, That there is like to followe in the Colonie some great distresse for victualls, except by speedy supply hence they be relieved. There is likewise in the Colony a most dangerous want of Powder, so great, as if the Savages should knowe the advantage they haue thereby, they might easily in one day destroy all o people. There is most extreame want of hose, shooes, & all apparrell, even to a dangerous empeachement of their healthes: and that so generall, as the provisions carried in these late Shipps, will not as farr as wee cann learne, supply the Tenth part of their necessities. The want of such wonted supplies, will vndoubtedly much dismay & deiect the Colony. But when they shall vnderstand of the Companies dissolueon, for the continuance of whose Governemt and the Liberties they enioyed vnder them, they were most importunate suitors to his Maᵗⁱᵉ, and that they are returned vnder those handes wᵗʰ they so much abhorred: Wee doubt no possible meanes wilbe found to keepe the greatest and best part of the Colonie from imediatly cominge away. [8] For wee are credibly informed, that some of the chiefe, haue allready by sellinge of their Estates, made preparation vpon the first notice of the change, to leaue the Country. But when farther they shall heare the newes of the late Contract, whereby all their hopes shalbe quite extin- guished, and all possibilitie of subsistance taken from them, wee cannot thinke that any will stay behinde that shall not bee kept by force. But howsoeuer it shall happen: sure wee are that by these alteracons & courses the mindes of the Planters wilbe filled wᵗʰ such Jealousies & suspicions, as it wilbe a long while ere they wilbe reduced to a firme resolucon of setting vp the Rest of their Lives, & hopes in the Colony: Which wᵗʰ all humble duty wee are bold to say, hath bin & will euer bee a disposition most pernicious to the establishing of the Plantation: And the overcoming thereof by the Company, Wee hold to haue bin one of the greatest services that they did. This wee conceaue to be yᵉ state of the Colonie now in Virginia. Wee though they should be persuaded or forced to stay, yet wᵗʰout supply of
2613:
APRIL (7), 1625

52 others sent hence, they must needes come to nothinge in a very short space, although they had noe other enemy. As for adventuringe hence, what by the disgracinge of the Action it selfe, & the undeserved suffrings of the late Companie, the businesse is brought to such a stand, as seemes incredible: there being no preparation that wee can heare of not only of any Shipp, but of any man to goe to Virginia, Whereas commonly for divers yeares before, there were foure or five shipps in readinesse, and as many hundreds of men, at this tyme of ye yeare. So that even in that regard also, the Colony will find themselves both in great discomfort, & great danger. For although formerly they had no Forte on the Land to hinder a forraigne Enemy: yet especially in the latter tymes, there was such aboundance of Shipping cominge and goinge continually to Virginia, that there hath bin sometymes told Seaventeene sayle together in James River. Whereby besides that it was a continual terror to the Natives, it would haue bin a difficult thinge to endamage the Colonie, w'out the power both of many Shippes, & many souldiers. Wh was amongst divers others, a very mayne securitie & encouragement, to perswade men boldly to goe to Virginia. But that and all other helpes being now foyled or much empayred, although the nomber of men be at least Three tymes as many as when wee vndertooke the Governem'; yet will wee Ingenuously yeeld, that equall thanks & equall honour wilbe due to them, who shall now recover & restore it to that prosperous & flourishing estate, to wch by Gods blessinge o cares & labours had brought it, vntill it was marred by them, who as appeares never loved it, but for their owne indirect ends, wch they haue industriously pursued, [9] Thus much touching the present estate of the Plantation, & the late generall decay thereof. Wherein wee hope yo" Lo* will excuse both our playnes & prolixitie, tending to no other end, but only to present vnto yo’ Lo® viewe, the cleare state & true nature of the disease; that so yo" Lo’ in yo' great wisedome may the better discerne & provide the proper remedies. Towards wch, since yo" Lo* haue bin also pleased to require some preparative as it were of o" opinions: wee will now humbly apply o'selues to that consideration, wtout wch, all the rest were but griefe & labour.
2614:
530 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

And here first wee are in duety forced to deliver vnto yor Lorᵈˢ, that the restoring, supporting & readvancement of that Plantation, wee hold to bee a worke, though of great necessitie for the honour, yea and service of his Maᵗʸ, these tymes considered: yet wᵗʰ all of soe extreme difficultie, that it is not to be rashly & vnadvisedly vndertaken, but wᵗʰ great circumspection, care, & preparacon, with assurance also of great assistance. For not to insist much, vpon the nature & greatnes of the worke, so remote from the favourers, so vicine to mighty Maligners of it: and indeed fitter for the power & purse of a Great Prince & State, then of private Adventureᵣˢ, and these allready exhaust & tyred; the wounds we since that great wound of the Massacre, it hath more lately receaved, from their handes whom it least beseemed, are still so wide & bleeding, that vnlesse his Maᵗʸ, and yor Lorᵈˢ as deputed from him, shall vouchsafe to apply a Soveraine hande for the healing of them, wee are resolute of opinion, that it is impossible, the Plantation carried as formerly by private persons, should either prosper or long subsist: Those woundes wee conceaue are three.

First the generall disreputation of the Busines, (Reputation being a principall pillar of all great Actions,) & that partly by some errors, neglects & disasters, but principally by the late faction, though of a few & small Adventurers, yet strongly & strangely Inanimated & supported against the great Body of the Companie: whereof in fine also by vndermining misinformation they haue wrought the Dissolution; & consequently left all both Adventurers & Planters, in an vtter vneertainty of their Rights, Titles & Possessions: though promise was made that they should be reassured to them, wᵗʰ these men haue neglected to see performed.

Secondly the great discouragement of sundry not of the meanest both Adventurers & Planters, some of them persons of Honour, and others also of good quallitie: by whose cares & labours, together wᵗʰ their freinds & purses, the Plantation having formerly receaved no small increase & benefitt, to the Planters great comfort & content, (wᵗʰ they haue not forborne from tyme to tyme to declare): yet haue they by the vniust Calumnies & clamors of these men, bin continually prosecuted wᵗʰ all variety of extremitie, to the rewarding of them with evill for their good.
2615: APRIL (?), 1626 531 deservings, and to the disheartening of all other, to succeed in like care & industry. Thirdly the present extreme poverty & consumption of the Plantation, being for want of the accustomed yearly supplies, reduced to that paucity of men, & want of all sorts well near of necessary provisions, that it cannot be restored, but with an huge expense, no less almost than to set up a new Plantation. Now touching the disreputation of the Action, and the general disheartening of the Adventurers & Planters, such especially as have spared neither pains nor expense, for the recovering, supporting & advancing the Plantation: We humbly crave your Lordships' favorable patience, though we somewhat enlarge ourselves in this place, to present in part the Injustices & grievances of those wounds to the honorable minds & skillful hands of your Lordships: Seeing that in our understanding, the curing of them by your Lordships, may be a means to revive again the generally deaded hearts of both Adventurers & Planters, & to add a new lustre & grace to the Action. Amongst the many glorious works of the late King, there was none more eminent, than his Gracious inclination, together with the propagation of Christian Religion, to advance & set forward a new Plantation in the new world. Which purpose of his continued till the last, manifested by his Majesty's many public & private speeches by divers Letters of his, & by his sundry Proclamations: at their faults are far the greater, who, as immediately shall be declared, did maliciously and cunningly pervert those Gracious intentions of his Majesty by scandalizing the Government as it then stood, as neither convenient here, nor likely there to advance the prosperity of the Colonie; and by insinuating assurances, that they themselves would maintain that work by better means. Which his Majesty conceiving (as it was reason) they would not so boldly have promised of themselves, being so great a work, unless they had had both knowledge, & means to go thorough with it; did also believe: & so they became the Undertakers. And now, as it hath been ever far from our practice, and against our present Desires, to fall upon the persons of any men, where the necessity & justice of the cause doth not necessarily require it: yet at this time it is impossible to clear this point to your Lordships without [Li] naming some of their persons, and particularizing their Actions. About Six years agoe, when by reason
2616: 532 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY of the apparent misprosperinge of the Plantation, and the fowlenes of the Accounts here, (the then Treasurer being Governour of Fower or Five other Companies, wch excused his neglect of attending this busines,) the Governemt of the Companie was translated from Sr. Thomas Smith and Alderman Johnson, into Sr. Edwin Sandis, & after into the Earle of Southampton's hands, & their Deputies: it is notoriously knowne, how they, with Captayne Argoll and other of their freinds, partly peradventure through discontent for being removed from their places, but principally through feare; (their Accounts, Depredations, Piracies & misgovernement being now questiond before the Counsell and in the Companies Courts,) perpetually disturbed & disgraced by severall wayes, both to his Maty & to the world, all the present proceedings of the Companie, to ye great disheartninge of the Companie here, and no small advantage of ye Colonie. And of this, and of the bad effects of it, all our bookes, & memories are full, But yet by Gods assistance, & the unwearied courage of the Companie, wee ridd out this storme. The next blowe, as wee had reason to believe, proceeding by their underhand raysinge of new spiritts, drawne to disturbe vs for their owne gayne was the bringing in of new & severall projects concerning Tobacco: wch was for the instant the only commoditie whereby the Planters mayntayned themselves. And so under colour of advancing profitt to his Maty sometimes (as hath bin before touched) wee were forbidden to bring in any Tobacco, sometimes to bring in but a small quantitie, and sometimes comaunded to bring in all, Wch varying directions, did so distract & confound the Adventurers & Planters, that it had in a manner ruynd the Plantation. But yet by Gods assistance, & the constancy of ye Companie, wee ridd out this storme also. The instruments in this worke, that especially appeared were the then Sr. Lionell Cranfield, Mr. Jacob, and some others: to the extreme damage of the Company, enrichement of themselves, & deceyt of his Maty: as was at large expressed & offered to be proved in ye last Parliament. Thirdly, by the procurement of that part, divers scandalous petitions against the Company in generall, & many in perticuler, did putt vs to much vexation & trouble. But their accusations were so false, that wee also overcame this Third assault.
2617:
APRIL (?), 1626

After this another stratagem was obtruded vpon vs, vnder pretence of freindship & love to the Plantation. The Earle of Middesex then Lo: high Treasuror of England, who in respect of his place was to take into consideracon all thinges that had relacon to his Maᵗʸ revenue, did first propound to Sr. Edwin Sandis, & afterwards to the Ea: of Southampton, the Lo: Cavendish & Sr. Edwin Sandis together, that the King, he knewe, had by Sr. Thomas Smithes meanes & Alderman Johnsons, and some great freinds & instruments of theires, bin strangely possessed agaynst the forme of our Governemᵗ, & the consequences of it: & particulerly that they had made such advantage by traducing the names of the Earle of Southampton and Sr. Edwin Sandis, that the busines of the Plantacon fared the worse for their sakes, That he had allready in Generall spoken wᵗʰ his Maᵗʸ, & assured him, that the whispers & relaçons of those men, had an eye to their owne safetie, and not to the Colonies good; and that therevpon the King referred the whole consideracon of the Plantation, and what was best to be done, to his care. Vpon this he propounded vnto those before named, that the best way to engage the Kinge in his care of the Plantations, and to make it impossible for any hereafter to disturbe the Companie, as they had formerly done, was to thinke of some such meanes, whereby the proffitt of his Maᵗʸ, & the good of the Plantation, might hand in hand goe together. And to speake truth, though those he spoke wᵗʰ, were at first very vnwilling to swallowe this guilded pill, as having heard of the stile he vsed in negotiatinge other businesses of this nature: yet he was so full of protestaçons in it, euer pretending ex || the Companies || good, and wᵗʰ all procured further intimaçon to the Earle of Southampton, that no service of his could be more acceptable to his Maᵗʸ then this now propounded: that Vpon these protestaçons & assurance, they engaged themselues to treat of a Contract betweene his Maᵗʸ & the Companies. In the making whereof, the said Earle of Midd remembred not his promised care of the Plantations, but in truth from one degree to another, wrested vs to such condiçons, & such a rate, as was very dammageable to the Plantations. But vpon serious debate in many & full Courts, vpon the whole matter wee were resolved, considering the protection of the Colonies, & fauour promised; and to be free from those frequent projects that in former tymes had so much wronged & disturbed vs, to accept an hard bargayne: conceavinge that though it were not so good as wee desired, & was fitt to haue bin offerd; yet by it wee should...
2618:
534 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

bee in a better case & way of benefitting the Plantations, then formerly wee were. And so in Michaelmas terme 1622 this Contract we began to be treated of in Easter terme, was concluded by the subscription of the Earle of Middlesex his hand, and by sending the Company word, that that day the whole Counsell board had given their assent therevnto, wch was the first tyme the Companie vnderstood that they had heard of the matter. [13] The Contract thus concluded, a great Tempest arose, by what seerett cause & vnderhand procurement, wee may guesse, but cannot affirme. But in a Court of the Company vpon the 4th of December followinge, one Mr. Wrote Cosen Germane to the Earle of Middlesex (discontented also that hee was passed ouer in the election of Officers.) did with a passionate & blastring speech, inveigh agaynst the Contract, & the menaging thereof with Sallary; agaynst the proceeding in the Treaty of it, as that it had bin vnduly and vniustly carried, that men had bin overawed; and that it had bin procured to private ends. Whereof not being able to make any shadowe of proofe, & persisting still in his violent & contemptuous demeanor, vpon a full hearinge, he was thrust out of the Companie; and vpon that ioyned himselfe to Sr. Thomas Smith, Alderman Johnson & the opposite party, & drewe also with him Two more of his Companions, and so now made shewe of a formall party agaynst the Company. But for all this wee still mayntayned the reputacon of our proceeding.

The next of troubles in order, (proceeding from what secrett cause, that wch followes will give your Lo? more reason of coniecture, then wee will now affirme,) was that this opposite party then attayned to about 25 in nomber, had some seerett encouragement or other given them, directly to oppugne the Contract; wch, as is before declared, was so formally made: And gave some reasons in writing agaynst it to the then Lord Trér; who receaving them, gave the Company first suspicon of double intelligence & indirectnes in his dealinge. But howsoever, the Earle of Southampton, the Lo: Cavendish, Sr. Edwin Sandis & some other, being called by the Earle of Middlesex to his Chamber at Whitehall, then thought, that they had given such answeres to them, as that his Lo? rested satisfied. But his Lo? after, speaking with the Ea: of South'ton and the rest before named told them, that they that had supposed, were a clamorous Company, and that to make the busines goe current, it were best that their objections...
2619:
APRIL 7, 1625

& of answeres should be heard at the Counsell table. And vpon hearing there of their accusations, and of answeres, the Earle of Middlesex, who assumed the chiefe knowledge & care of that busines, did in the close of that hearinge vse the words formerly rehearsed, Of the leaud carriage in former tymes, and of the latter in a manner miraculous recoverie. A greater testimony of our integritie & their guilt, could not be given. But as the sequell will manifest, & as wee haue since found in other of his Lor[dship's] proceedings, he meant to loose nothing by those words. [14] Howsoeuer it was, & whatsoever wee suspect, not intending now to dive into those miseries; from that day forward, to the Conclusion of this busines he professedly made himselfe the patron to that side, & enemy to the Company; for which wee appeale to your Lordships' better knowledge. Afterward about that Contract were divers meetings before the Lorde, where it was principally inveighed against by Sr. Nathaniell Rich, speaking against the injustice & unconscionablenes of it; protesting that he had euer sold his Tobacco for Fiue shillings a pound one with another, and that euery pound cost him Two shillings six pence in the Sumer Islands: and now to give a Third away to the King & peradventure the price not to be much higher, was against Justice & Conscience. And here by the way, wee humbly craue leaue to say thus much, that his Conscience now serues him in this new Contract, to force the Planter & the Adventurer to sell their Tobaccos, the best sort for 2s. 4d. and the second sort at sixteene pence a pound. But vpon that former Demonstrative Argument of his, though it were so fully answered as nothing could be more, yet the Earle of Middlesex tooke his ground to condemne the Contract he had signed, as hurtfull to the Plantations; and to comaund the Companies to thinke of propounding a better & to bring it in writing within Two daies: Which was accordingly done: and therein shewed, that the hardnesse of this Contract, was not by the Companies proposition, but by his Lordship's pressure. And therefore vrged what had bin offred to his Lordship at the first; that his Majesty would be contented with a fourth, & not require a Third of the Tobacco, To which in great scorne his Lordship replyed that take Two pence out of Six pence there would remayne a Groat. But the last Parliament sawe that his best invention, was by adding 3s. to 40s. to make vp Five pound. But in conclusion that Contract was dissolved, & a comaund laid vpon...
2620:
536 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

the Companies by his Lo' procurement, to bring all our Tobaccoes in, under colour that Three pence custome was abated; Whereas in truth, by his admitting also of all Spanish Tobacco upon Sr. John Wolstenholmes motion, we could not vent a third part of it here: and so by computation, in respect of the quantity unvented, we paid neere double as much as before: Which was his only favour to the Plantations. The Contract thus dissolved, as publicly damageable, by the encouragement of the Earle of Middlesex, & industry of the Five and twenty before mentioned, (that so place might be made for this [15] Latter Contract, so privately beneficiall, for so by the effect it hath appeared): the Government was now likewise to be questioned and altered, or else they compassed not their ends. Which to bring about, these two ways were used: First a petition was delivered to his Ma'y by Alderman Johnson, in the name of the rest, inveighing against the latter Government, & magnifying the former. And in the end, desiring a Commission to examine the proceedings of these last Fower years. This Petition was by the Company at large answered to his Ma'ty, & we joined in the point of having our Actions examined by the Commission: but withall thought it just, & desired, that their Twelve years Government before might be also examined: Which accordingly was ordered. The second means used by them, was to raise up Captayne Butler, who hasting from the Sumer Ilandes to Virginia, where he stayed but a few weeks, upon his returne delivered to his Ma'ty, a Paper called The Unmasking of Virginia. The substance of which was, first the dispraise of the Country, & making of it an unfit place for any English Colony; & next, scandalizing the Government of it, both here, & there. What concerned the Colonie, was proved to be false by Forty witnesses: who chanced to be in Towne then, & had bin often & long in the Colonie: And was endeavored to be maintained by him by two means only: one by practicing to get the hande of Two men unto it, to whom he owed money & deferred payment: who when they heard it read in Co', protested that they never saw what they set their hands to, and that Capt: Butler told them it was to a Paper, which he would show the King for the good of the Plantation: and desired the Companies pardon; for whatsoever was there said was false. Secondly he would have made it to have been better believed, by a forged Letter which he brought to Sr. John Bourchier from his daughter Mrs. Whittakers: who knew it.
2621:
APRIL (?), 1625

was not her hand. This was alleadged at the Counsell Table: & Capt. Butler answered, that shee was sicke, & dictated it to him, and he wrote it. But since, both shee & her husband being come ouer, they both forsweare it, & say it was none of her doing nor direction. But howsoeuer, by those meanes the opposite party thus farre obteyned their ends, that by the Defamation, and this trouble ensuinge, a very great number that intended to haue gone ouer, were discouraged. But yet for all this, the Companie knewe their cause to be so just and justifiable, that they did not abandon it: but prepared themselues to give divers charges before the Comission, agaynst divers of the partie opposite; & professed themselues ready to make their owne defence whensoever they should be charged. But whilst the Comission sate, farther to discourage vs, first of all our Bookes, & after the Minutes of them were sent for away from vs: that none of the Letters that then came from Virginia were to be seene by vs, being all seazed on by the Comission. But touching the rest of the Cariage of that Comission, because it was at large delivered in Parliament, & offered to be proved, if further proceeding in that businesse had not bin forborne vpon a Letter written to the house from his Maiestie, wee will now to your Lordship say only this; That whatsoever was brought by vs concerninge Accounts, Depredation, misgovernement, & diuers other crimes, agaynst perticuler persons, was by this Comission, (especially directed by the Earle of Midd,) shufled of for all the tyme, till the Comission was even at the end, and nothing done vpon them. And on the Contrary, whatsoever could be gathered out of the fragments of Letters from discontented persons in Virginia, concerning either the place or governement was diligently collected by them, and receaued by the Earle of Middlesex, as a great testimony agaynst vs; and would not take those other Letters for proofe which wee euer guided ourselues by, and came from the Governour and Counsell there. And lastly some three days before their Comission ended, they putt vs on a sodayne to answere to 39 Articles, or else they would take them pro confesso. This they thought for vs impossible to doe. But wee deceaved their expectation; and they could not find in the least perticuler, any just ground to make any report agaynst vs. 

1 Manuscript illegible, but it may be—"but answered that she was sick".
2622:
538 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

By all this, the Earle of Middlesex and that partie, perceaving yt Companie would not be beaten off a good cause; there was a practise to try whither wee had rather part from the busines, or from our mony. Wherevpon wee were called before the Counsell agayne, and there that side as compassionate affecters of the Plantation, vrged the want of Corne & other necessaries there, and that they were like to perish for want of provisions. The Earle of Midd replyed it was a matter of so great importance, & concerned the lives of so many of the Kings Subjects, that if yt Companie would not presently take order for sending Supplies, the State would call in their Pattent. Wherevpon yt Companie conceavinge that if they did send supplyes, their Patent would not [17] be taken from them, vnderwritt to a Roule; (though they knewe yt necessitie was nothing so great,) foure thousand and odd pounds, wch was paid and sent; and those Gentlemen that before seemed so zealous subscribed Twelue pounds, and paid it not. Vpon wh comparison wee leaue it to yo' Lor to iudge, wch party was the true father of this Child.

This then not succeeding according to their desires, certayne obscure persons were found out by the Earle of Midd, to be sent into Virginia, as Comissionrs, for these two ends, as wee haue since found. First, to sifte out what they could agaynst the forme of o' Governem' here, & there; & next to persuade the people to become Petitioners to his Maty for a newe. We succeeded not according to their expectation. For by the Colonies Peticons, answeres to those Papers that had bin delivered agaynst them here, & divers other remonstrances to his Maty from a Generall Assembly there, they shewed the misery wherein they lived, or rather languished in Sr Thomas Smithes tyme; and their happy estate in this latter Governement: concludinge (at if his Maty intended to alter the Governement, & putt it into the former hands, their humble suite to him was, That Comissionrs might be sent ouer to another purpose before declared, The writinges themselues will manifest this more at large.

These Comissionrs thus sent to Virginia, the Earle of Midd & the rest were not idle in further distractinge the Companie here at home. And about Michachuas a mocon was made to the Companie, to give their assents for surrendring their Patent, & altering the forme of Governem'; & a newe one was proposed: Wch according to order they takinge into consid-
2623:
APRIL (?), 1625

539

eracon, with duetie refused: rendring also in writing the reasons of their refusall. Whereupon a Quo Warranto was directed by the Earle of Midd[lesex] suggestion, for the calling in of their Pattent. In the meane time, to affright men, both from cominge to, & much more from speakinge in Courts, mens words were there carped at & complayned of; and their persons by the Earle of Midd[lesex] prosequution, were upon quick hearinge sent to prison. Yet for all this the Comp[any] stood to their owne Justification, & defence of their Pattent. Now Mr. Atturney, according to the duty of his place, & instructions given him, vrged the misgovernement of the Companie, & consequently the ruyne of the Plantation. To which point wee were willinge to ioyne issue. But afterwards in our reply to his pleadinge, without further enquiry of the former allegation, advantage was taken upon our mispleading, & in fine without any further ground that wee knowe of, the Patent was in Trinity terme following Condemned: But for any thing that wee haue yet seene, no iudgment entred. [18] Your Lordships by the perticulers before related, do see by what courses wee were reduced to this extremitie. One thing yet wee thinke most necessary to adde; It hath bin said by many, & perticulerly by some principall persons of the opposite partie, that the Dissolutions of these Plantations was part of the Count of Gondomars Instructions: And certaynely wee found his activenes in negotiatinge here, such, that in bringing about his owne ends, he could create here instruments of ourselves against our selves. Wee say not that he & other Spanish Ministers practised thus amongst vs. These two only perticulers, wee craue leaue to offer unto your Lordships Judgement. When Sr. Samuell Argoll some six or seauen yeares since, was vehemently complayned against, by Padre Maestro, and the Spanish Secretarie then here for Piracie, against the Kinge of Spaines subiects in the West Indies: he no sooner came home from Virginia, & appeared an Opposite to the present Company, who question'd him for divers misdemeanors, and amongst others for this, but the heate of the Spanish accusation did presently cease. Our second observation in this; Your Lordships cannot but remember, with what extreame earnestnes the Count of Gondomar, and afterwards Don Carlo di Coloma, inveighed against Capt. Butler whilst he was in the Summer Islandes, about the...
2624:
540 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

Spanish wrack. And so violent were they about it, that the Lo: Steward, now with God, and the Lo: Chamberlaine, were entreated to come on purpose to the Sumer Islands Company, about that busines. And a Comission was directed by the Lords of the Counsell, to examine the truth of the cause in the Sumer Islands. Well Captaine Butler having bin forewarned of by some friends of his, left his Government before he had leave, and before the arrival of the Comission: Having first there endeavoured to alienate the minds of the people from the forme of Government here. But he was no sooner come home, & delivered to his Maty The Vnmasking of Virginia before spoken of, but there was an end of Don Carlo Di Colomars prosecution. We have related the particulars; & make no application.

As for the late Comission, which hath succeeded in the place of the Company; if we might have seen the business seriously taken into the Grave cares, & prosecuted with the Noble pains of those most honoble personages, whose names are inserted in the said Comission: we should have hoped to have seen some good effect [19] befitting their great & eminent worth. But whilst their more weighty Affaires have hindered them, the business hath bin principally carried only by those persons, that were the chief Opposers of the late Company. For although there be named divers worthy Gentlemen, & Citizens likewise, in the Comission: yet as we understand, the most of them have forborne altogether to appear at any meetinge. Wherefore when either in our words or thoughts, we complain of any proceedings of the late Comission; we always except both all those persons of Honour, & indifferency: and only intend those others, whose stomachs were so great, as they durst undertake the overthrowing of the late Company; and yet their hearts so narrow, as they have not dared to adventure all of them during these Nine months, as far as we can learn, one five pounds to the advancement or subsistence of the Plantation.

By the publick Letters of the Governour delivered them in July last, they were plainly understood of the extreme want of Powder in the Colonie: and were often told from us of the great danger that might ensue thereby. Yet did they neglect the sending of any in the first Shipp, or in the Second: but about Christmas, & since in March, they have sent a small quantity, obtained by his late Maty gift (as we hear) out of the Tower. 

[In pencil.]
2625:
APRIL (?), 1625

This did not the late Company: who upon notice of the Massacre, did by the first shipp send 42 Barrells of Powder; for halfe whereof the Officers having disbursed the mony, are yet unsatisfied. Whereas all the Fower shippes now sent, were prepared in the Company's tyme; these last Commissioners callinge in the Comissions graunted them by the late Company, made them take newe as from themselues; that so they might glory upon anothers foundation: But whilst they thus hunted after windy ambition, hindringe the two first Shipps from takinge a faire winde; they have bin the causes of all the lamentable calamities & distresses, wch in so long voyages must needs befall them. The principall scope of his late Ma[jes]ties Comission to them, as wee understand, was, that they should finde a better forme of Government for the Plantations advancement; and therein is especially promised the conservation of euery mans right. Intentions worthy the wisedome & Justice of so great a Prince. But as far as wee can understand, these Commissioners have done nothing towards either of these ends: But quite contrary to the second. 

By an unknowne Contract, wch themselues will not so much as declare, much lesse are able to defend; they have sought to share amongst themselues, twice as much upon euery mans goods, as they will leaue to the Owner thereof. And although they say only three of them are Contractors yet wee cannot believe it; having observed the ends of some of them for many yeares, to have constantly bin bent to the compassing of some such advantage, as they have now by this bargayne gayned. It is constantly reported that they have liberally given that wch was not their owne, to those who have no right thereto; as namely the Colonies Mine to Sr. Samuell Argoll, & Mr. Woodall surgion to Sr. Thomas Smith. But this & all their other proceedings are kept in great secrett: wch breeds suspition that they have not bin good; else why doe they fly the Light? This is cleane contrary to the use of the late Company: who did all thinges in publick: wch was a cause of as great satisfaction, as this of Distaste. And as in this, so in all other thinges do they proceed cleane contrary to all right in of understandinge. They publish their Intention of imployinge Sr. Samuell Argoll & Captaine Butler for Governours agayne in the Plantations.
2626:
542 RECORDS OF the VIRGINIA COMPANY

tations: against whome the Colony hath professed open enmity. How they should make the Colony encrease by these means, which will bring home most of them that are there already, wee cannot imagine. Neither are Sr. Thomas Smith nor Alderman Johnson fit or likely men to reunite the late Companie, or to drawe them on to any thinge for the Plantations advancement: since as the whole world knowes, the late Companie have not only always conceaved extremely ill of them, but in the yeare 1623. putt up publick weevsaGoms against them, of very dangerous Consequence. As for the Colony, your Lot have formerly heard their like opinions. Nor can the late Companie conceive, Mr. Wrote, a fit Instrument to sett forward the busines; whome they thought unworthy to bee of their Societie. Nor that those who out of pretence for New-Englands good, have truly wronged Virginia, should now runne a right way for the behoofe thereof. Nor in sum, that those who have little or no interest in the Plantation, should be so sensible of it as were fit. In which number we account Sr. Nathaniel Rich; who to our knowledge hath not adventured anything for the good thereof but contrary wise hath been so perpetually a hinderer, & disturber of the Action, that the body of the Company, addressed a Petition of Complaint, to the last Parliament, craving justice against him, for his injurious & most unworthy practises. [21] Nor that they that mean not to adventure anything, will be able to persuade others to do that which themselves forbear.
