Nor that ever they will do the Adventurers of the late Companie right, in matters of their Estates; that have so violently endeavoured to do them wrong in their Honor & Reputations: having intended as themselves write, a Reformation & Correction of the Original Court books of the late Companie then possessed by them, if they could have got into their hand certain copies of them which Mr. Nicholas Ferrar late Deputy had at his own charges caused to be transcribed. But before their severe order came to him, he had delivered his copies to the Earle of Southampton: who sent the Commissioners word, that he would as soon part with the evidences of his Land, as with the said Copies; being the evidence of his honour in that.
2627:
APRIL (?), 1625

service: so by this meanes haue the Originall Courtbookes yet escaped purging: And with all duety wee humbly beseech your Lordships, that they may hereafter be protected from it: And that howsoeuer your Lordships shall please for the future to dispose of the Companie, that the records of their past Actions may not be corrupted & falsified. As for their resolucions of ordering the busines, wee cannot say any thinge, because wee heare nothinge, and wee doubt they meane nothinge. For all that wee heare tends only to nothing. They dislike the sending of nombers of men. They professe the reducinge of all tradinge to a Joynt-stock or Magazine: which courses in our iudgements tend directly to the subversion of the Plantation, at least to the appropriatinge of it to themselues which to haue bin the mayne end of some of them, the late Counsell & Companie for Virginia, haue vpon strong presumption bin long agoe induced to belieue: and therefore haue now thought themselues bound to declare it, that your Lordships in your Noble wisedomes may make such due preuention as shalbe fitt: humbly beseechinge that this perticuler examination of their Actions & persons, may not be interpreted to proceed from private spleene, but only from a sincere desire of the Plantations advancement. Wee doubt and feare, that wee haue wearied your Lordships with the large relation of the proceedinges of these men, wee meane the partie opposite to the late Companie & Colonie. Whereby as they haue laid all kind of Disreputacon vpon the Action, and made that in the estimation [22] of the world vilde & contemptible, which before was held worthy, beneficiall, & honourable: so by their manifold & incessant practises, to wroung & oppresse, to defame & disgrace, by vniust & vnworthy aspersions & contumelies, (& that by word & writing ouer all the kingdome) the innocency of men zealous for the good of Virginia, for no other fault saue only for their love of right & iustice; they haue bredd a great disheartninge & discouragement of many the most forward & most constant Adventurers, whose industry also & labours have bin of great vse to the Plantation. All which being wearied out with their mallice and iniuries, and louth to spend more of their lives in so vnthankfull a service, are humble suitors vnto your Lordships, that they may be spared from all farther employment in this Action. And that if these men will now at length apply themselues seriously to the busines of the Colonie, both with their paynes & purses, 15507— 35——36
2628:
544 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

we they haue hitherto spared, and vndertake (wᵗʰ they owe to his Matᵉ & yᵉ State) the repairinge those ruynes of the Plantation, whereof they haue bin the chiefe cause and instruments: the Governement thereof may, as it is, be continued in them, giving fitt securitie for so great a debt & duty. For wee protest vnto yoᵘ Loᵈˢ, vpon our truth & fidelitie, that if his Matᵉ may be served, the Colony seeured & cherished, iustice duly administred, mens rights & states preserved, innocent men not oppressed, and malefactors not protected & rewarded; wee shalbe so farr from envying the glory of their Governement, that extinguishing for euer the memory of all their former iniuries, wee wilbe ready to doe them all fitt service that they shall require.

By this we hath bin said, yoᵘ Loᵈˢ will easily perceaue, that obedience to yoᵘ comaundᵉ, and a desire that yᵉ Plantation (if possibly) may yet subsist, is yᵉ end of oᵘ labour: not that wee intend, or haue any enclinacon, to encomber our selues, wᵗʰ a busines so vexed & perplexed; but only ayme at what may bee to the good of it, though to oᵘ owne trouble. But if yoᵘ Loᵈˢ in yoᵘ wisedomes, shall not thinke it fitt to putt it into their handes: or that they, wᵗʰ such caution as may be reasonably desired, shall not adventure to vndertake it: Wee then will notwithstandinge, in expres- sion of oᵘ duty to his Maᵗ and the State, in respect of our ancient & present love to yᵉ Plantation, and for the speciall benefitt that may succeed to this Kingdome by such a place of securitie & retreate in America; (the want [28] whereof, as by experience in many particulars may be demon- strated, was in the late Queenes tyme the overthrowe of most of oᵘ voyages sett out for the West Indies) for these reasons wee say, wee shall endeauour oᵘ best, but dare not vndertake, to restore what these others haue allmost destroyed. But yet that, vpon such condi¢ons, as wee hold most necessary for the effecting of so great a worke, that is, some impediments to bee removed, & some encouragements to be given to it.

It hath bin a great errour, for any to imagine, that the persons of these men, who haue of late thus opposed the Companie, were either in nomber considerable, or in adventure to be valued any way at all, to further or advance the prosperity of the Plantation: but rather on the contrary, great impediments to the faire proceeding of it: And therefore whereas the late Companie, haue by the vniust practises of divers of these, and
2629:
APRIL (?), 1625

some of them vnworthy persons, suffered so much in the reputacion of their persons & actions, as well by private calumny, as also in some publick proceedings against them: Wee shall for that cause most humbly desire, that ye Actions & passages of our late Governement, may be brought to an vpright examination, before this Honorable Board: and that being found, as wee assure ourselues they will, to haue bin most iust, & euer tending to ye Plantations advancement, wee may then haue iust reparacion from those, by whom wee & the Plantation it selfe haue bin so much wronged: That the like dangers may be hereafter prevented, by discouraging others from the same attempts; and that wee the late Company, being restored to the integritie of our reputacions, may bee the better enabled to goe on with ye Action, for ye tyme to come.

Nowe in regard of the extreme distresse & poverty, that by these late practises of ye Colony is reduced vnto; and by reason of ye disability, & vnwillingnesse of Adventurers, being so extremely discouraged, and who haue already wasted a great part of their tyme, and no small part of their estates, in supporting this Plantation: as also in regard of the great danger that may be feared from a forraigne enemy: Wee shall most humbly desire, that his Ma'ty would be pleased, to yield vnto the Plantation, some such moderate supply, as after the late Massacre was promised in the last Kings tyme; Namely, the setting out of Foure hundred able men, at the voluntary charges of the seuerall shires of this Kingdome, proportionably to be rated. And besides for ye present pressing necessitie, to give vs some such reasonable proportion of Munition & Powder, as in regard of these tymes may be thought convenient.

These difficulties & impediments being eased or removed, wee come now in the last place to present our humble opinions, touching the best forme of Governement to be here established for Virginia; wherein wee humbly offer to your Lordships consideration, whether it may not seeme requisite, that a Companie be agayne erected of Adventurers & Planters for the governing & managing of the affaires of that Plantation. In the weighing whereof, wee haue divided our thoughts into these three branches: If his Ma'ty should be pleased himselfe to vndertake the Plantation, and the charge thereof to be defrayed out of his Royall Treasure; or otherwise at the Generall charge of the Kingdome: Wee hold it out of question, that
2630:
546 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

the fittest Governement of the Action, were by a select Counsell of Honor & able persons, to be ordayned and appoynted by his Maᵗᵗ, as is vsed in like cases in some forrayne Dominions. But if the burden & charge must be borne by the Adventurers and Planters themselves; Wee hold it necessary in that case, that yᵉ Governmᵗ thereof be also commended by his Maᵗᵗ to them, incorporated as before into a Legall Companie: yet so, as to be assisted & advised by a Councell to be appoynted by his Maᵗᵗ & bound by oath vnto him; and they also to haue reference in all causes of greatest & extraordinary importance, to his Maᵗᵗ himselfe, or to the Lords of his privy Counsell, from thence to take resoluçon & direction, as was formerly instituted, and in the latter times also practised. And this is agreeable to yᵉ com̄on vsage of the world, & in perticuler of this Nation: experience having manifested, that men are difficultly drawne to adventure any great matter in these Actions, in yᵗ ordering of wᶜʰ they haue no voice or interest. For as for this late third way of Governement, by an absolute Comission, disprovided of other meanes, saue what should be raysed from yᵉ Plantacon experience hath taught, that it cann worke no great effect, the hearts of all the Adventurers being turned away from the Action, & yᵉ Plantᵐ there in great part, vpon the bare feare & forerunning rumour of this Comission, resolving to come away & desert the Plantation. Howbeit, if such of yᵉ Comissioneʳˢ themselves, as formerly enioyed or partaked, & now affected this Governement, would haue opened their owne purses, as was promised to his late Maᵗᵗ, for the support of the Plantation: [25] it might perhaps haue bin continued on for some longer tyme: Whereas now all men avoiding to adventure vnder them, & they not disposed to give example in that kind, but rather to agitate and frame Contracts, whereby themselves might growe rich, though wᵗʰ the penury & consumption of the Generall Plantacon: the Colonie there doth wast by hasty Degrees, and will suddaynly come to nothing if speedy, remedy be not provided. Now if yᵒᵘ Loʳᵈˢ shall thinke good to approve of oᵘʳ humble opinion, (wᶜʰ wee in all duty submitt vnto yᵒʳ Loʳᵈˢ maturer iudgements,) and that yᵗ Companie be reerected by his Maᵗᵗ Lres Pattents & vnder his great seale, as it formerly was: then doe wee further presume to offer vnto yᵒᵘ Loʳᵈˢ consideraçon, these few perticulers here ensuinge.
2631:
APRIL (?), 1625

First wee hold it requisite, that this new Pattent should contayne the same priviledges & Liberties, the like orders & directions, as were in the former: yet with this, that if there appeare in the former graunts, any thinge inconvenient, as preiudiciall to his Maᵗʸ, it be reformed: Secondly, in regard the Colonie, taking all ill plight at the beginning, doth still runne eke on in plying only Tobacco, notwithstanding the great charges which the Companie was at, in the tyme of the latter Governement, for the setting vp of better Comodities, as Silke, Wynes, Iron, materialls for shipping, and others: that his Maᵗʸ would be graciously pleased, continuing the Custome vpon Tobacco, to remitt the custome of all other commodities for certen yeares; which wee suppose would be a matter of very small losse to his Maᵗʸ, aboundantly to be recompensed in the yeares ensuing; and yet a great meanes to drawe the Colony to those better courses, which no orders of the Companie could yet euer effect: And likewise, that the Customᵉʳs be restrayned from extorting Custome of goods transported thither for mens perticuler provisions, & not by way of Merchandize, as the Law requires. Thirdly, that in this Pattent there be declared a nullitie of all the proceedings of the late Comissioners; having bin vpon iust cause soe extreamly distastfull both to the Adventurers & Planters. Fourthly & lastly it is desired, that his Maᵗʸ would be graciously pleased that this new Pattent be confirmed by Act of Parliamᵗ, if the Lords & Commissions shall so thinke fitt. And this wee hold requisite for two important reasons; First wee suppose it will greatly encourage the Adventurers & Planters, [26] by giving them assurance of the continuance of this Plantacon, and of their seuerall estates & possessions in the same: the iealousy which hath bin bred by the late Quo warranto, being not otherwise possibly to be removed. And this encouragement would be greatly encreased, if by his Maᵗʸ Royall authoritie, with consent of Parliament, both Plantations might be annexed to the Imperiall Crowne of this Realme, according vnto the commendable pollicie of some other great Kingdoms. Secondly by meanes of this Act, the New Company may be inabled to recover the Debts due to the former Company, either vpon Accompt or otherwise.
2632:
548 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY otherwise; as also to haue restitution by a legall course for the great depredations done vpon the Colonie. A matter tending greatly to the support of the Plantation, as also to the reestablishing of the good Government of the same. And this is our humble answeare vnto your Lo™ first proposition.

[half a page blank]

[27] For the second Consideration, lefte vnto vs by your Lor®™, namely concerning an offer to be made, for such a Contract touching Tobacco, with his Ma™, as may both vphould his former Revenue, and not bee greuious to the Plantations, wee say thus.

That vnles in your lor?’ wisdomes those Conditions by vs formerly propounded bee yeilded vnto, wee cannot treate of this buissines; for wee come not as Contractors to make a bargaine for our owne priuate lucre, but with an eye only to the publique benifitt of the Plantations, as farr as it may be without preiudice of his Mat® proffitt; without any reseruation of secrett, as in the last Contract were pretended: For in a publique bargaine, betwixt his Ma‘ and his people, the most cleere, publique, & direct proceeding will euer receiue the best interpretation.

Wee cannot in our vnderstanding conceiue, that any proffer though neuer soe greate, cann be for his Mat aduantage, but rather the contrary, if it so presse vppon the Plantation, that the Planter shall not be able to liue with comfort by his labour: And so others be discouradged, from further proceeding. A greate reuenue peradventure maye be raysed for a yeare or two, but if the Plantation decaye the revenue cannot last: And thus it had beene, if the last Contract had gon on; though the immense gayne had come to the Contractors themselues & not to his Mat.

But now for ourselues, it is true A Contract was formerly treated of betwixt the Company, and the Earle of Middlesex, but as hath been before read vnto your Lor®® though it were then extreame hard, yett it is nowe impossible, by reason of the worse case the Plantation stand in nowe, then it did then, principally occasioned by the discouradgement giuen to the Company.

Wee acknowledge vnto your lor’, that the bestewinge banishinge of all Spanish Tobacco, will much redound to the Plantations benifitt, and his
2633:
APRIL (?), 1625

Maté losse: but withall, wee conceaue that if there were no Tobacco in neither of the Plantations, it were better for his Maᵗ to loose seauen or eight thousand Pound a yeare Custome by the not importation of Spanish Tobacco, then to hinder the importation of 100000ℓ a yeare in money, wᶜʰ this Comodity did, as was cleerely manifested to the two last Parliaments. Howsoeuer, wee intend not vppon the Conditions in the former paper mentioned; to make a meane & contemptible offer to his Matᵉ but such a one, as wee conceiue in truth, for the Kings proffitt, to befall as large, & more certayne then this last; and more then at any tyme really came into the Exchequar by this Comoditie. Profferinge soe much, as wee thinck the Plantations can possibly beare & subsist; and goinge as high nowe at first, as we shall euer be drawne to yeild vnto. And doubt not, but that yeildinge vnto his Maᵗ after the first yeare, 10000ℓ certayne, and 3000ℓ a yeare more by Custome, in all 13000ℓ per Annu, it will be thought more then sufficient from these nowe languishinge Plantations. For in this bargaine the Summer Islands as well as Virginia are vnderstood to be comprehended. And so wee are confident, that wee haue given yoᵘ Lorᵈ full satisfaction, to this second proposition, namely, concerninge the offer for such A Contract to be made wᵗʰ his Maᵗᵉ towchinge Tobacco, as maye both vphould his former reuenue, and not be greiuous to the Plantations. The perticulers followe.

That the sole Importation of Tobacco, into the Realmes of England, and Ireland, be graunted by his Matᵉ Letters Pattents vnder his greate Seale, to the Companies for Virginia & the Sumer Islands.

That his Maᵗᵉ, by Proclamation inhibite all others, vnder payne of confiscation of their Tobacco, and his Matᵉ highe displeasure.

That likewise the plantinge of Tobacco in England and Ireland, be forbidden by the saide Proclamation vnder a greiuous penalty.

In Consideration whereof, the Aduenturers, & Planters of both Collonies, wilbe content, that a fourth parte of their Tobaccoes (wᶜʰ shall yearely come home) shalbe sett aside & sould for publique vses, and out of yᵗ proceed thereof shalbe
2634:
550 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

First payd & discharged the Custome, due vppon the whole Quantitie (wᶜʰ shalbe brought home,) wᶜʰ Custome, shalbe after the rate of iijd p pound, as nowe it is rated and wilbe yᵉ full Custome that can be requyred, although the Tobacco should be sould after the rate of 6s p pound. (29) Secondly out of the proceeds of the saide fourth parte, there shalbe farther yearely payd vnto his Maᵗʸ by waye of thanckfull retribution for his gratious fauors—10000 li. The whole remaynder of the proceed of this fowrth parte of Tobacco, shalbe First, for the defrayinge of the chardges of menadginge and ordringe this Contract. Accordinge as the Company shall thinck good to proportion itt. And the Surplus, whateuer it bee shalbe bestowed (in such manner as the Companies shall finde most fitt) for the supporte & aduancement of the Plantations. And because it is doubted, that in regard of many difficulties, wᶜʰ are allwaies in the settlinge of newe buissinesses, the proceed of the fourth parte, for yᵉ first yeare, may not amount to soe much as the proportions aboue. Itt is therefore desired, that for yᵉ first yeare his Maᵗʸ would be gratiously pleased to allowe out of yᵉ proceed of yᵉ saide fourth parte First, as much as shall defraye the Custome, then 6000 li more towardes the vses aboue expressed, and then to accept of the remaynder that shalbe, although it should proue 10000 li. But in case it should proue more his Maᵗʸ to haue only 10000 li and yᵉ rest to be bestowed as is afore expressed. That the Tobacco to be brought in be consigned in one hand, viz of such officers as yᵉ saide Company shall appoynt. And that the saide Company haue the sole menadging of the saide sale of Tobacco. That the Aduenturers of each Plantation shall not be bound to bringe in any greater Quantities of Tobacco then themselues shall thinck good. It is lykewise desired, that for recouery of all such debts as shall from tyme to tyme growe due to yᵉ Companies by occasion of this Contract, the saide debts may be assigned ouer vnto the kinge, when & soe often as need shall require.
2635:
MAY, 1626

They likewise desire that there may be inserted in the Contract, a Graunt & Couenaunte from his Maᵗʲ against the grauntinge of lycences to Retaylers of Tobacco: Soe that the Sale thereof may remayne free as hetherto it hath done. That his Maᵗʲ be pleased to take a strickt course for the preuenting of all vndue bringinge in of Tobacco by other meanes. That all confiscations and other penalties vppon this Contract be deuided into three parts. The one parte to his Maᵗʲ use, the other to the Companies, the third to the Informers.

This extracte of all the titles & estates of land was sent home by Sr. Francis Wyatt (when hee returned for England) unto the Lords of his Majesty's Privy Councell, according unto their Order in their letter Dated at Salisbury

W. Cawbourne May 1625

CDLXXIV. Councin in Virginia. A Letter to THE Privy Council

JUNE 15, 1625

(1) Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, pp. 14, 14a. (2) C.O. 1, Vol. II, No. 41 Document in (1) Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.; (2) Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 761

Right. Honorable

We have received order from Your Lordships for returning an Account of Mr. Pountis his estate together with the goods themselves, An Inventory we have taken, by which Sr. Thomas Merry may understand the value thereof to be far short of what is conceived, and his debts both by reason of his own engagements, and entangling himself with the estates of other men, Ten times exceeding the same, Therefore we humbly desire to be excused that we send not home the goods, The most part whereof are not worth the Transport, to the end the Creditors may receive some part of Satisfaction

May it please your Honors to take knowledge that we are informed that Sr. Thomas Merry Knight as Executor to Mr. Powntis, doth sue Mr. John Bache for the payment of two hundred pound with the Country assigned unto him

158507 ie -37
2644:
560 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

towardes the supportance of his Charges in the solicytinge of theire affaires, A publique protestatione beinge made by the saide Mr. Powntis, that he would receiue the money by parcels as he should haue occasion to vse it, and render an accoumpt of his disbursements, and to restore the remainder, now Since no money was expended, and our suite not prosecuted, by reason of his death at his first arival vppon the Coaste, The Country humbly by us solicyte your Lorpps, that they not both lose theire cause and theire Charges, But that you woulde be pleased out of your Lorpps accustomed equitie to take such order, That Sr. Thomas Merry his suite may not proceed to the pervertinge of the intentione of theire gifte, and the equitie of the cause itselfe, To which we doupt not yt he beinge soe worthie a gentleman, will willinglie condiseende, We haue further to acquant your Lorpps that his Maie Comissioners for the affaires of Virginia haue written vnto us to send home the Tobacco levied for the discharge of the two hundred powndes yf it had been paide & consigne it to them, Which we desire wee may nott be forced vnto, beinge more grevious then yt former, seinge those goods, the money not beinge paide, is theire owne that gave it. Wheras Capt John Martin formerly recomended by your Lorpps. and lately nominated by his Maiesties Comissioners to be one of his Counsell in Virginia, hath proved him selfe altogether vnwoorthie of either, as is evident, yf your Lorpps shalbe pleased to pervse them, by many depositions and other particulars, in so much as we haue been foreed owt of yt service wt we owe to his Maiestie & this Countrey, to suspende him from the Executione of his place, wherin we proceeded accordinge to the awthoritic formerly given, And ratified by his Maiesties Comissione, and the Comissioners order, To whom we affoorded all respect and favor, not w'standinge his many delinquencies from his first entrance into the Lande, vntill they grew to soe erent an excess as was dangerous to his Maiesties service, and extreamely preiudiciall to the Colony, and we humblie desire that this may be accepted as our iuste excuse. We haue vnderstood from one of his Maiesties Commissioners for Virginia, that his Maiestie is highlie incensed against us for punishinge one Edwarde Sharples, who beinge farr aboue his qualitie and condicione after the death of Mr. Secretarie, Into whose service at his earnest request, he was first receaued, admitted to wright vnder us as a Clarke, and sworne not to deliuer any
2645:
JUNE 15, 1625

561 copies of our writings without leave from the Governor, the contrary to his oath and dutie, had upon a secret practice, delivered our papers which greatly concerned us, committed to his charge, for which his perfidiousness and perjury, he was set on the Pillory and lost a piece of one of his ears, though his sentence was to lose them both, which hath been so misreported & aggravated to his Majesty, as other things also have been, as a bloodie and barbarous Acte, and we threatened with such foul and injurious terms as if we were below the Condition of freemen. We humbly desire Your Lordships that we may not tread as upon thorns, in all our actions through the malice of our traducers, nor be subject to their violent insultings. Lastly, we are humbly to offer to Your Lordships consideration the desperate estate of this Colony, by the late pernicious contract which hath diverted his Majesty's royal intentions and bounty to this Colony in granting us the sole importation of Tobacco, (we well ordered, would certainly and suddenly advance the Plantation, by the present enabling us for works of worth and continuance, but by converting the benefit thereof to their private and inordinate lucre, hath given the Colony the greatest blow that ever it received, And without speedy redress, will prove incurable, and cause this noble and hopeful Action to be deserted. The effects whereof begin to disclose themselves in our scant and miserable supplies, at most unconscionable rates, and in the general discouragement of the whole Colony. And we may not be silent, that some whom His Majesty hath appointed Commissioners for those affairs, are contrivers & favorers of this Contract, [MARGINAL NOTE: 14a] Contrary to their duties and the trust imposed upon them by his Majesty, and some of them already by their deriding and triumphing upon those miserable wants that we are already fallen into, show they well enough understand the inevitable pernicious consequences of the Contract, which will, as they say, make us rather to be pitied than expostulated with all. Besides the malicious designs which are now in plotting and Contriving to overthrow his Majesty's public ministers, who have discharged their Consciences in his Majesty's service with all integrity and fidelity, And we no longer desire his Majesty's favor, which is more than life unto us, than their intentions shall appear to tend to the destruction, And our endeavors to the upholding and advancement of the Colony. Thus humbly desiring Your Lordships to take our innocence into your Honor's patronage, and that according to the Custom of the former...
2646:
562 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

tymes We may not be Condemned before we be heard, and that the Colony may not fail whilst it is in our Charge by the sinister practice of others, who frustrate all our endeavors we humbly take our leaves, And rest and remain James Citie the 15th of June 1625.

Your Lorpps most humble Servants

Samuel Mathews  
George Sandys  
Francis Wyatt  
Abraham Persie  
Roger Smith  
Francis West  
Wm Cleyburne  
Ralph Hamer  
George Yardley

To the Right Honorable the Lords of his majesty's most Honorable Privy Council.

CDLXXV. Council in Virginia. A Letter To THE COMMISSIONERS FOR THE AFFAIRS OF VIRGINIA June 15, 1625 Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt.i, pp. 12a-13a Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. List of Records No. 762

Right Honorable &c.

We have had many royal assurances of his majesty's great care and favor to this Plantation & we return our humblest thanks unto his Highness, that (notwithstanding the revoking the former Patent) he hath graciously promised, not only to confirm, but to enlarge with ample privileges the private interests of Adventurers & Planters.

It is true there hath been a late decrease in the progress of Adventures and supplies sent hither, but in other respects the Colonie was in a hopeful way & in as good a Condition as ever, howsoever his majesty hath been informed the Contrary as appears by your Letters to our no small prejudice.

We have to our utmost abilities endeavored to discharge that trust imposed upon us by his majesty in his late Commission, but we hope that we shall be shortly eased of this burden, the Commission being only for the present, in particular, Sir Francis Wyatt doth render all humble thanks to his majesty that he was graciously pleased to dispense with his service, in
2647:
JUNE 18, 1626

563

grauntinge leave at his choyse, to retourne, Although at our ernest requeste, and his zeale to the Action he is Content to staye a little longer, the arivall of a new Gouernor, wch we haue longe expected. It is no new thinge to us to be wronged by the defamation of malitious rumors, wheras this concerninge Capt Haruy may match any in falshoude, and we desire that the awther therof, yf it cann haue any, may be noted wth yᵉ infamye of a slanderer, and we wounder that such a rumor should goe vnecontrolde, when Mr. Porye one of his maties Comissioners was present at the fynell conclusione of that busines, and coulde haue certified the Contrarie. We had by the laste shippe sente a generall muster wherof we now sende you a copie wth additions of the distances of the severall Plantationes, How they haue been since awgmented, you shall know by the next generall muster, wch we intende, God willinge to take after yᵉ next harvest. We haue wth these retourned you an Accoumpte of wch lands, goodes, servants, Tenants, howses, boates or shipps, are any waye belonginge to the Compeny, and wch belonge to yᵉ Offices stated by the Compeny, as farr as we coulde learne by oath or otherwyse. Concerninge the depts and the moytie of the labors of the Compenys Tenants, Mr. George Sandys now returned hath brought into us an accoumpte, wch we heerewith send you. That transactione made by the Compenye to the Gouernor and Mr. George Sandys was in pte of Satisfactione of their pmised meanes, a due dept, and not a gifte, And to haue it wrested from them, vppon the revokinge of yᵉ Pattent, we accounmipie it a greate oppressione consideringe his ma eraeyous pmise of preservinge yᵉ pticuler interest of every man, other alienatione we know nott of. We hope yᵗ no man doupts but yᵗ it was necessarie to enioyne yᵉ Planters to finde men towardes yᵉ erectinge of a Blockhowse, though it fayled in suecess, through many misaccidents, easier to Censure, then to haue prevented, the five pounde of Tobacco p pole was not imposed, Lest a voluntarie contributione of such as had been at no charge conceringe the same, to ease the burthen of others, of wch little hath been gathered, The tenn
2648:
564 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

pownde of Tobacco was also a voluntary gift of yᵉ Countrey, and yᵗ charges allowed very necessary, neither could it be expected, considering our troubles, but yt they should have been much greater, Howsoever yᵉ Clamor of some suborned calumniators may have moved you to call it a pretext, And we hope that yᵉ free Acts of the Countrey shall not be farther questioned to the prejudice of any man. The accompts thereof as much as have been received we have herewith returned. The fower pownde of Tobacco p pole was given by yᵉ Countrey to Mr. Pountis Conditionally yᵗ he received the money and solicited yᵉ cause of the Countrey, wᶜʰ failing, the Countrey conceives yᵗ it must in justice and equity returne to themselves, as yᵉ true proprietors thereof, Besides as we understande, there is like to be suite about yᵉ recovery of the two hundred pownde by Mr. Pountis his Executor, wᶜʰ although we doubt not, when the case shall be truly knowne, will appear to have no Colour of law or conscience, yett in the meane tyme it is necessary yᵗ yᵉ saide Tobacco should remain as a securitie to those yᵗ stande engaged, wᶜʰ is yᵉ generall desire & resolution of yᵉ Countrey. The merchants were never enforced to take Tobacco at three shillings the pownde nor did they allow us above twelve pence a pownde at the moste as the Commodities were worth in Englande, But we found it absolutely necessarie to set some bounde [t]o the sea of their Covetousness, that would else have overwhelmed all, although the penalty of their daily failing were never exacted, and since, They have taken more libertie to themselves upon this new order, The wᶜʰ have been enhanced so intolerably, as if it continue but a yeere to an end, the Colonie will utterly be ruined, neither see we how it can be redressed, except the late pernicious contract be overthrown, wherein we doubt not of your uttermost assistance, as the most Important service you can do to his Maᵗʸ for yᵉ upholding of the Colonye.

[13] Mr. Blany [&c (on next page)] Mr. Blany never meddled wᶜʰ the disposing of the maides, But Mr. Pountis by whose death the accounts are left much entangled & perplexed, many in yᵉ list mentioned, wᶜʰ have made payment and most of yᵉ rest pretend the like, of wᶜʰ yett we have not had tyme to examine the proofs, That of
2649:
JUNE 16, 1626

The Shipwrightes and the glass workes given in by Mr. George Sandys we herewith send you, the death of one of the principall workmen, another being subject to the falling sicknes, and many defects which render the worke unserviceable, Hath moved us to condescend to the importunate suite of the glass men of returning for England, which worke so long, as there was any hope, was supported by Mr. George Sandys to his great charge and hinderance. We have taken caution of them to be at the disposall of the Adventurers till the expiration of the time of their Covenants. The account of Southampton hundred, we refer to Sir George Yardley who is now returning for England who allegeth that it was a duty belonging unto Mr. Pountis, unto whom he resigned all the estate and accounts of that Plantation, when that society first appointed him Treasurer, but since he heard of his death he hath diligently enquired into the state thereof, and will be ready to acquaint you, how it standeth at present. Those transcripts which you require, will ask more time, in any tolerable sort to perfect, than the stay of those ships will afford, Mr. Cleybourn's accounts you shall receive herewith. The oath hath been administered to those nominated in his Majesty's Commission, but since, for many weighty causes we have been forced to suspend Capt. John Martin from the exercise of his place, a man of a prostituted conscience, a sower of dissension and sedition, one from whose false accusations no innocency can be safe, disobedient to Government, and a person exceedingly dangerous to the state and Colonie, and we humbly desire he may not be restored, without our removal. We should be ready with our utmost endeavors to assist your pious work of the East India free school, but we must not dissemble, that besides their unseasonable arrival, we doubt that the age of Mr. Carclett will overbalance all his other sufficiency, though exceedingly good, and the number so few, as little will be expected from them. They were not able to subsist of themselves upon certain cleared ground which they might have had in Martins hundred, and came in so late as they could hardly have housed themselves, but what accommodations they could possibly give them, was offered by Mr. Horwood and Mr. Linersone, but Mr. Carclett utterly refused to seat there, though we advised him to it, he pretending that many of you disliked.
2650:
566 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

of that place, and that the charge of disposing the men lay upon him, The account of the people and goods formerly sent for the East India school, we herewith send you. We desire that their zeal who have traduced us in that business may hereafter be joined with some better knowledge, and that casual failings by mortality and otherwise, may not be charged upon us. We have received the twelve barrels of powder sent in the Temperance, for which we render our humblest thanks to his most excellent Majesty. The long stay of the Elizabeth makes us doubt her safety, if she miscarry this portion and our former store being utterly exhausted, and no hope left of supply from private Adventurers, will hardly enable us to defend our houses, much less to prosecute our revenge upon the salvages, and therefore we earnestly desire, that with the first, it may be supplied in a large proportion, one hundred barrels of powder being but a yearly competency for the numbers here. Concerning Ursula French there is security put into the Court in the behalf of Elias Long that one hundred weight of the best Tobacco shall be paid in for the said Ursula French at the next crop. Concerning the Cattle in Controversie between Sir Samuel Argall & the Company, we return you the account (from those to whom they were severally disposed by Sir George Yardley by order from the Company) of so many as we find to be remaining. We find that you have been exceedingly misinformed by Mr. Blany, the land she claims being excluded by a proviso in the Patent, and the goods most of them being due to the said Capt. Matthews, by Capt. Powell, and long before her return the accounts cleared between him and Mr. Blanye. A Copy of the Patent and the case as it appeared to us, together with the several depositions, and the order thereupon concerning the same, send you. It appears that Capt. Matthews was seated upon the said Land near twelve months before he was questioned at all by them, and no Complaint brought before us, till Mr. Blany's return out of England, by which means Capt. Matthews hath proceeded in great Charge in Building and clearing, which however the case may prove, ought in Conscience & equity to be satisfied, and exceed the value of the land. We herewith...
2651:
JANUARY 4, 1625/6

Mounsier Bomonte is arived, and accordinge to your order we haue geven him the best Accomodatione we maye. [13a] Thus humbly desiringe that false reports may not gaine creditt above our publique informationes, and that wronge Courses contrary to our certin knowledge and experience may not be taken, To the indangeringe of the Colony, And that our true and faithfull endevours may haue due acceptatione, recomendinge all to the protectione of the Allmightie, We humbly take our leaues, and remane, At your Comandes James Cyttie the 15 of June 1625

SAM: MATHEWS
George Sandys
Francis Wyat
Abra: Pierse

To the right Honorable the Lords and other his Ma'ties Commissioners for the affayers of Virginia

CDLXXVI. Governor and Councell in Virginia. A LETTER TO THE COMMISSIONERS FOR VIRGINIA January 4, 1625/6

(1) Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, pp. 68a, 69. (2) C. O. 1, Vol. IV, No. 1 Document in (1) Library of Congress, Washington, D. C., signed; (2) Public Record Office, London List of Records No. 763

Right Honorable,

Vppon the 20th of December last arived the good Shipp called the flyinge harte of Viushinge set out by Mr. Arthur Swaine & William Counstable Adventurers of the Company, who brought no Commissione with them, the Mr. Huett (who was to be their Pilott) beinge employed to London for procuringe a Commissione, returned not, though they staide for him a longe tyme to their great hinderance. Wherfore conceivinge it not any willfull error or neglect, we haue offered them the priviledge due to Adventurers, Chiefly in regard the extreeme wants of the Country enforced us, howsoever.
2652:
568 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

not to refuse supplyes, Besides the wante of a Comissione, we finde yt aboue halfe ye passengers com in wᵗʰowt any pvisione at all, who although they com in as servantᵉ to Planters, who havinge been seated heere may be supposed to haue made provisione for them, Yet til the Countrey be better aforehande, a care would be had, not only to new Comers, but even to Planters that they com over well pvided, But that wᵗʰ happilie is the gretest inconyenience is, yt after so longe an expectacione, and soe great Charges they come wᵗʰowt any letters or Direction at all, to guide or proceedingᵉ, All wᵗʰ we humbly desire yt you would be pleased to take into your Considerationes And accordinge to your graue wisdomes to prevent ye like inconvenyences heerafter, and to give us instructiones yf ye like case should happen at any tyme, What one our ptes is to be done. Notwithstandinge these irregularities, the substance of the newes they bringe is soe ioyfull and welcome, as after many discomfortes and perplexities, hath revived the harte of all men namely yt it hath pleased God, to place in the Royall Throne, our gracious Soueraigne Charles (whose happie Raigne God of his mercy longe Contynue over us) who not only in pietye, iustice, and wysdome treads in the stepps of his Royall father of famous memory, butt in his affectione and favor to this hopefull Colony, not only by contynuinge ye favors formerly granted, but by addinge and enlarginge them, and takinge the care therof, amidst ye multiplieytie of his great affayres, into his more neere and speciall Consideratione, wᵗʰ gives us assured hope that our petieyons, formerly exhibited, shall haue a favorable admittance & such order taken therin, as may best conduce to the advancement of the Plantatione, wᵗʰ as it is noe lesse to be Cherished in the flourishing tymes of peace, then necessary to advance ye enterprises of warr, Soe it well agrees wᵗʰ ye fortitude and magnanimitie of his most excellent Matᵉ (wherin he emulates the glorie of his renowned predecessors, to prosecute and give perfectione, by his Royall favor and Bountie to this Honorᵃᵇˡᵉ Action. We humbly therefore desire you to make remonstrance to his gratious highnes, That not only we are vtterlye vnfortified against a forren Enymie, wᵗʰ we are now allways to expect, but our store of powder and munitione (of late soe scantlie supplyed) is soe extreme shorte as is not sufficient to secure our Plantations against our Domestique Enymies much less for defence againste Invasion, prosecutione against the Treacherous Salvages (and the last supply of powder sent in the Elizabeth Qᵘᵗʰowt wᵗʰ royall Bountie of his Maᵗʸ we could not haue subsisted) cum in so late in Sommer.
2653:
JANUARY 4, 1625/6

As the time of preparation for cutting down the Salvages' corn was past, and since no addition being made, we cannot furnish ourselves of any for that so necessary service, our surcease of ours, out of mere necessity, gives the Salvages a hope of our inclination to peace, of which they are infinitely desirous, whereby it is probable that they will plant great quantities of corn in known places, so as if supplies of people, powder, and munition come in in time, we may have fair opportunity to revenge their former treacheries, which we have, and ever shall be most willing to perform with our utmost abilities, although we hope that some course will be taken to ease the country of that great charge.

About the middle of July last arrived Capt. Jones in a Spanish frigate which he had taken in the West Indies under the commission of the States, as he pretended, granted to Capt. Powell, from whose consort ship he separated himself, and put in here for relief, his vessel being very leaky and their victuals spent. She brought in no prize, but some few raw hides which by negligence lay sunk in the ship and were spoiled. He himself died shortly after, and since his death, there are rumors risen contrary to their first examinations, of mutinies and disorders committed by Jones and some of his company against Capt. Powell, of which perhaps we may have more light from England or the Low Countries, according to which, we may the better know how to proceed, since we conceive the substance of their acts against the Spaniards are not now too strictly to be questioned. They brought in with them for their pilot out of the Gulf (wherein they had lost themselves divers months) a Portuguese, who seems to be expert in all places upon the coast of the West Indies who is yet living, how to dispose of him we know not till we hear from you.

Upon your former letters, we did forbear to execute our proclamation concerning the rates of commodities, though we then certified you how excessive they grew, and have since exceeded all bounds and limits, but finding that notwithstanding it hath pleased his majesty to disannul the pernicious contract, prices rather increase than diminish, we have been constrained to revive by the former edict by a new proclamation, whereof we herewith send you, desiring that we may rather be believed in that we find necessary to the upholding of the colony, than every Jack who speaks only for their own ends, submitting it to...
2654:
570 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

your Judgments, whether by soe lowe prysinge of our Tobacco for the encoragement of Adventurers we do not more preiudice ourselves then them, What benefitt shall we haue by the sole ymport yf we haue not twelve pence the pownd for our Tobacco, in exchange for Commodities? how can we compell the Planter to make his Tobacco principall good, wch now soe concernes us, yf he be still enforced to make soe great quanteties to furnish them wt necessaries, And wheras it may be conceived yt by the fullnes of supplies prices will fall of them selves, there is little hope thereof, and in the meane tyme we shall come to as desperate a Condicione by debts and poverty, as we are now in by the scantnes. How can it be imagined, That the countrey should be fully supplied, Wheras accordinge to the rates lately Currante, two Thowsande pownde adventure will exhauste all the one Cropp. The Gouernor hath longe expected a Successor and the necessitie of the estate compelleth him not to putt off any longer his retourne for Englande, wch suiteth the purpose also, for wch though we hope it is alredy provided, yett holde it our dutie to make advertisement thereof. We haue been enforced for wante of advice and a new Commissione to proceed accordinge to the former, And we humbly desire yt our continuing the same forme & course of our proceeding may be interpreted as donne owt of necessitie, lest the Colony (in the interim) should suffer wante of due order and Gouernment. Lastly beseeching you to take such order, that we may not heerafter be or amazed in our busines for want of direction, And yt our endeavors in his Maties service may not be frustrate for wante of meanes, we humblie take our leaues, Restinge At your Comands

Francis Wyat
Fra. West
Roger Smith
Ralph Hamer
Abraham Persey
William Cleyburne.

James Cyttie about the 4th of January 1625

To the right Honorable the Lords & other his Maties commissioners for the affaires of Virginia.
2655:
APRIL 6, 1626

571

CDLXXVI. Governor and Councell in Virginia. A Letter to the Privy Councell

APRIL 6, 1626

Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. ii, pp. 69a-70 Document in Library of Congress, Washington, D. C., signed List of Records No. 764

Right Honobl

The 23rd of March arived the good shipp the Virgen of Southamptone with Lres from your Lopps of the 24th of October laste, Wherby we understande his Ma** royall care of this Plantation, as well in present supplie of our wants, as in takinge order for the full and pfect setlinge of ye affayrs therof. To the greate encoragement of the whole Colony, She bringeth us an earnest of those larger supplies gratiouslie promised by Ma**, in Commodities though in proportion not answerable to our great wants yett all very vsfull and well conditioned, for which we must acknowledge our great bonde to your Lopps & in pticuler to our singular good lorde The Lor Highe Threag.

We must ever acknowledge it a singuler favor from his Ma**, That he hath been pleased to remitt the ympositione vppon Tobacco in Consideratione of supplyinge of the Colony and we humbly desire that your Lopps will be pleased to take order, that it may be as well performed on their parts as promised, since we understande not as yett of any shipp sett out by them, Except it should be the William & John, which is a smale shipp, and her course by the west indies, As the tymes are, full of hazarde, and makes our supplie by her, very vncertaine, neither can it be greate, as well in respect of ye Passengers which she is to lande there, as of the Commodities which may be likelie to be vented there.

Nothinge hath been longe more ernestly desired, then the setlinge of the affayres of the Colonie, as well for the Gouerment as otherwayes, neither could there have been a greater Incouragement to the Planter, Than to vnderstand it to be his Ma** gratious pleasure, That noe psone of whome they have heertofore iustlie complayned, should have any hand in the Gouerment, (either heere or there) And we humbly desire your Lopps to solycite his Ma** (yf it be not alredye donne) for the spedy Accom-
2656:
572 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

plishment thereof, The rather because the Governors necessary occasions require his present returne. His ma'ties gratious assurance yt every man shall have his particular right preserved with addition of reasonable immunities, will be a singular means of inviting many people hither, and settling themselves here, Who for ye most part heretofore, (by reason of the many distractions & discouragements, have only endeavored a present Cropp, and their hastie returne, To ye great hinderance of raising staple Commodities, & all works of worth and Continuance, with all men will with earnestness and alacrity apply themselves to, when their thoughts are fixed in this Country, And much the rather, if your Lordships shall obtain of his Ma'ty the remission or the present of the imposition of 5 upon Tobacco, & other commodities, for the perfecting whereof, since as yet we must be unable by upholding the price of Tobacco, We humbly beseech his ma'ty to continue his favor in prohibiting the importation & sale of all Tobaccos, except from this Colony and the Sommer Islands, And here we cannot but make remonstrance to your Lordships how prejudicial those petty Plantations of the English in the Salvage Islands in the West Indies, must prove to this Colony, in effect to the utter overthrowing of the benefit of the sole importation granted to us by his ma'ty, both in respect of the quantities they may send, And that under Color thereof, much Spanish Tobacco may be imported & vented, And if the said prohibition be not strictly and precisely looked to, ye merchants who now hardly keep themselves within the bounds of our proclamation concerning the rates of commodities) will take advantage thereupon to enhance his prices excessively, Whereby the Colony will be kept in poverty as formerly.

Those great and important works, of surprising the Indians, discoveries by sea and land, fortification against a foreign Enemy, that they may be thoroughly and effectually performed, will require no less numbers than five hundred soldiers to be yearly sent over for certain years, with a full year's provision of victuals, apparel, arms, munitions, tools, & all necessities, To which worthy designs, The Colony will be always ready to yield their best furtherance & assistance, as they have been very for-
2657:
APRIL 6, 1626

573

warde since the massacre, notwithstandinge their great losse then sustained, And we conceive so great expence will haue the better success, if the ordering thereof be referred to the Governor and Counsell here residing, with the advise (in speciall cases) of the generall Assembly, both concerning this and all other things which may conduce to the settling of the Plantation. We have formerly given your Lordships advertisement, in the generall Assemblies answer to the fower propositions propounded by your Lordships to the Commissioners sent hither, And we doubt not but Sr. George Yardley hath given your Lordships full information of all things necessarie, And that nothing be wanting on our parts, by the next ships we will give your Lordships more full advertisement what courses we conceive most proper and assured for advancement of this noble Action. (70) Tending so much to the glory of God, and his majesty's honor, As far as experience upon the place shall enable our weak abilities. By the next also we shall advertise your Lordships of the Titles & estates of the severall owners of lands and other particularities required by your Lordships, wherein we could not give your Lordships present satisfaction, those ships being suddenly to Depart. We shall exactly observe his majesty's Command that all judgments, Decrees, and important Actions be given, determined, & undertaken, by the advise and voices of the greater part of the Councell (which course also we heretofore observed in all our proceedings) And that all be done in his majesty's name, under whose royall Government and protection, this Action (which hath hitherto labored under so many Difficulties) shall we doubt not receive the due perfection, And (as we never did) so we shall always forbear the Choosing of any Officers for longer time than during his Majesty's pleasure. Thus beseeching your Lordships to Continue the Patronage of this Plantation, that the beams of his majesty's favor may by your mediation and Councells shine, and be derived upon us, to Cherish our Endeavors, And quicken our new springing hopes, that no Contrary gust may nip them in the bud.

budd, nor envious cloude interpose it selfe betwen us & that comfortable light, we humbly take our leavs,

Your Lopps very humble servantes

James Cyttie the 6th of Aprill 1626.

Addenda CCCXLV

A. The King. Commission to Sir WILLIAM JONES AND Others

May 9, 1623

(1) Patent Roll 21 James I, part 19. (2) Virginia Miscellaneous Records (Blind copy), pp. 126-132

Document in (1) Public Record Office, London; (2) Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

James by the grace of God kinge of England Scotland ffrance and Ireland defender of the faith etc. To our trustie and welbeloved Sir William Jones knight one of our Justices of our Courte of Comen Pleas Sir Nicholas ffortescue knight Sir ffrancis Gofton knight Sir Richard Sutton knight Sir William Pitt knight Sir Henry Bourchier knight and Sir Henry Spiller knight greeting Whereas amongest the many memorable works undertaken sithence our happie Raigne over this our Realme those of the English colonies and plantations in Virginia and the Sumer Islands are of special importance as being the first forraigne Colonies planted by our English Nation and tending not onely to the propagation of God's glorie and Christian Religion but alsoe to the enlargement of the Territories and Dominions of our Crowne and the Increase of trade and Commerce whereby our people and subjects may be enriched And therefore Wee being graciouslie enclyned to soe glorious and publique a worke have from tyme to tyme and vppon all occasions vouchsafed our gracious and royall Assistance to the furtherance and incouragement thereof not onely by graunting unto the Adventurers and Planters large Charters and ample priviledge but enabling them to

2660: 576 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY raise Great somes of money towarde the vndergocing of the necessarie charges of the said plantacons And now being advertised aswell by the humble Peticon of some of the Adventurers themselves as otherwise That aswell by occasion of discord and discontentment amonge themselves as of sondrie misgovernments and other disturbances and impediments the prosperous and happie proceeding and growth of that worke hath byne and is daylie more and more like to be interrupted vnles We in our Princely providence shall putt a remedie therevnto Wee therefore vppon deliberate consideration hereof are constantlie resolved to pursue our former purpose and by all good meanes to expresse the continuance of our zeale and affection in restoring and settling that soe glorious a worke Whereof god hath byne pleased to make vs a principall Instrument and to take awaye all obstacles and hindrances that may any waye seeme to disturbe or crosse the quiet and peaceable proceeding in the same ffor the better effecting of which our resolucon Wee hold it most fitt that some persons of trust and vnderstanding be imployed to discerne discover and fynde out the whole State of the Premisses vppon whose informacon Wee may proceed to the effectinge thereof as Wee shall iudge most requisite Whereby the worke being reestablished may proceed and prosper to our honor and those religious and publique ends for which it was first intended Knowe yee therefore that wee reposing assured trust and confidence in the approued wisdomes fidelities and circumspections of you the said Sir William Jones Sir Nicholas ffortescue Sir ffrancis Gofton Sir Richard Sutton Sir William Pitt Sir Henry Bourchier and Sir Henry Spiller have assigned and appointed you to be our Commissioners And Wee doe hereby give vnto you or any fower or more of you full power and authoritie to view peruse and consider of all and singuler Charters Lres Patents Proclamacons Commissions and all other Acts orders and directions made or sett downe by vs or our privie Councell or by the company or Councell for Virginia warrants records books Accompts entries and other notes and writings whatsoever concerning the said Colonies or Plantations or concerning the severall Companies or Corporation to whome the care of the said Colonies or Plantations apperteyneth and aswell thereby as by examination of any witnes or witnesses vppon oath or without oath or by any other lawfull waies or meanes whatsoever to enquire discover fynd out and informe yourselves whither the said Charters Lres Patents Proclamacons Act orders and directions

577 have been observed performed and kept according to the true intent and meaning thereof or whether the same have bene violated infringed or broken and by whome and in whose default and what damage hurt and hinderance to the said Plantations and Colonies have thereby ensued and byn occasioned. And vppon due consideration thereof and of all other things needfull to trye and fynde out the true estate as well in tymes past as at this present of the said Colonies and Plantations and either of them in every respect. And of all incidents and circumstances therevnto belonging. And further Wee doe hereby give vnto you or any fower or more of you full power and authoritie by such examination vppon oathe or without oath or any other wayes or meanes as is aforesaid to enquire search discover and fynde out what somme or sommes of money at any tyme heretofore have byne levyed or collected either by contribution of Adventurers voluntarie guifte or bequest lotteries collections, adventures in magazines or by any other wayes or meanes whatsoever for or towarde the furtherance of the said Colonies or plantations or either of them or any the busines or affaires concerning the same and to whose handes the same monyes have come and how and in what manner and by whome the same some and sommes of money and every parte of them have bene expended or disbursed and whither the same have byn expended or disbursed as they should or ought to have byne for the good of the said Colonies and plantations and whither any and what parte or partes of the said Soffe or Somes of money have bene converted vsed or ymployed to the vse of any private person or persons or to any vse other then for or towarde the necessarie vse helpe and furtherance of the said plantations and to whose or to what vse or vses and what damage any such misployment hath bene to the said plantations and by whome and by whose meanes consent or procurement any such misimployment hath bene made or done with the grounds and causes thereof and all other necessarie circumstances in any wise touching the premises and what is and what in probabilitie of reason might have bene the true estate and condition of the said plantations and either of them at this present tyme by the proportion of the expence of soe much money as hath bene levied collected and gathered for the vse of the said plantations and either of them. And further Wee doe hereby give vnto you or any fower or more of you full power and authoritie by such examination vppon oath or without oath or any of the wayes or meanes aforesaid to enquire search discover and fynd.

MARCH 8, 1628

579 frauds, deceipts, wrongs, and iniuries hereafter to be done or committed in the governing, managing, ordering, or disposing of the businesses and affaires of the said Colonies or plantations or to be done unto any Adventurers or Planters in the same, and for the condigne punishment of the Offendors, and for the reconciling and taking away all contentions and differences and preserving peace and unitie amongst them. And to doe all other Acts and things whatsoever which to you or fower or more of you shall be found meete and convenient whereby this Our Commission may be fully executed according to the tenor of the same and our pleasure therein declared and the said Plantations established to the ends and purposes before mentioned. And to the end our said pleasure herein declared may take the better effect, Wee doe likewise hereby give unto you or any fower or more of you full power and authoritie to cause to come before you or fower or more of you all such person and persons as you shall thinke fitt to appeare before you for the better discovery of the truth in any the Premisses and to cause all and every person and persons as well such as are supposed to have offended in any the Premisses, their servants or Agents, as all and every person and persons being or which have bene Clerks or Officers of the severall Companies or Corporations of Virginia or the Summer Islands and any other person and persons whatsoever to bring and shewe before you or any fower or more of you as is aforesaid all and singuler such letters patent, proclamations, Commissions, warrants, Records, orders, books, accounts, entries or any other notes or writing whatsoever remayning in their or any of their Custodie which you or fower or more of you shall thinke fitt to be produced whereby the truth in the Premisses may the more playnely appeare. And to the end noe person may have just cause to complayne or be greeved at your proceedings in this behalfe, Our pleasure is that when and soe often as any examination of any person or persons shall by vertue of this our Commission be taken upon oath, That then and soe often upon request made by the parties whom the same shall concerne, you or any fower or more of you may examine the same or any other person or persons either upon oath or otherwise for the defence of such person or persons making such request if you or fower or more of you upon due consideration shall thinke it just and fitt. And our further will and pleasure is, And Wee doe hereby charge and command you our said Commissioners or foure or more of you to certifie unto the lords and others of our privie Councell from tyme to tyme your proceedings therein.

A. Councit and Assembly. Laws and Orders! March 5, 1623/4

(1) C. O. 1:3, no. 9. (2) Manuscript Records Virginia Company, III, pt. i, pp. 8, 8a Document in (1) Public Record Office, London; (2) Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. List of Records No. 642

Lawes & Orders cone * * * by the Councill [&] Assemblie Marche the 5 Anno 1623

1 That there shalbe in every Plantatione, wher the people vse to meete for ye worshipp of God, [a house] or Roome sequestred for yt purpose, And not to be for any temporall vse whatsoeuer, and a place e[mpaled in,] sequestred onlye to the buryall of the dead.

2 That whosoeuer shall absent him selfe from devine service any Sounday wthowt an alowable e[xuse] shall forfeit a pownde of Tobacco, and he yt absenteth himselfe a moneth shall forfeit 50° of Tobacco.

1 This important document, inadvertently omitted from its chronological place, was printed in 1809 by W. W. Hening in the first volume of his Statutes at Large of Virginia, pp. 122-127. At that time somewhat more of the document now in the Library of Congress was legible than can now be read, some of its margins having since been worn away. The words and parts of words here printed in square brackets are supplied from Hening's text.
2665:
MARCH 5, 1628/9

3 That there be an uniformitie in our Church as neere as may be, to the Canons in Englande both in [substance] and Circumstance and that all persons yeeld redie obedience vnto them vnder paine of Censure.

4 That y 22 of March be yeerly solemnized as hollidaye, and all other holliday (except when they fall two together betwixt the feast of y° Annuntiatione of y° blessed Virgine and St Michaell Thearkfangel,) then only the first to be observed by reason of our necessities.

5 That no minister be absent from his Cure aboue two moneths in all y° yeere vppon penaltie of forfeitinge halfe his meanes, and whosoeuer shall absent his aboue fowre moneths in the yeere shall forfeit his whole meanes and [Cure.]

6 That whosoever shall disparage a Minister wthout bringinge sufficyent proofe to iustifie his reporte, whereby y° mindes of his parishioners may be alienated from him, and his Ministery proue the lesse effectuall by theire [prejudice,] shall not only pay 500 waight of tobacco, but also aske y° minister so wronged forgiuenes publiquely in the Congregation.

7 That no man dispose of any of his tobacco before the Minister be satisfied, vppon paine of forfeiture double his [part] of y° ministers meanes, and one man of euery plant’ to Collect his meanes owt of y° firste & best Tobacco and Corne.

8 That the Gouernor shall not laye any taxes or impositiones vppon y° Colony, theire landes or comodities otherwise then by the authoritie of y° generall Assemblie, to be levied and ymployed as the saide Assembly shall appoynt.

9 The Gouernor shall not withdraw the inhabitante from theire privatt labours to any service of his owne vppon any couler whatsoever, and in case the publique service require ymploymente of many handes before y° holding of a generall Assemblie, to give order for y° same, in that case the leuiinge of men shalbe donne by order of the Gouernor and whole bodye of the Counsell and y° in such sorte as to be least burthensume to the People and most free from partialitie.
2666:
582 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

10 That all the olde planters, that were here before, or came in at the laste cominge of Sr. Tho: Gates they and their posteritie shalbe exempted from their personall service to the warres, and any publique charge (Church dewties excepted) that belongeth particularly to their persons, (not exemptinge their families) except such as shalbe employed to commande in Cheif.

11 That noe burgesses of the generall Assembly shalbe arrested duringe the time of the assemblie, a weeke before & a weeke after, vppon paine of the creditors forfeiture of his debt, & such punishment vppon the officer as the Courte shall awarde.

12 That there shalbe courtes kept once a moneth in the Corporations of Charles Cittie & Elizabeth Cittie for the decydinge of suites and Controversies not exceedinge the value of one hundred pounde of Tobacco, and for punishinge of pettie offences, That the Comanders of the places and such others as the Gouernor and Counsell shall appoynte by Commissione shalbe the judges, with reservatione of Apeale after sentence to the Gouernor and Counsell, and whosoever shall Apeale yf he be here caste in suite shall paye double damages, The Comanders to be of the quorum and sentence to be given by the maior parties.

13 That every privatt planters devident shalbe surveyed and laide out in severall, and the boundes recorded by the surveyor; yf there be any pettie differences betwixt neighbours about their devidents to be devided by the surveyor, yf of much importance to be referred to the Gouernor and Counsell: the surveyor to have 10 lb of tobacco vppon every hundred Acres.

14 For the encouragement of men to plant store of Corne, the price shall not be stinted, but it shalbe free for every man to sell it, as deere as he can.

14 That there shalbe in every Parish a publique Garnery unto which there shalbe contributed for every planter exceeding the age of 18 yeere alive at the Crop after he hath bene here a yeere a bushel of Corne, the which shalbe disposed for the publique uses of every parish by the maior parte of the freemen, the remainder yeerly to be taken out by the owners at St Tho: his day and the new bushel to be putt in the roome.
2667:
MARCH 6, 1628/9

16 That three sufficyent men of every parish shalbe sworne to see that euery man shall plant & tende suffycient [of Corne] for his family, those men that haue neglected soe to doe are to be by the saide three men presented to be Censured by the Gouernor and Counsell.

17 That all trade for Corne with the Salvages aswell publique as private after June next shalbe prohibited.

18 That every freeman shall fence in a quarter of an Acre of grounde before Whitsuntide next [to make a garden] for plantinge of Vines, hearbs, rootes &c. sub pena tenn pounde of Tobacco a man, but that [no man for his] owne family shalbe tyed to fence above an Acre of Lande, and that whosoeuer hath fenced a garden and tyed of the lande shalbe paide for it by the owner of the soyle; they shall also plant Mulberry trees.

19 The Proclamation for Swearinge and drunkennes sett out by the Gouernor and Counsell [are confirmed by] this assembly, and it is further ordered that the Churchwardens shalbe sworne to [present them to the] Commanders of every plantation, and that the forfeiture shalbe Collected by them [to be] for publique vses.

20 That A proclamation be read aboorde every shipp and afterwardes fixed to the mast of [such ship, prohibitinge them to break bulke or make private sales of any Comodities, untill they come to] James Citty, without speciall order from the Gouernor and Counsell.

21 [That the proclamation of the] rates of Comodities be still in force and that there bee [some men] in every Plantation to Censure the Tobacco.

22 That there be no waightes nor measures vsed, but such as shalbe Sealed by officers Appoynted for that purpose.

23 That every dwellinge House shalbe Pallyzadoed in for defence against the Indyans.

24 That no man goe or sende Abroade without a Sufficyent partie well armed.

25 That men goe not to worke in the ground without their armes (and a Centynell vppon them.)
2668:
584 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

26 That the inhabitants goe not aboard shipps or vppon any other occasions in such numbers, as thereby to weaken and endanger the Plantation.

27 That the Commander of every Plantation take care that there be sufficient of powder and munition within the Plantation under his Commande, and their pieces fixt & their armes compleat.

28 That there be due watch kept by night.

29 That no Commander of any Plantation do either himselfe or suffer others to spend powder unnecessarily in drinking or entertainmente, &c.

30 That such persons of qualitie as shall be found delinquent in their duties being not fit to undergoe corporall punishment may notwithstanding be imprisoned at the discretion of the Commander, and for greater offences to be subject to a fine inflicted by the monthly Court, so that it exceed not the value aforesaid.

31 That every man that hath not contributed to the finding 2 men at the Castell shall pay for himself and servant 5 pounds of Tobacco a head, toward the discharge of such as had their servants there.

32 That at the beginning of July next the Inhabitants of every Corporation shall fall upon their adioyning Salvages as we did the last yeere, those that shall be hurt upon service to be cured at the publique Charge, in case any be lamed to be maintained by the Country according to his person and qualitie.

33 That for defraying of such Publique debt or troubles have brought upon us, there shall be levied 10 pounds of Tobacco upon every male head above sixteen years of age now living (not including such as arrived since the beginning of July last.)

34 That no person within this Colonie upon the rumor of supposed change and alteration presume to be disobedient to the present Government, nor servants to their private officers, masters or overseers, at their uttermost perils.

35 That Mr. John Pountis Counsellor of State, go into England (being willing by our intreatie to accept of that Imployment to solicite the generall...
